The move comes as part of a broader crackdown on the internet sector, following criticism from the Chinese Consumer Association and state media calls for regulation. The guidelines apply to major firms such as Alibaba, Didi Global, and ByteDance, which use algorithms to predict user preferences and make recommendations.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Top Glove, IHH Healthcare, ComfortDelGro, GuocoLand
summary: Top Glove plans to renew its application to list in Hong Kong and pursue a dual primary listing. The company's shares rose 0.8% on the Singapore bourse following the announcement. This comes after the company resolved a US import ban on its products due to alleged forced labor practices.

site_title: Oil rally falters on pandemic surge, renewed Mexico supply
summary: Oil prices fell on Thursday, snapping a three-day rally, due to concerns over rising Covid-19 infections and renewed Mexico supply after a fire disrupted production. Oil prices dropped 1.6% to $71.07 a barrel for Brent crude and 1.4% to $67.42 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate. Mexico's state oil firm Pemex has begun restoring output after the fire, but efforts may lag projections. Energy companies are also preparing for a severe storm in the US Gulf Coast.

site_title: Virgin Australia to add nine planes to fleet ahead of expected travel rebound
summary: Virgin Australia plans to add nine Boeing 737-800 planes to its fleet from October, increasing its capacity and aiming to gain a one-third share of the domestic market. The move comes as vaccination rates rise and state borders reopen, with Virgin CEO Jayne Hrdlicka citing pent-up demand for domestic travel. The airline's fleet will reach 77 planes, still smaller than pre-Covid levels, but a step towards recovery. Virgin aims to have the new planes in the air by mid-February, as the Australian domestic aviation market is expected to rebound.

site_title: Gold steady as investors eye taper clues from Fed symposium
summary: Gold prices remained steady at US$1,793.68 per ounce, awaiting Fed chief Jerome Powell's speech at the Jackson Hole symposium. US central bank officials called for paring bond purchases, while gold imports in China fell 29% in July. The market was also cautious after an Islamic State suicide bomb attack on Kabul airport. Silver was flat, platinum rose 0.3%, and palladium increased 0.2%.

site_title: Apple will change App Store practices after settlement with small developers
summary: Apple has reached a proposed settlement with small developers on a class-action lawsuit over its App Store practices, including commissions of up to 30%. The settlement covers developers who made $1 million a year or less and releases claims that Apple's commissions were too high. As a result, Apple will make changes to its business practices.

site_title: Biden warns Kabul airport attackers: 'We will hunt you down'
summary: US President Joe Biden vowed to hunt down and make accountable the attackers of twin explosions at the Kabul airport, killing 12 American troops. He ordered the development of operational plans to strike ISIS-K assets and announced a response with force and precision at a time, place, and moment of his choosing. The US evacuations will continue without a change in the next Tuesday's pullout target.

site_title: Ex-deputy group director of LTA pleads guilty to taking S$1.24m in bribes
summary: A former deputy group director of the Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore, Henry Foo Yung Thye, pleaded guilty to taking approximately S$1.24 million in bribes in the form of loans from contractors and sub-contractors. Foo, who had a gambling habit, solicited the loans in exchange for advancing the contractors' business interests with LTA. He faces a sentence of at least six years and three months' jail. Foo's case is considered the largest case of public sector corruption to have been prosecuted in recent times.

site_title: Wing Tai Holdings profit jumps 173% amid higher revenue
summary: Wing Tai Holdings, a Singaporean property and retail player, reported a 173% jump in net profit to S$43.6 million for the full year ended June 30, driven by a 24% increase in revenue to S$461.4 million. The company attributed the revenue growth to higher contributions from its development properties. Despite a net loss of S$13.2 million in the first half of 2021, Wing Tai recommended an ordinary dividend of three cents per share and a special dividend of two cents per share.

site_title: Malaysia PM retains finance minister, senior figures in Cabinet
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob has unveiled his Cabinet, reappointing Finance Minister Tengku Zafrul Aziz and other senior figures from the previous administration to restore stability. Sabri was sworn in last week after Muhyiddin Yassin's resignation due to a razor-thin majority. The new Cabinet aims to address public anger over the government's handling of the Covid-19 surge and economic lockdowns. With nearly half of Malaysia's population fully vaccinated, Sabri's appointment brings back the United Malays National Organisation (UMNO) to the top office, marking the third prime minister since the 2018 election.

images.alt_text: Malaysian Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob unveiled his Cabinet on Friday, re-appointing the finance minister along with several other figures from the previous administration, as he looks to restore stability after months of political turmoil.

site_title: SGX prices maiden US$250m bond issuance at 1.234%
summary: SGX successfully issued a US$250m 5-year bond at a coupon rate of 1.234% with 88% of orders coming from Asian investors. The bond was allocated to fund managers (50%) and banks (31%), with the remaining 21% going to institutional investors. The strong investor interest reached an order book of US$2.3 billion, exceeding the issuance amount.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end lower on virus, policy jitters
summary: European stocks fell 0.3% on Thursday amid concerns over the US Federal Reserve's plans to taper stimulus and a decline in German consumer morale. The Stoxx 600 index, a pan-European benchmark, dropped as mining and travel stocks led losses. The US Federal Reserve's chair, Jerome Powell, is set to speak at the Jackson Hole symposium, where investors await hints on the central bank's plans. A survey showed German consumer morale fell for the second month in August, while travel companies like Tui and airlines like Wizz Air declined.

site_title: BlackRock faces key test in booming 100t yuan China market
summary: BlackRock is launching its debut mutual fund product in China, marking the first test of investor appetite for its products in the country. The company's new unit, established with China Construction Bank and Singapore's Temasek, has obtained regulatory approval and plans to offer a quant equities product. This move comes after BlackRock won approval to become the nation's first wholly foreign-owned mutual fund firm. The launch is seen as a significant milestone for BlackRock's expansion into China's booming 100 trillion yuan market.

site_title: Living the loft life
summary: A couple, Cheryl Tan and Philip Tai, transformed a 50-year-old walk-up apartment in Singapore into a unique and spacious home. Designer Lam Jun Nan removed walls and false ceilings to create a seamless flow of space, taking advantage of the high ceilings to make the apartment feel larger. The apartment features an industrial-chic aesthetic, with grey and black colors, brick walls, and metal accents. The couple, who wanted a New York City apartment feel, now use the apartment as a weekend home, enjoying its stylish spaces and pet-friendly features.

images.alt_text: The open kitchen and dining area allows for the homeowners and their guests to freely mingle.
The sculptural spiral staircase connecting the common areas to the private study in the mezzanine.
A brick wall and the use of greys give the living room an industrial vibe.

Left: Steps leading to the bedroom on the lower level, where there is a standalone glass wardrobe, and a slide for the owners' dogs. Right: A sculptural beam in the bedroom is converted into a photo display space.
The hotel-like master bathroom has a vanity area that looks out onto the greenery.

site_title: US: Wall Street loses ground, snapping rally on Afghanistan, Fed concerns
summary: US stocks closed lower on Thursday, snapping a streak of all-time closing highs, amid concerns over developments in Afghanistan and potential shifts in the Federal Reserve's policy. The S&P and Nasdaq fell, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.54%. Hawkish commentary from Dallas Fed president Robert Kaplan and a blast outside the Kabul airport strengthened risk-off sentiment. The Fed is expected to begin tapering asset purchases in October, according to Kaplan, but the exact timeline remains unclear.

site_title: China's push for 'common prosperity' may drive assets overseas if not for curbs
summary: China's President Xi Jinping has outlined a plan to regulate and redistribute excessive wealth, aiming to achieve "common prosperity" through a fair redistribution of wealth. The government plans to expand the middle-income group, adjust excessive incomes, and make fiscal transfers to promote social mobility. China has 5.28 million millionaires, with the richest 1% holding 30.6% of the country's wealth. The government will also introduce a property tax pilot and a state-led campaign against excessive spending. However, experts warn that the plan may drive assets overseas due to capital outflow restrictions, and that the government should not interfere with entrepreneurial activities.

site_title: Winners and losers in China's sweeping private-sector crackdown
summary: China's private-sector crackdown has led to significant stock market declines in gaming, after-school tutoring, healthcare, and liquor sectors, with the MSCI China Index subgauges plummeting 21% since June 30. Industry leaders such as Tencent Holdings, Alibaba Group Holding, and Meituan have seen their shares tumble, while pharmaceutical companies and online medical-service providers have also been hit. However, industries seen as crucial for China's green goals and self-reliant manufacturing ambitions, such as semiconductors, renewable energy, and electric vehicles, have gained traction, with investors piling into companies like Ganfeng Lithium and Trina Solar.

site_title: Lawyers behind billionaire Ackman's retreat may target more SPACs: sources
summary: Lawyers behind billionaire William Ackman's SPAC retreat may target more SPACs, according to sources. The group, led by former US SEC Commissioner Robert Jackson, filed lawsuits against three blank-cheque acquisition firms, accusing them of operating illegally by not registering as investment companies. The lawsuits, filed on behalf of a shareholder, claim that SPACs have breached the Investment Company Act by investing in US government bonds and money market funds instead of merging with a company. The lawyers, who also represent a "frequent filer" shareholder, may target up to 50 SPACs, potentially putting off companies from proceeding with mergers.

site_title: Analysis: Evergrande to speed up asset sales as hopes swirl about government lifeline
summary: China's debt-laden property developer Evergrande is accelerating asset sales to raise cash, amid government efforts to avoid a hard landing for the company. Analysts say Beijing is prioritizing social stability, safeguarding suppliers and employees, over creditors. Evergrande's debt has swelled to 1.95 trillion yuan, and its stock price has nosedived. The government has instructed banks to roll over maturing loans and is considering a creditor committee to facilitate a restructuring. Evergrande's liabilities, accounting for 2% of China's GDP, may trigger systemic risks if not swiftly defused.

site_title: Selangor Dredging looks to sell conserved freehold building at guide price of S$18.9m
summary: Malaysian developer Selangor Dredging Berhad is selling a conserved freehold commercial building in Singapore's Kallang River area at an indicative price tag of S$18.9 million. The 18-storey building, integrated with the 117-unit freehold Jui Residences, has been fully approved for restaurant use on the ground floor and office use on the second floor. The property features a 30-metre-long main road frontage, a communal roof terrace, and access to park connectors along the Kallang River, offering potential for value-add opportunities such as outdoor refreshment areas or rooftop cafes.

site_title: The return of the Michelin Guide
summary: The Michelin Guide will unveil its 2021 Singapore results in a virtual presentation on September 1, marking the first time the livestream will be open to the public. The event comes as the F&B industry faces a slower-than-expected recovery after a year of dining closures due to the pandemic. While some restaurants are optimistic about the boost, others express concerns about the impact of the pandemic on their businesses. The virtual presentation will also provide a morale boost for chefs and restaurateurs, who are eager to see their hard work recognized.

site_title: NTUC calls for payouts for jobless PMEs beyond current grants
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) is calling for monetary support beyond current grants for professionals, managers, and executives (PMEs) who have lost their jobs in Singapore. PMEs, particularly mature ones, face job security worries and require greater support in employment and training opportunities. NTUC is pushing for policies like career fair participation and resume submission requirements to prevent unemployment benefits from discouraging people from working. The organization also aims to increase hiring opportunities and skills upgrading for mature PMEs to address workplace discrimination and support them in transitioning to quality jobs.

site_title: Japan PM faces challengers in LDP leadership race
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga faces challenges from former foreign minister Fumio Kishida and ex-internal affairs minister Sanae Takaichi in the upcoming Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) leadership race. Suga, struggling with crumbling approval rates, has vowed to seek re-election in the Sept 29 race. The winner is virtually assured of becoming prime minister due to the LDP's majority in parliament's lower house, which must lead the party to a general election by Nov 28. Kishida's campaign focuses on listening to the people and offering broad choices, while Suga's ratings have sunk below 30% amid Japan's COVID-19 crisis.

site_title: A more sustainable future for aviation in Asia, post-Covid
summary: The aviation industry in Asia is poised for recovery post-Covid, with strong growth forecasts in air travel and air cargo. However, concerns over the industry's environmental impacts, particularly climate change, are growing. Airlines have committed to net-zero carbon emissions, and sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) is seen as a key solution. Governments in the region are reviewing policies to support the adoption of SAF, with Singapore and New Zealand proposing mandates. Collective efforts from governments, regulators, and industry leaders are necessary to create a more sustainable aviation sector, with technological innovations and collaborations crucial to achieving this goal.

site_title: GuocoLand's net profit up 48% for FY21 to S$169.1m
summary: GuocoLand, a Singapore-based property developer, reported a 48% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$169.1 million for FY21, despite a 9% fall in revenue to S$853.7 million. The decline was attributed to lower sales from its Singapore residential projects and the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on its hotel segment and investment properties in Malaysia. The company sold 1,500 units in FY21 with a total value of S$1.4 billion, and its shares closed flat at S$1.62. A final dividend of 6 cents per share is proposed.

site_title: The smart car buying guide
summary: There is no article content provided for "The smart car buying guide".

site_title: The war for talent is real: LinkedIn Asia-Pac MD
summary: LinkedIn Asia-Pacific managing director Feon Ang emphasizes the importance of nurturing and managing talent. As the face behind LinkedIn's first-ever global government collaboration from Singapore, Ang aims to improve Singapore's perception of human capital. She believes in constant learning and has implemented strategies to track leadership development, which can boost the country's global competitiveness.

site_title: German consumer morale drops heading into September
summary: German consumer morale has declined, dropping to -1.2 points for September, according to a GfK survey of 2,000 Germans. Rising inflation and increasing Covid-19 cases have made consumers more hesitant to buy. Germany's harmonized annual consumer prices rose 3.1% in July, a 13-year high. The decline in consumer morale is attributed to accelerating inflation and concerns about the economy, with 61.3 new coronavirus infections reported per 100,000 people. The decline in consumer sentiment may impact private consumption growth in the coming month.

site_title: China to continue with people-oriented growth as top priority
summary: China's Communist Party of China (CPC) has released a publication outlining its 100-year journey to rejuvenate the country and vision for the future, with people-oriented development as its top priority. The party aims to become a modern socialist country by 2035, while continuing its reforms and opening up the economy globally. Despite acknowledging that the journey will not be smooth, the CPC promises to break any shackles hindering common prosperity, equity, and justice. The party also emphasizes the importance of cooperation and mutual benefits with global neighbors, and vows to pursue development in a way that is more efficient, equitable, and sustainable.

site_title: Wing Tai Holdings profit jumps 173% amid higher revenue from Le Nouvel Ardmore, The M
summary: Wing Tai Holdings reported a 173% jump in net profit to S$43.6 million for the full year ended June 30, driven by a 24% increase in revenue to S$461.4 million. Higher contributions from development properties, including Le Nouvel Ardmore and The M, accounted for the revenue growth. The company also declared an ordinary dividend of 3 cents and special dividend of 2 cents per share. Despite a stable residential property market, Wing Tai expects rising construction costs due to manpower shortages and reduced productivity, prompting prudence in liquidity and capital management.

site_title: Five art shows to catch this week
summary: Five art shows are returning in Singapore post-Phase 2 (Heightened Alert). The Word For World Is Forest by Khairulddin Wahab at Cuturi Gallery showcases lush aesthetics and complex paintwork on large canvases, depicting human attempts to control nature. Before The Birth Of Eden by Joanne Pang at Yavuz Gallery features radiant fusion of colors and textures, exploring the nature of memory. Remembrance Of A Friend by Chng Seok Tin at The Arts House highlights the artist's reliance on sensory intuition after losing her eyesight. A Most Absurd Guide by various artists at UltraSuperNew Gallery offers outrageous and absurd works. Only Losers Left Alive - Part Two at Yeo Workshop imagines a post-apocalyptic scene with works that explore the human condition.

site_title: Game on for Asia's e-sports scene
summary: Asia's e-sports industry is experiencing rapid growth, generating 68% of the world's total e-sports revenue in 2019. The region is home to major events like the League of Legends Championships, with the 2020 edition attracting over 139 million viewers. Data analytics plays a crucial role in e-sports, enabling players to optimize gameplay, teams to gain an edge, and the industry as a whole to increase revenue. As the industry continues to expand, there are golden opportunities for data experts, with teams, event organizers, and companies seeking top analytical talent.

site_title: Toshiba in talks with four investment firms for strategic ideas: sources
summary: Toshiba is in talks with four global private equity firms, including KKR & Co Inc and Blackstone Inc, to seek their ideas for a new strategy. The move comes after the company's chairman was ousted in June following a scandal involving collusion with the Japanese government. Toshiba has launched a strategic review and plans to engage with potential investors, but it's unclear if this will result in formal buyout bids. The company has pledged to present its new business plan in October.

site_title: Re-imagining adult learning for the workforce of tomorrow, today
summary: Singapore's training and adult education (TAE) sector has strengthened employee skills and built workforce resilience amid the pandemic. A McKinsey Global Survey found 69% of respondents prioritizing learning and development. The sector has leveraged digital technology to improve learning outcomes, with 76% of adult educators expecting future enrolment in online skills training programmes to rise. Innovative modalities, such as AI-powered platforms, are being developed to enhance workforce reskilling and upskilling, and the TAE community is embracing a hybrid adult learning model to support a future-ready workforce.

site_title: UK car output plunges on semiconductor shortage
summary: UK car production plummeted to 53,438 vehicles in July, the lowest level since 1956, due to a 38% decline from last year and ongoing semiconductor shortages. The 'pingdemic' also affected production, as workers were forced to isolate after being contacted by the NHS Covid-19 app. The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) is calling for the government to reduce energy levies and business taxes for the sector. Similar issues have plagued auto manufacturers worldwide, with Volkswagen's Wolfsburg plant restarting on only one shift.

site_title: Oslo-listed Barramundi Group considering dual listing on SGX
summary: Barramundi Group, a Singapore-based sustainable fish farming company, is considering a dual listing on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) following its recent listing on the Euronext Growth Oslo. The company aims to triple its production output to 7,000 tonnes by 2026 and achieve profitability in its Singapore and Australia operations within the next 12 months. With a new farm in Brunei expected to deliver its first harvest in three years, the company hopes to serve the export market. Barramundi Group's revenue rose to S$28.4 million in FY2020, and the company is targeting gross margins of 30-50% by 2026.

site_title: US dollar rises from one-week low as taper bets grow
summary: The US dollar rose from one-week lows due to growing bets on the Federal Reserve's tapering of monetary stimulus, as signaled by Jerome Powell's speech at the annual Jackson Hole conference. The conference, which began in a virtual format, is expected to shape market expectations for the Fed's monetary policy. US Treasury yields remained near 1.35%, supporting the dollar's uptrend.

site_title: Vietnam Airlines aims to start first US flights in late October
summary: Vietnam Airlines plans to launch its first US flights in late October, using either Boeing 787 or Airbus A350 aircraft on the Ho Chi Minh City to San Francisco route. The carrier aims to mitigate losses from the pandemic by transporting cargo to offset low passenger demand. Vietnam Airlines is facing a 75% drop in revenue this year, with a loss of 7 trillion dong in the first half of 2021, and may seek government support in September.

site_title: Google brings Samsung's 5G modem tech to US market
summary: Google will use Samsung's 5G modem technology in its next flagship Pixel smartphone, marking the Korean firm's first win in the US market dominated by Qualcomm. This partnership signals Samsung's growing influence in the US market and its capabilities in chipmaking. Samsung will manufacture the processor and supply the 5G modem technology for Google, ending the company's reliance on Qualcomm. This move gives Samsung its first big chance to showcase its skills to the wider phone industry.

site_title: 112 new locally transmitted Covid-19 cases; 40 linked to Bugis Junction cluster
summary: Singapore reported 112 new locally transmitted Covid-19 cases, with 40 linked to the Bugis Junction cluster. Of the remaining cases, 31 were linked to previous cases, 17 were not in quarantine, and 24 were unlinked. Four imported cases were also detected, bringing the country's total to 66,928.

site_title: Tensions flare over trade dropouts in US$7t currency market
summary: Tensions over the last look practice in the global currency market remain high, with traders and liquidity providers disagreeing on guidelines released by the Global Foreign Exchange Committee. The new guidelines aim to improve transparency and fairness, but critics argue they do not go far enough in addressing concerns about unfair trading practices. Industry players are pushing for more formal external oversight, with some suggesting a regulatory structure could be the solution to the ongoing issues.

site_title: Peruvian food and fun at Canchita
summary: Canchita, a new Peruvian restaurant in Singapore, brings a dose of friendly hospitality and comfort food to Dempsey. Chef Tamara Chavez's menu features dishes such as ceviche, tacos, and Peruvian Chinese favorites like Lomo Saltado and Arroz con Mariscos. The restaurant's easy-going vibe and endearing chef are matched by its heartwarming and substance-filled food, including pureed beans, potatoes, and rice. Canchita is a rare Peruvian restaurant that's enjoyable for both purists and those new to the cuisine.

site_title: US jobless claims see small rise but growth remains strong
summary: US jobless claims rose to 353,000 in the week ended August 21, slightly more than expected, but still within the downward trend seen in recent months. Economic growth in the second quarter was revised to be better than initially reported. The labour market remains tight, with most workers unwilling to be laid off. The Delta variant of the virus is expected to impact hiring, not jobless claims, which are closely watched as a metric of labour market health.

site_title: A dish millions can agree on
summary: A book titled "Instant Comfort: A Collective Memory" features over 100 Singaporeans sharing their personal stories and recipes about instant noodles. The book includes contributions from well-known chefs, politicians, and celebrities, and has raised over S$600,000 for two children's charities. The book showcases various methods of making the best bowl of instant noodles, from simple recipes to creative hacks, highlighting the dish's significance in Singaporean culture.

site_title: US Q2 economic growth revised slightly higher; weekly jobless claims rise
summary: The US economy grew at a 6.6% annualized rate in Q2, exceeding expectations, as massive fiscal stimulus and vaccinations boosted spending. The growth lifted the GDP above its pre-pandemic peak. Consumer spending, accounting for 2/3 of the economy, drove the growth, while the Federal Reserve maintained its ultra-easy monetary policy stance. However, momentum slowed in Q3 due to a resurgence of Covid-19 infections and supply chain bottlenecks. Economists expect 7% growth this year, the strongest since 1984, with growth expected to pick up in Q4.

site_title: Two blasts at Kabul airport; casualties include civilians, US service members
summary: At least two explosions occurred near Kabul's airport, resulting in US and civilian casualties, including at least 13 reported deaths and multiple injuries. The blasts, potentially from a suicide bombing, happened near the Abbey Gate and the Baron Hotel, prompting a large evacuation effort by the US and its allies. The US Embassy had warned of "security threats" and advised citizens to avoid the area, with the airlift continuing despite the warnings.

site_title: A gold grocery shopping experience
summary: CS Fresh Gold, a premium grocery shopping experience, has opened at Paragon in Singapore, offering a wide selection of international cheeses, delicatessens, organic produce, and vegan and plant-based brands. The store features an upscale shopping experience with an exclusive tie-up with Ryan's Grocery for dry aged beef and Crystal Jade for prepared roasts. CS Fresh Gold also partners with HUON, a sustainable and ethical salmon fisheries, and features a dog treat bar. The launch is part of Dairy Farm Singapore's S$40 million rebranding exercise to refresh all 48 outlets by end-2022.

images.alt_text: CS Fresh Gold has an exclusive tie-up with Ryan's Grocery, well-known for its dry aged beef and premium meats.
Some of the produce on offer at the newly opened CS Fresh Gold at Paragon.

site_title: Wall Street boom or bubble? Don't blame it all on the Fed
summary: US stocks have reached an all-time high, with the S&P 500 more than doubling from its COVID-19 low and setting a record for 51 highs this year. While the Federal Reserve's asset purchases are a contributing factor, experts argue that the tech-heavy composition of Wall Street and strong economic growth are driving the surge. The US equity market's high price-to-earnings ratio, above 20, is also attributed to the Fed's policies and investors' willingness to pay premiums for US stocks.

images.alt_text: The tech-heavy composition of Wall Street, which benefits more from low interest rates and plain old stronger economic growth, is adding fuel to the US stock surge.

site_title: India lifts Boeing 737 MAX ban, leaving China as final hurdle
summary: India has lifted its ban on Boeing's 737 Max jet, allowing it to resume flights in the country. The decision comes after Boeing met local requirements, including setting up a simulator, and observed "no untoward reporting" on jets flying since 17 global regulators allowed it to resume flights. This move leaves China as the only leading aviation market yet to allow the aircraft to fly again. Boeing is still working with Chinese authorities to lift the ban there, with test flights conducted and commercial flights potentially resuming in months.

site_title: How did the football transfers game get crazy?
summary: The football transfer market has become unsustainable, with teams struggling to afford top players due to inflated values. The rise of ultra-wealthy owners and the increasing spending power of clubs has led to record-breaking transfer fees, with a 100 million-euro fee no longer shocking. This phenomenon is attributed to the interconnected ecosystem of agents, sponsorships, broadcast rights, and owner spending power, which have driven up values. The consequences of this trend are being felt, with Barcelona reportedly unable to afford its most valuable player.

site_title: WHO begins shipping Chinese vaccines despite some misgivings
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) plans to ship 100 million doses of Chinese Covid-19 vaccines, mostly to Africa and Asia, by the end of August. This shipment will help the Covax vaccine sharing programme, which is behind its 2 billion dose pledge due to supply problems and export curbs. The move could boost Beijing's vaccine diplomacy efforts despite concerns over the efficacy of the Chinese shots.

site_title: Two explosions hit Kabul airport, at least 13 including children killed
summary: Two explosions hit Kabul airport, killing at least 13 people, including children, and injuring an unknown number of others. The blasts occurred near the Abbey Gate and the Baron Hotel, with reports suggesting a possible suicide bombing. The attacks come as thousands gather outside the airport for evacuation, with US and allied troops racing to depart by August 31. The Taleban, who are guarding the perimeter, also face a threat from the Islamic State group, ISIS-K.

site_title: The world economy's supply chain problem keeps getting worse
summary: The world economy's supply chain problem is worsening, with the Delta coronavirus variant causing factory production disruptions in Asia and shipping delays. Manufacturers are facing shortages of key components and higher costs, leading to bidding wars for shipping space and record-high freight rates. This is expected to continue into 2022, with economists warning of potential inflation and a slowdown in global recovery. Companies such as Toyota and Hong Kong-based Musical Electronics are feeling the impact, with some even canceling shipments altogether. The transportation bottleneck is at the heart of the problem, with many Asian producers relying on networks of small and medium-sized producers that struggle to secure shipping space.

site_title: UK targets 'endless' cookie pop-ups in data shake-up
summary: The UK has announced plans to reform its data protection rules, aiming to eliminate "endless" website pop-ups asking for user permission to store cookies. Digital Secretary Oliver Dowden said the pop-ups are "pointless" for most websites, while high-risk sites will still need to ask for permission. The reforms are part of the UK's push to harness data and secure global partnerships, potentially putting it at odds with the European Union's data law. The EU has warned that changes could affect its recognition of the UK's data protection standards.

site_title: Singapore-based Omnilytics acquires Malaysian data startup in US$20m deal
summary: Singapore-based Omnilytics acquired Malaysian data startup Supahands in a US$20 million deal. Supahands, which develops training data for AI applications, will strengthen Omnilytics' fashion analytics and insights software. The acquisition aims to fill a critical gap in Omnilytics' tech capabilities, with Mark Koh joining as a board member and chief strategy officer. The deal marks a pivotal step in Omnilytics' journey to become retail's most important data stack.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 15.94 points to 1,585.74. The index saw 580 gainers for every 506 losers, with a total volume of 4.385 billion lots worth RM3.254 billion.

site_title: US Q2 GDP growth revised slightly higher
summary: US GDP growth in the second quarter was revised to a 6.6% annualized rate, higher than initially thought, as massive fiscal stimulus and vaccinations boosted spending. The economy has recouped losses from the Covid-19 recession and consumer spending, which accounts for over two-thirds of the US economy, also increased. However, momentum appears to have slowed in the third quarter due to a resurgence in Covid-19 infections and supply chain bottlenecks. Economists expect growth to pick up in the fourth quarter and overall growth of around 7% this year, the strongest since 1984.

images.alt_text: The US economy grew a bit faster than initially thought in the second quarter, lifting the level of gross domestic product above its pre-pandemic peak, as massive fiscal stimulus and vaccinations against Covid-19 boosted spending.

site_title: Forbes agrees to go public through merger with Magnum Opus SPAC
summary: Forbes Global Media Holdings agreed to go public through a merger with Magnum Opus Acquisition, a blank-cheque firm, valuing the combined company at $630 million. Forbes' management team will remain in place after the deal, expected to close in late 2021 or early 2022. The merger aims to capitalize on Forbes' brand and technology to convert readers into long-term, engaged users through memberships and targeted product offerings. The deal is the latest in the active news-media space, following BuzzFeed's agreement to go public with a special-purpose acquisition company in June.

site_title: Greatearth goes bust; five BTO and two public projects hit
summary: A Singaporean main contractor has gone bust, impacting five Build-To-Order housing projects and two public projects. The affected BTO projects include Sky Vista @ Bukit Batok, Senja Heights and Senja Ridges in Bukit Panjang, and Marsiling Grove in Woodlands. The five projects have over 2,982 units, and the delays are expected to affect more than 2,900 homebuyers. The main contractor's bankruptcy may also impact two public projects, causing possible hold-ups.

site_title: Top Glove plans to renew lapsed listing application
summary: Top Glove Corp plans to renew its lapsed application to list in Hong Kong and pursue a dual primary listing, following the resolution of forced labor issues in its operations. The company, the world's largest glovemaker, had delayed its plans due to a US import ban. Top Glove has been waiting for US customs authorities to verify remedial action taken on workers' recruitment fees. The company intends to renew its HKEX listing application as soon as practicable, reducing the proposed listing size to US$1 billion.

site_title: China's 'common prosperity' push does not mean 'killing the rich', official says
summary: China's "common prosperity" push, aimed at easing inequality, does not mean targeting the rich, an official said. Instead, it encourages those who get rich first to help others, while promoting hard work and rational income adjustments. The government aims to increase rural disposable incomes to 44,000 yuan per year by 2025, compared to 17,000 yuan in 2020. Recent policies regulating internet companies and tightening anti-monopoly rules aim to curb cost-of-living pressures and promote social responsibility, but do not target private or foreign companies.

site_title: GuocoLand's net profit up 48% for FY21 to S$169.1m, despite dip in revenue
summary: GuocoLand reported a 48% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$169.1 million for FY21, despite a 9% fall in revenue to S$853.7 million. Lower sales from Singapore residential projects and the Covid-19 pandemic impacted hotel and investment properties. The company sold 1,500 units worth S$1.4 billion and proposed a final dividend of 6 cents per share. GuocoLand stated it has become more resilient against disruptions and will leverage its capabilities to identify and seize opportunities.

site_title: STI little moved as investors await tapering hints at Jackson Hole on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose marginally by 0.06% on Thursday, awaiting Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell's hints on tapering at the Jackson Hole symposium on Friday. Dairy Farm International was the top performer, while ComfortDelGro was the top loser. Asian markets were mixed, with declines in South Korea and Australia offset by gains in Malaysia and Japan.

site_title: Police arrest man over injecting food at three London supermarkets
summary: British police have arrested a man after injecting processed meats and microwaveable products with needles at three supermarkets in west London. The incident occurred on Wednesday evening, causing the stores to close. People who bought food from the supermarkets on that evening are advised to discard their purchases. The man is being questioned on suspicion of contamination of goods with the intention of causing public harm. Investigations are ongoing to determine if other businesses in the area are involved.

site_title: Banks have little choice but to binge on govt debt
summary: Banks are investing heavily in government debt due to a decline in borrowing demand from businesses and consumers. The COVID-19 pandemic's lingering effects, including supply chain issues and uncertainty about office reopenings, have reduced loan demand. As a result, banks are forced to invest in government bonds, which offer low returns, rather than taking on riskier loans. This trend is expected to continue until companies and entrepreneurs have a better sense of economic certainty, and it may help keep interest rates low for the time being.

site_title: Oxley posts full-year net profit of S$49.5m, reversing last year's losses
summary: Oxley Holdings has reported a net profit of S$49.5 million for the full year ended June 30, reversing a loss of S$275.1 million in the previous year. Revenue increased 33% to S$1.4 billion, driven by higher revenue from projects in Cambodia, Singapore, and Ireland. The company achieved positive cash flows of S$623.6 million and repaid S$600 million of fixed-rate notes. Oxley is targeting 100% sales of its Singapore development projects by the end of the year, with its overseas projects achieving "tremendous success" in the past year.

site_title: MOH investigating two new Covid-19 clusters at Punggol and Toa Payoh bus interchanges
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore is investigating two new Covid-19 clusters at Punggol and Toa Payoh bus interchanges. All staff at both interchanges will be tested for Covid-19. The Punggol cluster has 11 cases, including 10 employees and a household contact, while the Toa Payoh cluster has 25 cases, all of whom are staff members. The MOH will conduct widespread testing to contain the spread of the virus.

site_title: Taiwan eyes jet fighter buy amid modest hike in 2022 defence spending
summary: Taiwan plans to spend $1.44 billion on new fighter jets, as part of a $471.7 billion defense budget for 2022. The move comes amid increased pressure from China, which has stepped up military activity near Taiwan. The budget represents a modest 3.4% increase from this year's spending, and includes funding for advanced, mobile weapons to deter a potential Chinese invasion. Taiwan's defense spending is the third-largest government expenditure for 2022, after social welfare and education.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close flat ahead of central bankers meeting
summary: Tokyo stocks closed flat on Thursday, awaiting the outcome of the Jackson Hole symposium of central bankers. The Nikkei 225 index edged up 0.06%, while the Topix index inched down 0.02%. Investors are cautious ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's speech on Friday, which could signal changes to the US central bank's policies. Economists expect no major headlines from the meeting, with Powell unlikely to provide details on easing up on bond purchases.

site_title: From HDB to private property: the dollars and sense
summary: Singaporean first-time private property buyers must consider various costs, including a 5% upfront deposit, option fees, stamp duties, and valuation fees. The maximum loan is capped at 75% of the purchase price, and borrowers must adhere to a 60% total debt servicing ratio. Mortgage structure is key, with shorter loan tenures reducing interest costs. Tenancy-in-common arrangements have become more popular, particularly among couples planning to buy multiple properties for inheritance. Mortgage insurance can mitigate risks, and buyers should prioritize paying a premium for this coverage.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) proposes changes to listing rules, requiring listed companies to disclose climate-related information and provide details on board diversity policies. Auditors face increasing complexity in ESG reporting, while manufacturing growth in Singapore is expected to slow due to a chip supply crunch. A private equity firm, Firmus Capital, acquires Le Quest Mall in Bukit Batok, and five HDB projects in Singapore face further delays due to contractor insolvency. The Straits Times Index (STI) remains little changed, awaiting hints on tapering at the Jackson Hole meeting on Friday.

site_title: Japan keeps economic view intact, bleaker on outlook due to Covid
summary: Japan's government maintained its economic assessment for the fourth straight month in August, citing a resurgence in Covid-19 infections as a factor in consumer spending. The report noted the economy is "continuing to pick up" but faces "weaknesses" due to the pandemic. The outlook was revised to highlight "heightening downside risk" caused by the pandemic, while imports were cut for the first time in 10 months due to sluggish household demand. The report also revised up corporate profits due to solid earnings among manufacturers.

site_title: Malaysian chip makers still struggling to meet demand, association says
summary: Malaysia's semiconductor industry continues to struggle with meeting global demand, despite efforts to ease restrictions and increase production. The industry association says demand remains high, with orders piling up since last year, and supply is expected to improve by the end of the year as vaccination rates increase and production capacity returns to normal. The country accounts for 13% of global chip assembly testing and packaging, and several major automakers, including Toyota and Ford, have been impacted by disruptions in the sector.

site_title: SPH media restructuring: Privatisation, sale options considered but not viable
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) has decided to transfer its entire media-related business to a company limited by guarantee (CLG) as a sustainable solution, allowing profits to be reinvested instead of being distributed to shareholders. The move comes after a strategic review, which revealed a secular decline in print advertising revenue. SPH's non-media assets will be privatized through a S$2.2 billion bid by Keppel Corporation, valuing SPH at S$3.4 billion. The company will hold a virtual EGM on September 10 to seek shareholders' approval on the restructuring plan.

site_title: Australia: Mining, gold stocks drag shares lower
summary: Australian shares slipped 0.54% on Thursday, dragged down by losses in mining and gold stocks amid growing COVID-19 concerns and expectations of a hawkish stance from the US Federal Reserve at the Jackson Hole Symposium. The ASX 200 index ended at 7,491.2, with miners falling 1.6% and gold stocks shedding 2.3%. New daily COVID-19 cases in Australia reached a record 1,000, and investors are bracing for potential interest rate hikes from major central banks.

site_title: Firmus Capital acquires Le Quest Mall in Bukit Batok
summary: Firmus Capital has acquired Le Quest Mall in Bukit Batok, a single-storey commercial property with a gross floor area of 64,584 square feet. The mall, located near the future Tengah Park MRT Station, has key tenants including FairPrice Finest, McDonald's, and Guardian Pharmacy. The acquisition brings Firmus' total assets under management to S$200 million, as part of its newly launched Firmus Opportunity Fund VCC. The mall is positioned to serve a catchment of 10,000 households and has potential as a last-mile fulfilment hub for retail companies.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end 3-day rally as BOK raises rates; Jackson Hole in focus
summary: South Korean shares ended a three-day rally as the Bank of Korea raised its policy rate for the first time in almost three years due to surging household debt. The Kospi fell 0.58% to 3,128.53, with technology giants Samsung Electronics and Naver declining 1.45% and 1.63%, respectively. The move comes ahead of the Federal Reserve's Jackson Hole symposium, where Chairman Jerome Powell is expected to signal the future direction of US monetary policy. South Korea reported 20 Covid-19 deaths and 1,882 new infections.

site_title: Fed's Powell likely to give few hints on bond-buying taper timeline
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell is likely to provide few hints on the timeline for reducing the US central bank's massive asset purchases, which total $120 billion monthly. Powell's speech at the Jackson Hole economic conference aims to reassure investors that tapering bond purchases doesn't necessarily mean an imminent interest rate hike. Fed officials agree that the bond purchases and rate hikes are independent decisions, with some policymakers debating whether to end the program quickly or stretch it out. The US economy shows signs of slowing due to the surging Delta variant, raising questions about the Fed's support for the economy.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed 1.08% lower, mirroring a sell-off across most of Asia. Disappointing earnings from tech firms weighed on the market, following China's crackdown on the sector. The Hang Seng Index fell to 25,415.69, while the Shanghai Composite and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. The sell-off was part of a broader market trend, with US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Ping An Insurance profit down 15.5% on China Fortune loss
summary: Ping An Insurance Group reported a 15.5% fall in first-half net profit due to a 20.8 billion yuan loss from investments in China Fortune Land Development, a beleaguered property developer. The insurer's total exposure to China Fortune was 54 billion yuan, and it made provisions totaling 35.9 billion yuan. The group's gross written premiums fell 5% and its banking unit Ping An Bank posted 28.5% growth in net profit. Despite the decline, Ping An plans to repurchase 5-10 billion yuan worth of shares.

site_title: Europe: Stocks open lower
summary: Europe's major stock markets opened lower on Thursday, mirroring Asian markets due to growing fears over the end of central bank largesse. London's FTSE 100 dropped 0.6%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 fell 0.8%, and Paris's CAC 40 declined 0.6%. The decline is attributed to South Korea's interest rate hike and concerns over the end of the Federal Reserve's emergency financial support, as well as China's recent regulations on private firms.

site_title: Moody's cuts Indonesian developers' sales growth forecast on latest Covid-19 outbreak
summary: Moody's has cut the sales growth forecast for Indonesian developers due to the latest Covid-19 outbreak. The report expects retail asset demand to remain depressed, while the office and industrial markets will suffer. However, the residential segment is expected to remain stable, driven by housing projects in the one billion rupiah range. Private home sales are forecast to grow by 5% year-on-year, down from 10% previously, due to increased loan availability from banks. A resurgence of coronavirus infections is expected to slow the pace of recovery.

site_title: Asia: Shares retreat from rally, South Korea raises rates
summary: Asian shares retreated from a rally, with MSCI's Asia-Pacific index dropping 0.22% due to rising Covid-19 cases and concerns about inflation. South Korea raised its base rate by 25 basis points to 0.75%, the first major Asian economy to do so. Despite a solid US stock performance, Asia's benchmark is still up around 4% for the week, with analysts predicting a correction by the end of the year.

site_title: IHH Healthcare swings back to profit in H1, rebounds beyond pre-Covid-19 levels
summary: IHH Healthcare, a Malaysian hospital operator, posted a net profit of RM858.9 million (S$276.9 million) for the first half of 2021, reversing a loss of RM440.4 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 34% to RM8.2 billion, driven by strong demand for Covid-19-related services and cost discipline. The company's earnings per share rebounded to 9.29 sen, surpassing pre-Covid-19 levels, and no dividends were declared. IHH's managing director attributed the performance to its focus on patient care, Covid-19 services, and cost management.

site_title: SGX RegCo seeks feedback on climate reporting, ESG, board diversity proposals
summary: SGX RegCo proposes mandatory climate-related disclosures and board diversity policies for listed companies in Singapore. The regulator aims to enhance its sustainability reporting regime amid growing global focus on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors. Companies will need to subject their sustainability reports to assurance, adopt climate reporting on a comply-or-explain basis, and disclose their board diversity policies starting from 2022. Directors will also undergo a one-time training on sustainability. The proposals follow recommendations from the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) and aim to improve climate risk management and investor decision-making.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index dipping 0.08% to 25,673.78. Investors were cautious ahead of Federal Reserve boss Jerome Powell's policy speech, following a record on Wall Street. The Shanghai Composite eased 0.09% to 3,537.31, while the Shenzhen Composite Index remained flat. Global markets were also influenced by US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Asean regulators tipped to keep supporting fintech despite tightening controls
summary: Southeast Asian regulators are expected to continue supporting fintech despite tightening controls, according to Fitch Ratings. The credit agency notes that local regulators are generally supportive of the industry, driven by potential to broaden financial inclusion and drive product innovation. However, aggressive business practices may attract regulatory responses, leading to stiffer sector regulation. Electronic payments have grown due to pandemic-related preferences and digital ecosystems, and corporate users will have greater access to faster and cheaper wholesale payment services. Networks like PromptPay in Thailand, Singapore, and Malaysia are expanding to include fintech operators, lending credibility to the technology.

site_title: Graffiti artist captures lightness of clouds to lift spirits
summary: A French graffiti artist, Saype, has created a 1,500 square meter painting on the summit of Moleson peak in the Swiss Alps, titled "Un nouveau souffle" (A New Lease on Life). The biodegradable painting depicts a child blowing bubbles amidst clouds, aiming to inspire childlike wonder and a contemplative approach to life. The project seeks to reconnect people with nature and their imagination, encouraging a more carefree and optimistic outlook.

site_title: Two 999-year shophouses in Boat Quay, Club Street up for sale
summary: Two 999-year shophouses in Singapore's Boat Quay and Club Street are up for sale via expression of interest. The properties, both zoned for commercial use, have guide prices of S$16 million and S$9.9 million, respectively. Foreigners can purchase without additional buyer's stamp duty, and the shophouses offer prominent frontage and proximity to major transportation hubs. The sales are seen as rare investment opportunities in the area, particularly for F&B shophouses, which are tightly held in Club Street.

site_title: New road maps launched to help process construction and maintenance sector digitalise
summary: Singapore has launched two road maps to help the construction and maintenance sector digitalize, benefiting over 500 businesses and 30,000 employees. The industry digital plan aims to enhance productivity, safety, and competitiveness in the sector. Companies such as CYC International and Shing Leck Engineering Services have seen cost- and time-savings by adopting digital solutions, including robotic systems and employee attendance tracking. The plan was jointly led by Enterprise Singapore and the Infocomm Media Development Authority, and comprises sector-specific digital plans for various industries.

site_title: Japan's Suga faces likely challenge in Sept 29 party poll
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's ruling party will hold a leadership election on September 29, with former foreign minister Fumio Kishida expected to challenge him. Suga's ratings have sunk below 30% amid Japan's worst Covid-19 wave, and he plans to seek re-election as LDP president. Victory would ensure he remains premier due to the LDP's majority in the lower house. Kishida typically ranks low in surveys, but a grass-roots vote could shake up the outcome.

site_title: Tennis: Venus joins sister Serena, Kenin in missing US Open
summary: Venus Williams, two-time US Open champion, has announced she will miss the upcoming US Open due to a leg injury, becoming the third US female to withdraw after her sister Serena and Sofia Kenin. The 41-year-old cited issues with her leg throughout the summer, expressing disappointment at missing her "favourite slam". Kenin also withdrew due to a breakthrough Covid-19 infection, while Serena was forced to withdraw with a torn hamstring. The US Open main draw begins on Monday.

site_title: Toshiba in talks with four investment firms for strategic ideas: sources
summary: Toshiba is in talks with at least four global private equity firms, including KKR & Co and Blackstone, to seek strategic ideas for its new strategy. The move comes after the company's chairman was ousted in June following a scandal over collusion with the Japanese government. Toshiba has launched a full review of its assets and pledged to engage with potential strategic and financial investors. The company plans to present its new business plan in October, but declined to comment further on the potential engagement with buyout firms.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 8.14 points or 0.5% to 1,577.94, with 188 gainers outnumbering 100 losers. Volume reached 105.65 million lots worth RM55.7 million. The market opening higher on Thursday follows a positive trend in regional markets, with Singapore's STI up 0.4% and the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: US plans Covid-19 booster shots at six months instead of eight
summary: US health regulators are expected to approve third Covid-19 booster shots for adults at least six months after full vaccination, instead of the previously announced eight-month gap. Pfizer and BioNTech have submitted an application for the approval of its booster shot, which increases antibodies against the coronavirus by more than three-fold. Approval is expected in mid-September, with boosters for Moderna and Johnson & Johnson shots also pending.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on hopes for Covid peak
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index opened higher, rising 0.22% or 61.15 points to 27,785.95, as US shares hit record highs on hopes the pandemic may have peaked. The Topix index also firmed 0.12% or 2.30 points. This follows renewed optimism globally, despite ongoing tariff uncertainty and mixed Fed views.

site_title: Gold subdued as investor focus turns to Powell's speech
summary: Gold prices fell 0.1% to $1,788.17 per ounce as investors turned cautious ahead of US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's speech, which may provide guidance on tapering economic stimulus. The dollar index rose, weighing on gold, and spot gold prices have declined 0.7% in the past session, its largest drop in two weeks. Analysts expect Powell to signal the Fed's move to dial back bond-buying, but note that lower interest rates may support gold prices in the long term.

site_title: Auditors see new challenges in ESG requirements, greater investor expectations
summary: Auditors face new challenges in meeting environment, social, and governance (ESG) requirements as investors demand greater accountability and transparency. The evolving role of auditors now includes digital trust and ESG factors, reflecting changing business models in response to technology, climate change, and demographic pressures. According to assurance leader Choo Eng Beng, auditors must adapt to a "multitude of challenges and increasing complexity" to build trust with stakeholders. This shift marks a significant evolution in the auditor's role beyond financial matters.

site_title: Moderna withholds 1.63m Covid-19 vaccine doses in Japan due to contamination
summary: Moderna has withheld approximately 1.63 million doses of its Covid-19 vaccine in Japan due to contamination of vials with particulate matter. The contamination is believed to be caused by a manufacturing issue at a contract manufacturing site in Spain. Moderna has put on hold the affected lot and two adjacent ones, but no safety or efficacy issues have been identified. The Japanese health ministry will withdraw some doses as a precaution and work with Moderna and regulators to address the issue, aiming to minimize the impact on inoculation plans.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end flat as utility losses outweigh travel, bank gains
summary: Europe's stock market ended flat on Wednesday, with the Stoxx 600 index closing unchanged at 471.84 points. Travel and bank stocks rose 1.8%, while utilities fell 0.8% due to a negative outlook from brokerage RBC. German stocks fell 0.3% and business morale declined for the second month in August due to rising Covid-19 cases and supply bottlenecks. Despite this, analysts predict strong earnings will keep European stocks near record levels for the rest of 2021.

site_title: US to work with Big Tech, finance sector on new cybersecurity guidelines
summary: The US government has announced plans to work with Big Tech and the finance sector to develop new cybersecurity guidelines, following a series of high-profile attacks on US companies. President Joe Biden met with industry executives, including CEOs from Microsoft, Google, and Amazon, to emphasize the need for improved cybersecurity. The National Institute of Standards and Technology (Nist) will lead the initiative, which aims to create secure technology and assess its security. Industry leaders have committed to participating and investing in cybersecurity efforts, with commitments including free cybersecurity training for the public and $20 billion in investments over five years.

site_title: Afghans told to avoid Kabul airport as Islamic State threat emerges
summary: The US and its allies have urged people to avoid Kabul airport due to an emerging Islamic State (ISIS) threat, amid a chaotic backdrop of thousands trying to flee Afghanistan. Western troops are working to evacuate as many Afghans as possible before an Aug 31 deadline. The US has evacuated over 88,000 people, including 19,000 in the past 24 hours, with the Taliban guarding the perimeter and Taliban fighters trying to flee the country. The Islamic State threat cannot be ignored, and Western forces aim to complete evacuations on time to comply with an agreement with the Taliban.

site_title: Connect@Changi converted into Covid-19 community care facility
summary: Singapore has converted the Connect@Changi facility into a community care facility for Covid-19 patients with mild symptoms. The facility, located at the Singapore Expo, is part of the government's efforts to prepare for Covid-19 becoming endemic. Health Minister Ong Ye Kung aims to admit 97.5% of infected individuals into community care facilities, reducing hospital admissions. The conversion comes as the country sets up more community care facilities, with six existing facilities capable of accommodating over 5,000 individuals.

site_title: Singapore factory output growth eases to 16.3% in July as chip production cools
summary: Singapore's factory output grew 16.3% year-on-year in July, slightly below the median forecast, as the electronics cluster cooled down due to a high production base from the previous month. Biomedical manufacturing output surged 86.6% in July, driven by pharmaceuticals output more than doubling. Precision engineering output rose 20.3%, while transport engineering grew 33.1%. General manufacturing output increased 11%, with miscellaneous industries offsetting declines in other sectors.

site_title: Time for CDL to unlock value of Swiss Club Road GCB site
summary: CDL, a Singaporean developer, may unlock value from its Swiss Club Road site, a prime GCB area. The site, comprising 13 bungalow plots, has been in CDL's landbank since 1996. CDL could sell the plots individually or develop them itself, offering custom-built bungalows with economies of scale. The site is not subject to Qualifying Certificate rules, allowing CDL to develop without regulatory deadlines. With GCB land prices rising 25-40% in prime areas, CDL may consider accelerating capital recycling to lower gearing and free up cash for acquisitions.

site_title: China's push for common prosperity does not mean 'killing the rich': official
summary: China's push for "common prosperity" aims to decrease inequality, but does not mean "killing the rich" to help the poor, according to a ruling Communist Party official. The policy encourages those who "get rich first" to help others, while promoting hard work and discouraging reliance on others. The government will protect legal income and "rationally adjust" excessively high incomes. Charitable giving can improve distribution, but donations are not compulsory. This shift comes amid regulatory crackdowns on big business and investors believe a major reform is underway to cut cost-of-living pressures.

site_title: Qantas aims for international travel from December as loss narrows
summary: Qantas Airways plans to resume international travel from mid-December, with flights to countries with high vaccine rates like Singapore, Japan, and the US. The airline aims to bring back 5 of its 12 A380 super-jumbos by mid-2022 to fly to the US and Britain, a year earlier than forecast. Qantas expects international capacity to reach 30-40% of pre-Covid levels in the third quarter and 50-70% in the fourth quarter, pending government decisions.

site_title: Facebook considers forming an election commission
summary: Facebook is considering forming a commission to advise it on global election issues, including political ads and election-related misinformation. The proposed commission, if formed, would be separate from the Oversight Board, which was established in 2018. The announcement could come this fall ahead of the 2022 US midterm elections. The move comes as social media companies struggle to balance free speech with the spread of misinformation.

site_title: Indebted China Evergrande expects H1 profit to plunge as much as 39%; shares slip
summary: China Evergrande Group, the country's most indebted property developer, expects its 6-month net profit to drop as much as 39% due to a drop in selling prices and higher expenses. The company reported losses of 4 billion yuan in its property and electric car businesses. Evergrande shares fell 5% and its electric car stocks dropped 12% after markets opened on Thursday. The company is scrambling to raise funds to pay its lenders and suppliers, raising concerns about potential ripple effects on China's banking system.

site_title: South Korea lifts interest rates from record low as debt concerns grow
summary: The Bank of Korea (BOK) raised its policy rate by 25 basis points to 0.75% for the first time in almost three years, aiming to curb surging household debt. This decision follows concerns about financial imbalances and comes ahead of expectations for a rate hike in emerging economies. Analysts predict further rate hikes, with most expecting the base rate to reach 1.25% by end-2022, as South Korea's economy transitions away from crisis-era stimulus.

site_title: BT Explains: Reverse mortgage with a CPF twist
summary: DBS has introduced a reverse mortgage product that allows seniors to tap into the equity of their fully paid private homes and channel the borrowed amount into CPF Life, Singapore's insurance annuity scheme. The loan is capped at 30 years, with a fixed interest rate of 2.88%, and borrowers can sell their property without penalty. The product aims to provide flexibility to seniors who want to "buy some time to think through what they need" in their retirement years. DBS has implemented safeguards to minimize the risk of debt left to inheritors, and the loan amount is capped at each individual's CPF Enhanced Retirement Sum.

site_title: G-7 finalises West's withdrawal from Afghanistan
summary: The G-7 has agreed on a "road map" for future engagement with the Taliban, with a focus on ensuring safe passage for those who want to leave Afghanistan beyond August 31. The US, despite European pressure, has set a deadline for the airlift to end on Tuesday. The G-7 will use its limited leverage to try to ensure safe passage and may recognize the new regime as legitimate, unlocking billions of dollars in frozen funds. The decision comes amid a strong emphasis on geopolitics, with the G-7 discussing alternative infrastructure plans to rival China's Belt and Road Initiative.

site_title: China criticises US 'scapegoating' over Covid origin report
summary: China has criticized the US for "scapegoating" its role in the origin of the coronavirus, demanding an investigation into US labs after the release of a US intelligence report. The report considers various theories, including a lab accident in Wuhan, China, and a lab leak at the US Army's Fort Detrick base. China has denied a lab leak occurred in Wuhan and instead suggests the virus escaped from a US lab. The US has expressed concerns about Chinese access to an investigation, and a Congressional panel is set to receive a copy of the classified report.

site_title: GIC-backed Klarna bets on further growth as US gives boost to transactions value
summary: Swedish payments firm Klarna reported a jump in transactions using its platform in the second quarter, with 20 million users in the US, up three million from the previous period. The company expects to make its stock market debut in early 2022, with a valuation of around $46 billion after raising $639 million in June. Klarna plans to continue entering new markets and diversifying revenue streams, driven by a surge in demand for "buy now, pay later" services during the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Swedish payments firm Klarna said on Wednesday it would continue to enter new markets, as it reported a jump in transactions using its platform in the second quarter.

site_title: US probes Deutsche Bank's asset management arm over sustainability claims: sources
summary: US authorities are investigating Deutsche Bank's asset management arm DWS Group over allegations that it overstated the use of sustainable investing criteria to manage its assets. The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) and federal prosecutors in Brooklyn, New York, are probing the matter, which is in its early stages. The SEC has established a task force to address misconduct related to environmental, social, and governance issues, amid a surge in US$51 billion invested in sustainable funds in 2020. The investigation is the latest scrutiny on Deutsche Bank's practices following the SEC's efforts to improve investor transparency.

site_title: For the love of sports
summary: Singapore Pools supports sports, particularly for the Paralympics. Nur Aini, a Powerlifting Women's - 45kg competitor, faces challenges due to the gym's closure during the Circuit Breaker. The Singapore Disability Sports Council helps her train at the Singapore Sport Institute.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq notch all-time closing highs ahead of Fed meeting
summary: US stocks reached record highs on Wednesday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq closing at all-time highs ahead of the Federal Reserve's Jackson Hole Symposium. Investors expect the Fed to maintain its policy tightening timeline, supporting risk-on sentiment. Financials and chipmakers led gains, while healthcare stocks declined. The S&P 500 ended the session up 0.22% at 4,496.19, and the Nasdaq rose 0.15% to 15,041.86.

site_title: Thailand more resilient to taper tantrum: central bank
summary: Thailand is less vulnerable to a "taper tantrum" due to its low reliance on external debt financing and high foreign reserves, according to Bank of Thailand Governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput. This makes its bond yields less exposed to a global spike in interest rates. Thailand's bond market relies less on non-resident financing, and 90% of corporate financing is bank-based, which reduces the transmission of global yield spikes to the local economy. Despite this, the baht may still be affected by domestic factors.

site_title: Thailand develops robotic system to squeeze out more vaccine doses
summary: Researchers in Thailand have developed a robotic system, AutoVacc, to increase vaccine efficiency and optimize lower-than-expected vaccine supplies. The machine can draw 12 doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine in four minutes, a 20% increase from manual drawing. The prototype costs 2.5 million baht and can be used with other vaccines. The system aims to reduce burdens on health workers and increase vaccination efficiency, particularly in Thailand's worst coronavirus outbreak yet, where around 9% of the population has been fully vaccinated.

site_title: US new home sales creep up; tight supply, rising prices remain constraints
summary: US new home sales rose 1% in July to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 708,000 units, driven by a record rise in unsold homes yet to be built. Despite this, housing prices remain a constraint, with median new house prices soaring 18.4% to a record $390,500. Tight supply and backlogs in construction, coupled with high prices, are expected to temper sales in the months ahead.

site_title: China's regulatory crackdowns are already hurting the economy
summary: China's regulatory crackdowns on industries such as steel, education, and property are hurting the economy, with economists warning of a weakening economy due to fresh virus outbreaks. The regulatory restrictions are curbing growth, and Beijing is expected to continue regulating businesses, requiring careful management to avoid exacerbating the economic downturn. The country's GDP growth is set to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at open after Wall Street ends at record highs; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.3% at open on Thursday, following Wall Street's record highs. The Straits Times Index (STI) advanced 7.93 points to 3,115.42, with gains outnumbering losses 85 to 61. Banking stocks led the morning higher, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC rising 1.1%, 0.1%, and 0.3% respectively. Investors are awaiting the upcoming Jackson Hole Symposium for reassurance on the Federal Reserve's monetary policy timeline.

images.alt_text: One of the most active counters by volume was marine and offshore engineering group Sembcorp Marine.

site_title: Xi says China aims to meet economic targets with virus curbs
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping stated that the country aims to meet economic targets this year while maintaining strict COVID-19 controls. Xi emphasized the need for high-quality development and coordinated policies between economic growth and safety. The comments were made during a visit to Chengde in northern China, where he inspected various projects. Xi's remarks come amid concerns about China's slowing GDP growth, which may put pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: President Xi Jinping said China will strive to achieve key economic and social development targets this year, while maintaining strict virus controls.

site_title: Biden could recover politically after Afghanistan 'fiasco'
summary: US President Joe Biden's presidency may recover from the recent Afghan withdrawal controversy, as the economy and the Delta variant of COVID-19 pose greater concerns for Americans. Unlike the US military's involvement in Vietnam, which was widely followed due to the draft, the current withdrawal from Afghanistan has received less attention from the public. Biden's pledge to end the endless wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, like predecessors Barack Obama and Donald Trump, has helped him maintain support among voters. The Republican party's criticism of Biden over Afghanistan may backfire if the withdrawal is largely complete and the focus shifts to domestic issues such as inflation and crime.

site_title: Oil extends rally, rises over 1% on US fuel demand recovery
summary: Oil prices rose over 1% on Wednesday, extending gains for a third session, after US fuel demand climbed to its highest since the start of the Covid-19 pandemic. Brent crude rose to $72.25 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude gained to $68.36 a barrel. Fuel demand rebounded, with US total product supplied averaging nearly 21 million barrels per day, the highest since March 2020. Refiners increased production to 92.4% of capacity, driving US crude inventories to their lowest since January 2020.

site_title: Japan expands virus emergency on Covid-19 surge
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga has expanded the country's state of emergency to eight areas, covering about 70% of the population, due to a surge in Delta-variant cases. The areas include Hokkaido and Aichi, and will be under the emergency from Friday until September 12. This move aims to put pressure on the medical system amid record-breaking cases. The decision affects nearly 80 million people, with Tokyo and other major cities already under the emergency.

site_title: Moderna seeks full US approval for its Covid-19 vaccine
summary: Moderna has completed the application process for full US approval of its Covid-19 vaccine, putting the company on track to obtain the second clearance from federal regulators. The company submitted its Biologics License Application (BLA) in June and has been providing data on the vaccine's safety and effectiveness to the FDA. Moderna's application is part of the company's efforts to secure full approval of its vaccine, which would allow it to be prescribed and administered without restrictions.

site_title: Greenback holds above one-week low on Delta fears
summary: The US dollar rose above a one-week low on Wednesday amid concerns over the Delta coronavirus variant's economic impact, despite improved risk appetite and expectations of a potential tapering of US stimulus. The dollar index edged up 0.1% to 93.019, while the greenback gained 0.2% to 109.89 yen. Analysts expect Fed Chair Jerome Powell to strike a balance between highlighting the US economic recovery and the challenges ahead, potentially leading to a buying opportunity for the dollar ahead of key US data releases.

site_title: US core capital goods orders flat in July; shipments up
summary: US core capital goods orders remained steady in July, unchanged from June, despite economists' forecasts of a 0.5% increase. Shipments of core capital goods rose 1.0% after a 0.6% increase in June, indicating business investment in equipment could offset a potential slowdown in consumer spending. This steady reading is seen as a positive sign for the economy's growth in the third quarter, despite concerns over consumer spending and supply chain bottlenecks.

site_title: Razer to focus on B2B fintech with ceasing of Razer Pay e-wallet, card
summary: Razer, a gaming hardware company, will cease its Razer Pay e-wallet and Razer Card project, citing high operating costs and a more viable B2B payments processing business. The company posted a record US$752m in revenue for the half-year, driven by a strong hardware business, and expects to double down on its B2B fintech strategy, including expanding into South-east Asia. The move has minimal financial impact and will not affect staff, with redeployed employees across the group.

site_title: SEC chief warns 'clock is ticking' on delisting Chinese stocks
summary: SEC Chair Gary Gensler warns Chinese companies that they must permit US inspections of their financial audits by 2024 or risk delisting from the NYSE and Nasdaq. The SEC has a three-year deadline to enforce the mandate, and companies that refuse will face consequences. Gensler plans to increase transparency and disclosure from Chinese firms, including information on regulatory and political risks. The SEC has already suspended new IPOs of Chinese companies until they provide adequate disclosures, which could last several weeks or months.
