A fully vaccinated 90-year-old man died from Covid-19 complications, marking the first death of a fully vaccinated person in Singapore.

site_title: BT's Top Stories from Last Week
summary: A growing sentiment of "us vs them" in Singapore is fueled by resentment towards foreigners perceived as taking jobs, despite being unfounded. Overseas Singaporeans miss the familiar taste of home, including food and culture, 18 months into the pandemic. International Plaza is set to launch an en bloc tender, with a potential multi-billion dollar sale. Top property agents have bagged nearly half of HDB resale transactions, while Singtel posted a net profit of S$445m in Q1, reversing last year's loss. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower as BHP weighs; financials jump
summary: Australian shares closed 0.1% lower, marking a third straight negative session, as BHP Group dropped 7% after announcing an exit from its petroleum business and a UK dual listing end. Financials rose 0.7%, with the "Big Four" banks climbing, while New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.7%. The news came amid rising Covid-19 cases in New South Wales, potentially pressuring the central bank to delay rate hikes.

site_title: CosmoSteel profitable in Q3, but flags continued revenue impairment
summary: CosmoSteel Holdings reported profitability in the third quarter of its financial year ending Sept 30, despite continued revenue impairment due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The company reduced finance costs and focused on selling second-hand inventory at a profit. CosmoSteel remains on the Singapore Exchange's watch-list due to its inability to meet the exit criteria, but has guided for further revenue impairment. The company continues to explore projects to increase revenue and expand its existing products or services.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: A Singapore unicorn, Pine Labs, has allegedly been hit by a ransomware attack, with a threat actor claiming to have obtained service and private agreements between Pine Labs and Indian banks. The region's venture capital industry has seen a significant growth, with assets under management (AUM) more than doubling to US$37 billion in five years. Meanwhile, two shophouses in Bugis are up for sale by tender, and Singapore companies have rolled out new technologies, including robots, sensors, and electric vehicles, to spice up their businesses. The Straits Times Index ended the day at 3,131.44, up 0.4%.

site_title: China plans US$7b Huarong recapitalisation led by Citic
summary: China's Huarong Asset Management is set to receive a US$7.7 billion recapitalization led by Citic Group, shifting control of the embattled company. The plan, approved by China's State Council, involves Citic assuming the Chinese government's controlling stake in Huarong from the Ministry of Finance. This move aims to resolve a crisis in China's credit market, which has seen a record wave of defaults since April. The capital injection from a Citic-led consortium is expected to be announced soon, marking the first major attempt to support a troubled state-owned borrower.

images.alt_text: China Huarong Asset Management is poised to receive about US$7.7 billion of fresh capital as part of an overhaul plan that would shift control of the embattled company to state-owned conglomerate Citic Group, people familiar with the matter said.

site_title: Insurer M&G to buy financial advice provider Sandringham
summary: British insurer M&G announced it will buy financial advice provider Sandringham Financial Partners, adding assets worth over £2.5 billion to its UK wealth management business. The deal will integrate Sandringham's advice, platform, and investment businesses into M&G Wealth. This move aims to bolster M&G's presence in the UK wealth management market, expanding its offerings and customer base. The acquisition is expected to enhance M&G's financial stability and growth prospects.

site_title: Tencent sales slow as China crackdown weighs
summary: Chinese tech giant Tencent's revenue grew 23% year-over-year to $42.3 billion for the first half of 2021, but at its slowest pace in two years. Operating profits rose 17%. The growth rate slowed due to concerns over an expected regulatory crackdown on the gaming industry. Gaming firms, including Tencent, face new headwinds as China's communist rulers crack down on Big Tech and other powerful sectors deemed out of control. The online gaming industry is seen as the next target, with regulators labeling games "spiritual opium" and imposing curbs on play time.

site_title: Qantas to require all employees to be vaccinated against Covid-19
summary: Qantas Airways will require all employees to be vaccinated against Covid-19 by November 15 for pilots, cabin crew, and airport workers, and by March 31, 2022, for other staff. Exemptions will be granted for those with documented medical reasons. The airline's move follows similar requirements from other airlines, including United Airlines and Cathay Pacific Airways. Qantas has also previously stated it will require international passengers to be vaccinated once Australia's borders reopen.

site_title: Indonesia's July trade surplus widens as export, import growth slows
summary: Indonesia's trade surplus widened to $2.59 billion in July, driven by slower-than-expected growth in exports and imports. Exports rose 29.32% year-over-year to $17.70 billion, while imports expanded 44.44% to $15.11 billion. The July trade surplus was higher than the forecast $2.27 billion and June's surplus of $1.32 billion, despite a slowdown in growth rates compared to June. The data comes as Indonesia imposed mobility restrictions to control a spike in Covid-19 cases.

site_title: Europe: Markets rise at open
summary: European stock markets rose in opening deals on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index advancing 0.2% to 7,193.07 points, driven by a slowdown in UK inflation and gains in Asian markets. The eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 also rose, despite concerns over the global economic recovery due to the Delta coronavirus variant.

site_title: Singapore unicorn Pine Labs allegedly hit by ransomware; bank clients may be impacted
summary: Pine Labs, a Singapore-based payments platform backed by Temasek, has been allegedly hit by ransomware, with hackers claiming to have stolen service and private agreements between the company and multiple Indian banks. The hackers, BlackMatter, have demanded a ransom in exchange for not publishing the stolen data. Pine Labs' chief technology officer said the company's production systems remain operational, but is investigating the source of the stolen data. The attack may impact clients such as HDFC Bank and ICICI Bank, but it is unclear if it will affect the company's plans for an initial public offering.

site_title: COE prices rebound after pandemic restrictions are lifted
summary: COE prices rebounded after Singapore lifted pandemic restrictions, with cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp reaching S$45,689, and those above 1,600cc or 130bhp reaching S$61,001. The motorcycle premium surged to an all-time high of S$9,500. Commercial vehicle COE fell to S$40,010. The surge in COE prices for bigger cars indicates weakness in the mainstream market, with buyers less price-sensitive and sellers having fatter margins.

images.alt_text: Certificates of entitlement (COE) prices ended mostly higher at the latest tender on Wednesday (Aug 18) as the economy reopened after the latest pandemic restrictions, with the highly-speculated motorcycle premium reaching an all-time high of S$9,500.

site_title: Sydney warned worse to come as Delta cases surge
summary: Sydney's Delta outbreak continues to surge, with 633 new cases reported, including 545 in the city, surpassing the state's previous high. Sixty people have died since the outbreak began, and authorities warn of more deaths if cases continue to rise. Only 28% of NSW residents aged 16 and above are fully vaccinated, putting pressure on the government's vaccine rollout. The city remains under lockdown, and efforts to contain the outbreak have failed, with the virus spreading to regional towns.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise on opening
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.41% on Wednesday, recouping losses after a surge in Delta variant cases sparked economic recovery fears. The Hang Seng Index rose to 25,852.69, while the Shanghai Composite and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased. The gains come as investors brush off new US President Trump's threats to extend stocks rally.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rebound from 3-month low on institutional investor buying
summary: South Korean stocks rebounded from a three-month low on Wednesday, closing up 0.50% at 3,158.93 after an eight-session losing streak. Institutional investors snapped up shares, with technology giant Samsung Electronics falling 0.40% and peer SK Hynix rising 2.46%. Foreigners were net sellers of $223.04 million worth of shares.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei snaps losing streak to end higher
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index ended higher, snapping a four-day losing streak, with a 0.59% gain to 27,585.91. The broader Topix index rose 0.44%. Despite a surge in virus cases, the Japanese government's expansion of a coronavirus state of emergency was seen as a factor in the market's rebound. Exports surged 37% in July, marking five straight months of increase, while core machinery orders fell 1.5% in June.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened flat on Wednesday, down 1.11 points or 0.07% to 1,522.48. Losers outnumbered gainers 203 to 136, with a trading volume of 420.99 million lots worth RM140.18 million.

site_title: Raffles Education Corp launches corporate building for sale at S$200m
summary: Raffles Education Corp is selling its corporate building, Raffles Education Square, for S$200 million. The 27,669 sq ft building has a gross floor area of 77,445 sq ft and is zoned "Commercial" in the 2019 Master Plan. The leasehold title has 71 years remaining. The sale is part of the company's asset rationalization plan. Marketing agent Delasa launched an expression-of-interest exercise, which closes on Sept 23. The property's unique surroundings and accessibility make it an attractive option for a corporate buyer looking for a vibrant and productive work environment.

site_title: China to target ultra-rich as its seeks wealth redistribution in push for 'common prosperity'
summary: China's President Xi Jinping has outlined a plan to address income inequality, aiming for "common prosperity" through income regulation and redistribution. The government will target the ultra-rich, regulate high incomes, and encourage the wealthy to give back to society. Measures include expanding the middle-income group, growing low-income earnings, and prohibiting illicit income. The plan also includes implementing taxes on property and inheritance, as well as improving social security programs. The goal is to create an environment where more people can become wealthy, with a focus on promoting social fairness and justice.

site_title: Nanofilm says it will improve communication with the market to align views
summary: Nanofilm Technologies' shares plummeted nearly a third after releasing its half-year results, but the company plans to improve communication with the market to align views. Founder Shi Xu attributed the sell-off to gaps in communication, stating that the company needs to better sense market sentiment and share its views on performance and strategy. Despite a 3.1% dip in net profit, revenue increased 24.2% to S$96.6 million. The company is actively engaging with investors and has a strong management team in place.

site_title: Shareholders must decide on Sembcorp Marine's rights issue this week: Sias
summary: Sembcorp Marine is set to raise S$1.5 billion through a rights issue, which shareholders must decide on by August 20. The company is seeking to shift into the green sector and address temporary working capital depletion, but critics argue it is raising funds just over a year after its last S$2.1 billion fundraising. Sembmarine's CEO says the company aims to become a global leader in clean energy, but some shareholders question the value of investing in the company again, with no guarantee of a third rights issue in three years.

site_title: Instant delivery startup RaRa Delivery bags US$3.25m in funding
summary: RaRa Delivery, a Singapore-founded instant delivery startup, has secured US$3.25 million in funding led by Surge and East Ventures. Founded in 2019, the company uses batching technology for "many-to-many" deliveries within hours, allowing drivers to earn more in fewer hours. Key customers include grocery players Sayurbox and healthtech company Alodoktor. The startup aims to integrate its services into major online marketplaces in South-east Asia to offer instant deliveries, starting in Indonesia, and create an ecosystem for premium customer experiences.

site_title: Two shophouses in Bugis for sale by tender
summary: Two shophouses in Singapore's Bugis area are up for sale by tender, with guide prices of S$12.3 million and S$29 million. The properties, located at 17 Jalan Klapa and 14 Purvis Street, respectively, offer 999-year tenure conservation and freehold corner shophouse options. Both properties are zoned for commercial and hotel use, and buyers from both local and foreign markets are eligible to purchase. The tender exercises close on September 30.

site_title: Singapore watchdog probes game giant Ubisoft over harassment claims
summary: Ubisoft's Singapore office is under investigation by a watchdog over claims of sexual harassment and racial discrimination. The allegations, made by 20 current and former employees, also included harassment, bullying, and racial pay disparities. The incidents follow previous allegations of sexual misconduct that led to senior staff resigning last year. The investigation is the latest controversy for the French game giant, which publishes popular titles like Assassin's Creed and Far Cry.

images.alt_text: Video game giant Ubisoft's Singapore office is under investigation over claims of sexual harassment and racial discrimination, a watchdog said, in the latest controversy for the French firm.

site_title: Australian crypto firm Iris Energy files for direct listing on Nasdaq
summary: Australian crypto firm Iris Energy has filed for a direct listing on the Nasdaq, a move amid growing popularity of digital currencies as investment assets. The company, which mines bitcoin using green hydroelectric power, has raised up to $130 million to expand its operations in Canada. Iris Energy expects its 9 megawatt data centre to reach 30 megawatts by the end of the year, and plans to raise more funds to add additional computing capacity in 2022. The direct listing is expected to be effective in the last quarter of 2021.

site_title: Robots, sensors and EVs: Singapore companies roll out new tech to spice up business
summary: Singapore companies SMRT, SPTel, and SingPost are introducing new technologies to improve business operations. SMRT will deploy robot baristas at MRT stations, while SPTel will implement Internet of Things-as-a-service to enhance urban farm operations. SingPost is piloting electric delivery vehicles to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. These initiatives aim to increase efficiency, reduce costs, and promote sustainability, with the goal of setting the companies apart from the competition.

images.alt_text: Robot baristas will be introduced at some 30 SMRT MRT Stations, where they can serve up to 200 cups of coffee per hour to commuters.

site_title: Australia wages rise annual 1.7% in Q2, miss forecasts
summary: Australia's wage growth rose 1.7% annually in Q2, missing forecasts of 1.9%, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The 0.4% quarterly increase was lower than expected, following a record low of 1.4% in the previous quarter. The slower-than-expected growth is attributed to a clampdown on public sector pay, despite recent coronavirus lockdowns expected to delay recovery. This marks a trend of lower wage growth, which had trended lower for much of the past decade.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise as upbeat earnings counter BHP slide
summary: Australian shares rose 0.1% to 7,522.7 points, offsetting a 0.9% drop on Tuesday, as upbeat earnings reports from Domino's Pizza Enterprises and EML Payments boosted the market. Financials, led by the "big four" banks, gained 1% despite a near 7% slide in BHP after it sold its petroleum assets. New Zealand's benchmark rose 0.6%, while healthcare products distributor EBOS Group jumped 3.5% on a jump in annual profit.

site_title: Japan's July exports jump 37% y-o-y: MOF
summary: Japan's exports surged 37.0% in July from a year earlier, surpassing economists' expectations. The trade balance reached a surplus of 441.0 billion yen, exceeding the median estimate. Meanwhile, July imports rose 28.5% year-on-year, also beating forecasts. This growth follows June's 48.6% increase.

site_title: Nissan has a new 'Z' that's a blast from the past
summary: Nissan unveiled its new "Z" sports car, featuring a petrol-fueled engine and manual transmission, in response to fan demand for a high-performance model. The vehicle will be available in the US in spring 2022, as Nissan aims to accelerate a financial turnaround. The new Z marks a throwback to the brand's past success, having helped revive consumer interest in 1999. Nissan plans to offer electric options in all models by 2030 and is prioritizing semiconductor supplies for its 12 new models.

images.alt_text: Nissan Motor unveiled the latest generation of its "Z" sports car, which will come with a petrol-fueled engine and a manual transmission, a throwback in a world that's moving toward electric sports cars.

site_title: South-east Asia needs vaccine access to curb record deaths: Red Cross
summary: South-east Asian countries are struggling to contain record Covid-19 infections and deaths driven by the Delta variant, with most countries lagging behind in vaccination rates. The region needs greater access to vaccines, with Indonesia and the Philippines having only vaccinated around 10-11% and 2% of their populations, respectively. The International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies calls for richer countries to share excess vaccine doses, and for vaccine companies and governments to boost production and share technology. A 70-80% vaccination rate is seen as a critical target.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Wednesday's open; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% or 11.38 points to 3,129.89 at 9:05am on Wednesday, driven by gains from Addvalue Technologies and Singtel. Banking stocks were mixed, with UOB and OCBC up 0.7%, while DBS fell 0.1%. The STI has notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with investors remaining positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

images.alt_text: Gainers outnumbered losers 87 to 55, after 44.7 million securities worth S$68.8 million changed hands.

site_title: 70,000 CPF members to get S$40m in matched top-ups to their retirement accounts
summary: Seventy thousand CPF members in Singapore will receive approximately S$40 million in matched top-ups to their retirement accounts, increasing their monthly payouts. The Matched Retirement Savings Scheme, launched earlier this year, matches every dollar of cash top-ups made by eligible members up to an annual cap of S$600. Eligible members, mostly between 55-70 years old, must have less than the prevailing basic retirement sum of S$93,000 in their account. The grants will be credited in January next year, with 440,000 people eligible for the scheme.

site_title: Krispy Kreme forecasts higher revenue on online, drive-through bet
summary: Krispy Kreme forecasts higher annual revenue, beating second-quarter estimates, with net revenue rising 42.6% to $349.2 million. The company attributes the growth to its online business, drive-through, and new menu items, betting on a shift towards eating at home. Krispy Kreme also plans to raise prices in September to offset higher labor and commodity costs. The forecast is part of a trend of major US restaurants increasing their online presence to cut wait times for delivery and drive-through.

site_title: Australian casino operator Star seeks more gaming machines in Sydney
summary: Australian casino operator Star Entertainment Group plans to negotiate with the New South Wales government to increase the number of gaming machines permitted at its Sydney casino. The move comes as rival Crown Resorts faces uncertainty due to allegations of money laundering and governance failures. Star argues its Sydney casino is underutilized, currently permitted to operate 1,500 gaming machines, compared to Crown's Perth and Melbourne casinos. Negotiations are expected to commence shortly, following Star's withdrawal of a A$9 billion buyout proposal for Crown last month.

site_title: Philippines' Create Act makes investment more attractive
summary: The Philippines' Create Act, the country's largest fiscal stimulus package, has made investment more attractive for foreign companies. The law provides over $26.9 billion in tax relief and flexible incentives for private enterprises over 10 years, including reduced corporate tax rates and streamlined processes. The move is expected to support growth in sectors such as healthcare, information and communications, and agriculture, with the country reporting a 11.8% year-on-year GDP growth in the second quarter. The Asian Development Bank projects moderate growth of 4.5% in 2021 and stronger growth in 2022.

site_title: New Zealand holds rates at record low as fresh Covid-19 outbreak stokes uncertainty
summary: New Zealand's central bank left interest rates at a record low of 0.25% amid a snap lockdown following the detection of new Covid-19 cases. Economists had expected a rate hike, but policymakers prioritized caution due to the country's low vaccination rate and risk of Delta variant spread. The decision came despite projections indicating the cash rate would reach 0.50% by the end of the year and over 2% by 2023. The New Zealand dollar dropped 0.3% after the announcement.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SPH, GK Goh, Nutryfarm
summary: Singapore stocks to watch include SPH, which recommended shareholders vote in favor of hiving off its media business, and shares ended flat at S$1.89. GK Goh Goh announced a conditional share sale and purchase deed, causing its shares to close at S$1.08. Nutryfarm dismissed a rumor about Covid-19 on durian packaging, with shares closing at S$0.37. The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday, despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: US: Weak retail sales data ends streak of Dow records
summary: US retail sales fell 1.1% in July, exceeding expectations and contributing to a sell-off on Wall Street. This marked the end of the Dow's five-day streak of records, following a week of successive highs. The decline was largely due to a sharp drop in auto sales. The news exacerbated concerns about the latest Covid-19 wave and added to worries about the US economy.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts cool on APAC Realty, but still recommend PropNex
summary: Analysts have downgraded APAC Realty's call to "neutral" due to potential cooling measures in the property market, but still recommend PropNex, citing its stronger financial metrics and larger market capitalization. PropNex's target price is set at S$2.19, with analysts expecting 13.5% long-term growth potential. APAC Realty's earnings are expected to peak this year before declining next year due to reduced inventory levels, while PropNex's net profit is forecast to more than double to S$60.1 million in FY2021.

site_title: Facebook moves to block Taliban's WhatsApp accounts
summary: Facebook has blocked WhatsApp accounts linked to the Taliban following the group's takeover of Afghanistan. The move is under Facebook's Dangerous Organisation policies, as the Taliban is sanctioned as a terrorist organisation under US law. The blockage shut down a hotline set up by the Taliban to receive complaints about violence and looting.

site_title: Europe: Stocks edge higher after data, virus worries linger
summary: European stocks rose 0.1% after a week's low, driven by upbeat euro zone data showing a 2% economic growth in the second quarter. Despite concerns over a slowdown, data suggests the economy is recovering from pandemic lows. However, travel and leisure sectors fell, and some companies, such as Dutch tech firm Prosus and online trading platform Plus500, declined. Investors remain cautious due to ongoing Covid-19 cases and travel restrictions.

site_title: Singapore may test business travel from some nations in September
summary: Singapore plans to test business travel from select nations in September through pilot programmes with countries such as Germany, Australia, Canada, and South Korea. The move aims to reopen its borders, with the possibility of also allowing leisure travel. Trade and Industry Minister Gan Kim Yong discussed the plans in an interview with Bloomberg News.

site_title: AUM for Asean-focused PE, venture capital industry at US$37b, more than doubling in five years
summary: The Asean-focused private equity and venture capital industry has seen a significant surge in assets under management (AUM), more than doubling to $37 billion in five years, according to a Preqin report. Venture capital and growth funds hold 81% of total AUM, driven by the region's attractive startup environment and growing technology adoption. The industry is expected to continue growing, with fundraising activity and exit momentum picking up, despite the COVID-19 pandemic. Several Asean companies, including Tokopedia and Grab, are planning to go public, with GoTo aiming for a post-money value of $40 billion.

site_title: Biden, Johnson agree to hold virtual G-7 summit on Afghanistan: White House
summary: US President Joe Biden and British Prime Minister Boris Johnson agreed to hold a virtual G-7 summit to discuss a common strategy and approach on the crisis in Afghanistan. The summit, to be held next week, aims to provide further humanitarian assistance and support for refugees and vulnerable Afghans. The leaders also emphasized the need for continued close coordination among allies and democratic partners on Afghanistan policy, with a focus on preventing a humanitarian crisis. The move comes after the Taliban's takeover of Kabul, prompting a chaotic evacuation effort.

site_title: Biden approval drops to lowest of seven-month presidency after Taliban takeover
summary: President Joe Biden's approval rating has dropped to 46%, the lowest level in his seven-month presidency, according to a Reuters/Ipsos poll. The drop comes amid the collapse of the US-backed Afghan government and the Taliban's takeover of the country. A majority of Americans, including both Republicans and Democrats, say the US should leave the conflict, and 44% of respondents praise Biden's handling of Afghanistan. The poll also found that 51% of Americans think former President George W. Bush did a better job in Afghanistan.

site_title: 6G is not a far-off dream: it could arrive as early as 2030
summary: Researchers predict 6G technology could be available as early as 2030, offering significant improvements over 5G, including speeds five times faster, latency 10 times less, and reliability 100 times more. A 6G-powered world would enable seamless integration between the physical and digital worlds, with applications in virtual reality, artificial intelligence, and the Internet of Things. However, challenges remain, including addressing cost, coverage, and power consumption, as well as ensuring data privacy. The transition to 6G will require breakthroughs in various technologies and techniques, and planning for its potential impact on society is essential.

site_title: China's youth react to gaming curbs with anguish and cunning
summary: China's tech firms have implemented gaming curbs, limiting players under 12 from making in-game purchases and restricting under-18s from playing for extended periods. The measures, aimed at curbing addiction, have sparked anguish among young gamers, with one 14-year-old expressing his frustration. The gaming giant Tencent has issued an edict, citing concerns over the industry's impact on the country's youth. The move is part of a broader effort to address accusations that Chinese tech firms are selling "spiritual opium" to the nation's youth, with estimated annual gaming revenues reaching US$20 billion.

images.alt_text: An edict by gaming giant Tencent means players under 12 can no longer make in-game purchases in multiplayer battle smash-hit Honor of Kings, while under-18s are locked out after two hours during holidays and one hour on school nights.

site_title: EU solar power generation hits record high
summary: The European Union saw a record high in solar power generation in June and July 2021, accounting for 10% of total electricity produced. The 27 countries generated nearly 39 terawatt hours of power from solar panels, with new records set in eight countries, including Spain and Germany. However, solar generation still lags behind coal, and the EU aims to increase renewable energy to 40% of final consumption by 2030. Germany maintained the largest share of solar power production, while Spain saw the largest growth over four years.

site_title: Over 10,000 apply for 450 Hougang 4-room BTO flats
summary: Over 10,000 applicants vied for 450 Hougang 4-room BTO flats, with one in 17 first-time applicants and one in 6 second-time applicants securing a unit. This contrasts with mature estates, where competition is less stiff. The strong demand in Hougang is attributed to lower supply and attractive locations, bucking the current trend of preference for mature estates.

site_title: New Zealand PM warns virus outbreak will grow
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has warned of a growing Covid-19 outbreak, linked to the highly transmissible Delta variant, with six positive tests confirmed. A nationwide stay-at-home order was issued after the first case was identified, with the total number of cases rising to seven. Ardern attributed the rapid spread to the Delta variant, which authorities have struggled to contain in Australia. The lockdown is a response to the increasing number of cases, with Ardern urging New Zealanders to brace for additional cases.

images.alt_text: New Zealanders must brace for additional Covid-19 cases from an outbreak that has plunged the previously virus-free country into a snap lockdown, Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern warned on Wednesday after six more positive tests.

site_title: American home improvement boom's next phase favours retailer Home Depot
summary: Home Depot is poised to benefit from the next phase of the American home improvement boom, which is expected to favor professional contractors over DIYers. Despite a surge in DIY projects during the pandemic, revenue from professional contractors is now on the mend, with Home Depot's pro business expected to outpace DIY sales. The company's investments in its pro business, including a $8 billion acquisition last year, are expected to pay off as housing prices continue to rise and homeowners see their homes as investments.

site_title: Japan sees peril in US chip hub to counter China
summary: Japan is concerned that the US's plan to invest billions in chip manufacturing could further weaken its own semiconductor industry, which has declined significantly over the past two decades. The US's efforts may also lure Asian chip foundry giants, such as Taiwan's TSMC, to the US, leaving Japan without a key supplier. To counter this, Japan's government is considering investing heavily in chip manufacturing and data centers, but the country's financial situation and limited spending compared to other nations like the US and EU may hinder its ability to keep up.

site_title: Looking ahead from Q2 earnings season
summary: The US Q2 earnings season is nearing its end, with over 80% of companies having reported their earnings. Most companies beat consensus forecasts, with traditionally cyclical sectors like financials, industrials, and materials showing triple-digit percentage growth. The consumer discretionary sector, including e-commerce, automobiles, and F&B companies, rebounded from negative earnings in Q1 and is expected to grow by over 60% in 2021 and 30% in 2022. Analysts attribute this growth to the US consumption recovery, driven by previous stimulus packages and an improving job market.

site_title: China moves to further tighten control of its technology sector
summary: China has published draft regulations to tighten control over its technology sector, aiming to tackle unfair competition and restrict the use of user data. The rules, issued by the State Administration for Market Regulation, ban unfair competition and prohibit companies from hijacking traffic or influencing users' choices with data or algorithms. The move is part of Beijing's efforts to curb the abuse of market power, misuse of consumer information, and violation of consumer rights. The regulations are open to public feedback until September 15.

site_title: US billionaire buys struggling shopping malls as others shy away
summary: US billionaire Igal Namdar has accumulated a $2 billion fortune by buying struggling shopping malls at bargain-basement prices. His strategy involves recruiting down-market retailers to fill vacancies, limiting debt, and minimizing capital improvement spending. Since the pandemic, mall values have plummeted 46% from their 2017 peak, making Namdar's approach lucrative. Despite lawsuits accusing him of neglecting maintenance, Namdar believes he can turn a profit before the last tenants leave, focusing on B and C-rated malls that others deem unviable.

site_title: A recipe for bringing people together
summary: Singapore's Health Minister Ong Ye Kung launched a book titled "Instant Comfort: A Collective Memory" about instant noodles, which has raised over S$600,000 for two children's charities. The 236-page book features personal stories from over 100 people, including well-known personalities, about their experiences with instant noodles during the pandemic. The book's proceeds will support The Business Times Budding Artists Fund and The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund, which have helped approximately 200,000 children over the years.

site_title: Oil eases as weak Asian data, more lockdowns dampen demand hopes
summary: Oil prices declined for a fourth consecutive session, falling 0.7% to $69.03 per barrel for Brent crude and 1% to $66.59 per barrel for US West Intermediate crude. Weakened Asian demand, fueled by surging coronavirus cases in Japan and lockdowns, contributed to the decline. A strong dollar and lower US crude stocks also pressured prices. Analysts expect oil prices to remain volatile until the Delta variant subsides and the global economy recovers.

site_title: FDI applications uptick a bright spot in Thailand's gloomy economic outlook
summary: Thailand's Board of Investment (BOI) reported a 158% year-on-year increase in investment applications for the first half of 2021, reaching $12 billion. The surge is attributed to existing investors expanding or upgrading production lines, and investing in technology. Despite a third wave of Covid-19, the BOI's figures offer a bright spot in Thailand's gloomy economic outlook, with exports growing 15.5% year-on-year and a 10% devaluation in the baht currency. However, the tourism sector remains a concern, with a forecasted 150,000 foreign tourists for 2021 and a lowered GDP growth forecast to 0.7%.

site_title: How to ensure corporate governance and responsible investment in private equity go hand-in-hand
summary: A first-of-its-kind investigation by Simon Witney explores the relationship between corporate governance and responsible investment in private equity. As a visiting professor at the London School of Economics and a private equity lawyer with over 20 years of experience, Witney examines the interplay between these two functions. His research aims to understand how corporate governance and responsible investment can work together effectively, particularly in the context of private equity, where institutional investors and boards of directors play a crucial role.

site_title: Why are US Treasury yields so low?
summary: US Treasury yields remain near their lowest levels since the pandemic, despite the fastest pace of inflation since the early 1990s. The unusual dynamics can be attributed to the interplay between the US Treasury and the Federal Reserve, with the Fed purchasing $80 billion in Treasuries per month and the Treasury drawing down its cash reserves. However, with the US debt ceiling lifted and the Treasury cash balance set to return to pre-pandemic levels, investors expect a reversal in the trend, potentially leading to higher Treasury yields.

site_title: Taliban say won't seek 'revenge', co-founder back in Afghanistan
summary: The Taliban have pledged not to seek "revenge" against their opponents in Afghanistan, as co-founder Mullah Abdul Ghani Baradar returned to the country after months of talks with the US and Afghan peace negotiators. The group announced plans to form a government and allow women to work in accordance with Islamic principles, although details on their policies remain unclear. The US has authorized the deployment of 6,000 troops to ensure safe evacuations and will hold the Taliban to their promises to respect human rights. The international community is watching closely as the Taliban attempts to project an air of restraint and moderation.

site_title: Binance in talks with bourse veteran for top Singapore job
summary: Binance Holdings is in talks with former Singapore bourse executive Richard Teng about the top job at its Singapore business, as the crypto exchange seeks to appease regulators globally. Teng, who returned to Singapore from the UAE in April, previously held positions at the Monetary Authority of Singapore and Singapore Exchange. Binance is seeking a compliance expert to lead its Singapore unit amid scrutiny from regulators worldwide. The potential appointment is seen as a step towards placating regulators, but compliance track record and technology risk-management systems will also be crucial.

site_title: BHP to exit fossil fuel business in sweeping overhaul
summary: BHP Group announced a sweeping overhaul, exiting its fossil fuel business and shifting towards "future-facing" commodities. The company will sell its oil and gas operations to Woodside Petroleum in exchange for shares, and invest $5.7 billion in a massive fertilizer mine in Canada. BHP also approved a single primary listing in Australia and unified its dual-listed structure. The move is part of CEO Mike Henry's efforts to focus on metals and minerals benefiting from reduced emissions and electrification. The decision comes as investors pressure companies to transition away from fossil fuels.

site_title: CapitaLand Investment may pave way for other real estate investment managers to list on SGX
summary: CapitaLand Investment (CLI), a newly listed real estate investment manager, has seen its share price surge 20% since announcing a major restructuring plan in March. With pro forma net assets of S$14.7 billion, CLI's valuation is estimated to be around S$2.8 per share, potentially undervalued if it trades above its book value. The listing of CLI may pave the way for other real estate investment managers to list on the Singapore Exchange, potentially boosting the sector.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open flat after Wall Street falls
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index opened flat on Wednesday, following a decline in Wall Street shares, amid Japan's struggle to control a surge in virus cases. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.02% to 27,428.84, while the Topix index rose 0.03% to 1,916.26. The flat opening comes after a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks, where the STI rose 0.4% on Thursday, and amid positive trading in the US, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: UK wage growth hits a record as job vacancies pass one million
summary: UK wage growth hits a record 8.8% as job vacancies exceed one million for the first time, driven by loosening coronavirus rules. Average earnings surged in the second quarter, partly reflecting pandemic distortions, but underlying wage pressures gather pace. The recovery from the 300-year economic slump continues, with the unemployment rate falling to 4.7% and payroll growth rising by 182,000 in July. The Bank of England warns that meeting the 2% inflation target may require a modest withdrawal of monetary stimulus.

site_title: The art of the deal has to be learnt in person, not via Zoom calls
summary: A former investment banker argues that the art of deal-making on Wall Street cannot be learned through virtual meetings and emphasizes the importance of in-person collaboration. He recounts his own experiences watching senior bankers and traders at Lazard and Merrill Lynch, observing their subtle power dynamics, emotional nuances, and social cues. The author believes that returning to offices, even with vaccination, is crucial for the next generation of bankers and traders to learn from experienced professionals and master the art of deal-making.

site_title: Janet Yellen gets a chance to shape the Fed, this time from outside
summary: Janet Yellen, the US Treasury secretary, is getting another chance to shape the Federal Reserve after being replaced by Donald Trump in 2017. As president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco and its board, she has extensive experience. Yellen will now use her position as Treasury secretary to influence the Fed's future decisions. This move could be seen as an opportunity for her to reassert her influence on monetary policy.

images.alt_text: Now, as Treasury secretary, Dr Yellen (centre) will be a critical voice in deciding who ought to lead the Fed in a once-in-a-generation opportunity to remake the important institution.

site_title: Kiwi tumbles ahead of RBNZ meeting; US dollar up
summary: The New Zealand dollar plummeted 1.4% to its lowest in nearly three weeks after the country's first Covid-19 case since February prompted a short-term lockdown. Auckland will lock down for seven days, while the nation as a whole will face the toughest level of lockdown for three days. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand is expected to raise interest rates, but analysts now predict a quarter-point hike with a probability of 85%. The US dollar rose 0.1%, while the Australian dollar fell to a nine-month low amid risk-averse currency markets.

site_title: Banks may be ready to start dancing again
summary: Banks appear to be poised for a recovery, with concerns over non-performing loans proving overblown. Many banks have reversed provisions for bad debts, and their price-to-book ratios and dividend yields suggest they are undervalued. Despite share prices being higher now than last year, investors can look at the current valuation and consider adding to their holdings when they appear cheap. The resilience of banks has regained investor confidence, and they are ready to "start dancing again," according to former Citigroup boss Chuck Prince.

site_title: Green push to seed new jobs in carbon services, product development
summary: Singapore's sustainability push is expected to create new jobs in carbon services and product development, according to EDB chairman Beh Swan Gin. This nascent area will see companies innovate and create new products. The country is positioning itself as a global hub for sustainability and advanced technologies.

site_title: Singapore's psyche must be prepared for living life with Covid-19
summary: Singapore's Covid-19 situation appears to have stabilized, with vaccination coverage on track, low severe case numbers, and decreasing new daily cases. However, the country must now focus on less quantifiable costs, such as the mental toll on citizens and societal faultlines that may deepen under the strain of the pandemic. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong highlighted these issues in his National Day Message, emphasizing the need to address material conditions and provide support to those affected. The government must continue to work on improving conditions, making help available, and maintaining national morale, preparing the country's psyche for living with Covid-19.

site_title: Shipping is getting safer but risks are growing
summary: Shipping incidents and losses have decreased by 50% over the past decade, with total losses down to 2,703 in 2020, according to a report by Allianz Global Corporate & Specialty (AGCS). Despite this, the industry faces growing risks, including crew changes, mega-ships, supply chain disruptions, and climate challenges. East Asian waters have seen the most ship losses, with the South China, Indochina, Indonesia, and Philippines maritime region reporting 224 vessels lost. Insurers warn that while shipping is safer, it's not without risks, and the industry must adapt to these challenges.

site_title: Changes to eligibility of cancer drugs for claims under MediShield Life
summary: Singapore's MediShield Life insurance will change its cancer drug treatment eligibility starting September 2022, requiring outpatient cancer drugs to be included in a list of clinically proven and cost-effective treatments. The list, created by the MediShield Life Council, will have 55 more cancer drugs added, increasing support for around 150 cancer drugs. The changes aim to reduce healthcare costs and ensure that patients pay less for cancer drug treatments, with close to 90% of subsidized patients having their bills fully covered by subsidy and MediShield Life.

site_title: Share prices of world's major vaccine manufacturers surge
summary: The share prices of world's major vaccine manufacturers have surged due to plans for a Covid-19 vaccination booster and increased profits. BioNtech and Pfizer saw significant gains, with BioNtech soaring 365% and Pfizer rising 45%. Other vaccine producers, including Johnson & Johnson, AstraZeneca, and Moderna, also saw increases in share prices. Many countries are considering making booster shots available, and companies are expanding supply to more countries, including low- and middle-income economies. The third vaccination is expected to further boost profits, with companies charging higher prices for wealthy nations and donating vaccines to poorer countries.

site_title: July factory output up by most in 4 months; retail sales fall reflects shift to services spending
summary: US factory production rose 1.4% in July, the largest increase in four months, exceeding pre-pandemic levels. Industrial output also grew 0.9%, driven by resilient business spending and steady consumer demand. However, retail sales fell 1.1% in July, reflecting a shift towards services spending and higher prices. The drop in retail sales may signal a softening in third-quarter consumer spending growth, with economists forecasting a 4.5% annualized pace.

site_title: Yuan's global use faces test as Xi's reforms rattle markets
summary: China's yuan faces a test of its global use as sudden industry crackdowns raise concerns among investors. Despite a steady increase in its use in international trade and investment, the yuan's share of global payments via Swift and central bank reserves still lags behind the US dollar. The yuan's share in global payments increased to 2.46% in June, close to a record high, and around 30% of central banks plan to increase exposure to the yuan in the next 12-24 months. However, the crackdowns may have dented trust in the currency, with some experts warning of potential outflows from yuan assets in portfolios.

site_title: Palm oil stocks record stronger H1 revenue, profits on higher CPO prices, demand
summary: Palm oil stocks in Singapore have seen a surge in revenue and profits due to higher crude palm oil (CPO) prices and stronger demand for their products. CPO futures are up 54.1% year-to-date, with supply from Malaysia and Indonesia coming under pressure due to drought. Companies such as Golden Agri-Resources, Indofood Agri Resources, and Wilmar International have reported higher earnings and revenue, with some exceptions like Kencana Agri and First Resources. Analysts expect CPO prices to hit a record high in 2021, but prices are expected to lose steam beyond this year.

site_title: Successful innovation investing
summary: Innovative investments are expanding beyond technology, focusing on applying existing technologies to develop new business models, reach new customers, or address new markets. Recent developments include OpenAI's planned web browser release, Chinese AI startup Manus' relocation to Singapore, and AI Hay's $10 million Series-A funding. Additionally, startups like Bluebird and DeepSeek are accelerating their innovation efforts. These investments demonstrate the growing importance of innovation and its potential to drive growth and success in various industries.

site_title: Giving social enterprises a leg up
summary: DBS Private Bank is working to encourage philanthropy and social entrepreneurship among Asia's wealthy, recognizing the need for a "dual bottom line" where purpose and profits go hand-in-hand. The bank connects high-net-worth clients to social enterprises, providing funding and support to address social and environmental problems. This approach is gaining traction, with investors warming up to "venture philanthropy" and record investments in sustainable funds in Asia. DBS aims to expand its ESG conversations with clients beyond personal wealth and help businesses create positive social impact.

site_title: Malaysia power struggle unlikely to see major shift in policy direction
summary: Malaysia is set to have its third government in as many years following Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin's resignation. However, analysts expect no major shift in policy direction, with populist measures such as cash transfers likely to remain. The king has ruled out elections during the pandemic, and a caretaker premier will remain in office. The speaker of parliament has set a deadline for lawmakers to submit their choice for the next prime minister. The country's "credible and effective institutions" are expected to limit the impact on macroeconomic policies and credit profile, despite ongoing political uncertainty.

site_title: Fine-tuning MediShield Life: From 2022, cancer drug treatments must be in 'positive list' to be eligible for claims
summary: Cancer drug treatments for outpatient patients will be required to be included in a 'positive list' of clinically proven and cost-effective treatments to be eligible for MediShield Life claims starting from September 2022. This change aims to curb soaring healthcare and claims costs.

site_title: US: Stocks fall after weak July retail sales data
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday after disappointing July retail sales data, with car purchases dropping significantly. The decline was attributed to concerns over rising Covid-19 cases and uncertainty over China's tech crackdown. Analysts also pointed to worries over US-China trade tensions. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite these concerns, highlighting a mixed market sentiment.

site_title: Nato chief blames Afghan leadership for Kabul collapse
summary: NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg blamed Afghan leaders for the collapse of the government and the Taleban's swift victory, saying their failure to achieve a peaceful solution led to the "tragedy." NATO remains focused on ensuring the safety of its personnel and Afghan employees, with around 800 personnel working at the Kabul International Airport to maintain operations. Stoltenberg urged the Taleban to respect and facilitate the safe departure of those who wish to leave the airport and ensure roads and border crossings are open for the safe evacuation of Afghan citizens.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets extend losses at open
summary: European stock markets declined at the open on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.3% to 7,135.02 points, and the eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices also falling 0.5% each. The declines are attributed to economic recovery concerns and rising virus cases.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts lower Nanofilm target price on weak results, leadership uncertainty
summary: Analysts from UOB Kay Hian, DBS, and Jefferies have downgraded Nanofilm Technologies' target price to S$4.00 from S$5.51 due to weak results and leadership uncertainty. The company's shares lost 10.1% on Tuesday after announcing disappointing first-half results, with analysts citing higher-than-expected costs and lower average margins. Despite maintaining "add" ratings, analysts expressed concerns about execution and leadership changes, including the departure of CEO Lee Liang Huang and COO Ricky Tan.

site_title: OCBC Bank launches inaugural climate index
summary: OCBC Bank has launched the inaugural OCBC Climate Index, a survey measuring Singaporeans' environmental sustainability awareness and climate action. The index, based on a survey of 2,000 Singaporeans aged 18-65, found that Singaporeans have high awareness of environmental issues but struggle to adopt green practices due to cost and inconvenience concerns. The index highlights the need for environmentally sustainable behavioral change and aims to raise awareness about carbon emissions. OCBC Bank plans to use the index to inform policy and business decisions, while Eco-Business will use the data to drive consumer and business decisions.

site_title: BRICS flexing muscles on the world stage
summary: The BRICS bloc, comprising Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa, is flexing its muscles on the world stage, driving a potential period of sustained movement towards greater global income equality for the first time in two centuries. The bloc's economic cooperation has led to a decline in global income inequality, with BRICS accounting for a quarter of global GDP and contributing to the decline of global income inequality. However, the bloc's growing political cooperation and diverging economic trajectories among its members pose challenges to its cohesion and relevance. The BRICS will convene for their annual summit in September, with a focus on reforming the multilateral system and promoting sustainable development.

site_title: NutryFarm quashes rumour that packaging on durians imported from Thailand to China carry coronavirus
summary: NutryFarm International has denied a rumor that durian packaging imported from Thailand to China carried the coronavirus. The company states that there is no incident, and online articles claiming otherwise are inaccurate. NutryFarm continues to export fresh durians from Thailand to China, adhering to strict food safety standards and customs guidelines. The company's business operations are functioning normally, and it aims to capitalize on China's demand for durians and create an international platform for fresh produce trading.

site_title: 3 in 4 financial services firms want clearer AI ethics, governance standards: Temasek report
summary: A report by Temasek found that 75% of financial services companies want clearer AI ethics and governance standards. Despite guidelines existing, only 50% of organizations are familiar with them, highlighting a need for improvement. The report also showed that 93% of firms prioritize trustworthy AI solutions. Meanwhile, global AI spending is expected to reach $110 billion by 2024, with financial services accounting for a significant portion of this growth, and AI solutions potentially adding $2 trillion to annual value.

site_title: Maki Kaji, 'Godfather of Sudoku', dies at 69
summary: Maki Kaji, the "Godfather of Sudoku," has died at 69 due to bile duct cancer. A university dropout, Kaji founded Japan's first puzzle magazine and created the 9x9 logic puzzle "sudoku" in the mid-1980s. The puzzle, which challenges players to fill a grid with unique numbers, has become popular worldwide, with over 100 million people estimated to try it regularly. Kaji stepped down as head of his company, Nikoli, in July due to ill health and passed away on August 10. He was known for his simple yet exciting puzzle design philosophy.

site_title: NEA launches S$3b medium-term note programme to finance sustainable waste management projects
summary: The National Environment Agency (NEA) of Singapore has launched a S$3 billion medium-term note programme and green bond framework to finance sustainable waste management projects. The first project, the Tuas Nexus waste management facility, is Singapore's first integrated facility to treat incinerable waste, source-segregated food waste, and dewatered sludge. The green bond framework aligns with the International Capital Market Association's Green Bond Principles and aims to support Singapore's green finance market, as part of its "Green Plan" to green its economy.

site_title: Anwar Ibrahim, Ismail Sabri neck-and-neck in race to be Malaysia's next PM: Sources
summary: Anwar Ibrahim and Ismail Sabri are neck-and-neck in Malaysia's prime ministerial race, with both having the backing of around 105 lawmakers. A simple majority of 111 MPs is needed for a majority government. Warisan Sabah has offered its support to Anwar in exchange for the deputy prime minister post, which could potentially bring in additional MPs from other parties. The King has set a deadline of Wednesday for MPs to submit their choices, with Muhyiddin Yassin also reportedly gathering support for a comeback.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What happened today
summary: Several large Temasek-linked employers in Singapore, including Singtel, SATS, and SingPost, have lifted salary freezes and restored pay for employees as the economy recovers from the COVID-19 pandemic. Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) growth remained robust at 12.7% in July, with economists optimistic about the export outlook for the rest of the year. Additionally, Singapore Press Holdings' media restructuring plan has been backed by an independent financial adviser, and the country's stock market fell for a second consecutive day despite upbeat NODX figures.

site_title: Circular Economy and clean technology for a sustainable future
summary: The World Bank predicts a 70% increase in global waste by 2050 if current practices continue, highlighting the need for sustainable waste management. The Circular Economy model offers a solution, focusing on designing-out waste, maximizing resource value, and regenerating natural systems. Benefits include a sustainable future, reduced consumption of natural resources, improved environmental conditions, and lower greenhouse gas emissions. Companies like Timberland and Patagonia are adopting Circular Economy practices, and advancements in wastewater treatment and clean technology are enabling industries to recover and reuse wastewater, creating economic and social benefits.

site_title: FTSE 100 to lose second-biggest name as BHP goes home to Australia
summary: BHP Group, the world's largest mining company, announced plans to simplify its listing structure by moving from a dual listing in the UK and Australia to a primary listing in Australia. This move will result in BHP being removed from the FTSE 100 Index, prompting asset managers and exchange-traded funds to sell their holdings. The change aims to make BHP more nimble in pursuing deals and better align with its Australian roots, but will also have a significant impact on the UK index, which is seeking to attract new listings outside the European Union.

site_title: Independent financial adviser in favour of SPH's media restructuring
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) is set to restructure its media business, which has been struggling due to declining print advertising revenue. Independent financial adviser Evercore Asia recommends shareholders vote in favour of the proposal, citing potential significant losses and risks. The move aims to shift the company's focus to the real estate sector and related segments, allowing for strategic direction and increased opportunities for shareholders. The restructuring will also lift restrictions under the Newspaper and Printing Presses Act, enabling investors to own more than 5% of shares.

site_title: 90-year-old fully vaccinated man is Singapore's first to die from Covid-19 complications
summary: A 90-year-old fully vaccinated man in Singapore has become the first to die from Covid-19 complications, despite being fully vaccinated. He had a history of chronic kidney disease and hypertension. He developed symptoms on July 29 and died on August 2. The man's death highlights that even fully vaccinated individuals with underlying medical conditions can be susceptible to severe illness. As of Tuesday, 45 people have died from Covid-19 complications in Singapore, with 93 active clusters and 404 patients in hospital.

site_title: New Zealand reports first coronavirus case in community since February
summary: New Zealand reported its first community case of COVID-19 in six months, with a person testing positive in Auckland. The case's connection to the border or managed isolation is being investigated. The country, which has virtually eliminated COVID-19 domestically, advises Auckland residents to wear masks as a precaution. This case marks the last reported community case since February.

site_title: Hong Kong doubles quarantine for most returning residents
summary: Hong Kong has doubled its hotel quarantine period to at least two weeks for most returning residents, ending a brief period of looser travel rules. The decision, made by Chief Executive Carrie Lam, solidifies the city's "Covid Zero" stance and restricts entry to vaccinated travelers from New Zealand, Macau, mainland China, and Taiwan after a seven-day quarantine. The move follows a resurgence of outbreaks driven by the delta variant and comes as other countries, including Singapore, begin to ease restrictions and plot reintegration with the world.

site_title: Thailand seeks 12m Sinovac shots for mix-and-match vax strategy
summary: Thailand plans to buy 12 million doses of Sinovac's coronavirus vaccine to accelerate its rollout, using a mix-and-match strategy of Sinovac's inactivated virus vaccine and AstraZeneca's viral vector vaccine. The move comes amid a severe coronavirus wave in the country, with a record 239 new deaths reported. Officials claim this combination protects against the Delta variant, although concerns over efficacy remain. The strategy is being implemented due to supply shortages of locally produced AstraZeneca vaccines. Thailand aims to inoculate its population faster, with just 7.3% of the population fully vaccinated.

site_title: GK Goh unit to divest stake in Definitiv Group
summary: A unit of investment firm GK Goh Holdings has agreed to sell its 31.52% stake in corporate services provider Definitiv Group to Access Workspace. The sale includes a cash component and an earn-out amount tied to Definitiv's annual recurring revenue targets. The deal is conditional and subject to adjustments. The sale will be conducted through Boardroom, a 92.02% indirect subsidiary of GKGH.

site_title: China holds assault drills near Taiwan after 'provocations'
summary: China conducted assault drills near Taiwan with warships and fighter jets, responding to "external interference" and "provocations". The People's Liberation Army (PLA) dispatched troops near Taiwan to carry out "joint fire assault and other drills". The move comes amid a pressure campaign by China to force Taiwan to accept its sovereignty.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall for second consecutive day despite upbeat NODX figures
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.9% to 3,118.51, marking the second consecutive day of decline, despite a 12.7% non-oil domestic exports growth in July, beating economists' expectations. Tech names were major losers, with AIY shedding 6.2% and MZH extending its decline by 10.1%. Investors remain cautious due to lingering coronavirus fears, but analysts like Yeap Jun Rong see a positive longer-term outlook for the Singapore market due to vaccination rates and gradual reopening.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 20.69 points to 1,523.59 on Tuesday, closing higher. The index saw a gain in volume with 4.216 billion lots worth RM2.406 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 633 to 372.

site_title: Japan to expand virus emergency to battle surge
summary: Japan's government has expanded a coronavirus state of emergency to seven new regions, including Tokyo, ahead of the Paralympic Games. The measures, which include banning restaurants and bars from selling alcohol and requiring them to close by 8 pm, were initially set to end by August 31 but will now run until September 12. The country is battling a record wave of infections, with over 20,000 daily cases nationwide, and only around 37% of the population is fully vaccinated. The government attributes the surge to the virus spreading across the country, not the Olympics.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close well down
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed with significant losses on Tuesday, as investors reacted to the Delta coronavirus strain. The Hang Seng Index fell 1.66% to 25,745.87, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined by 2.00% and 2.52%, respectively. The losses were attributed to concerns over a stalled global economic recovery.

site_title: Sea's Q2 net loss widens to US$433.7m even as revenue rises
summary: Sea Ltd, the parent company of e-commerce platform Shopee and game developer Garena, reported a widening net loss of US$433.7 million in Q2, despite revenue more than doubling to US$2.3 billion. The company attributed the growth to its gaming and e-commerce arms, with digital entertainment sales reaching US$1 billion and quarterly active users increasing by 45.1% to 725.2 million. Sea also reported an increase in operating expenses, with sales and marketing spending rising by 142% to US$649.2 million.

site_title: China denounces US for 'awful mess' in Afghanistan
summary: China has denounced the US for leaving an "awful mess" in Afghanistan following the Taleban's takeover of the country. China's foreign ministry spokeswoman, Hua Chunying, criticized the US withdrawal, saying it has left "unrest, division and broken families" in Afghanistan. China, which shares a border with Afghanistan, had previously offered economic support and investment for reconstruction. China is now ready to cooperate with the Taleban, urging the new regime to prevent the country from becoming a gathering place for terrorists. China's criticism comes amid a hasty withdrawal by the US after 20 years of military intervention.

site_title: Global tax reforms will not hurt Singapore's competitiveness: EDB chairman
summary: Singapore's Economic Development Board (EDB) chairman Beh Swan Gin says the country is not concerned about global tax reforms hurting its competitiveness. Despite a potential minimum global corporate rate of 15%, Singapore has built strong value propositions, such as a steady and effective environment for capital, technology, and knowledge-incentive activities, and protection for intellectual property. The country's emphasis on good governance and safe management measures during the pandemic has also attracted companies. With 70% of the population fully vaccinated, Singapore is seeing increased interest from companies looking to set up shop in the country.

site_title: China market regulator issues draft rules banning unfair competition in Internet sector
summary: China's State Administration for Market Regulation issued draft rules banning unfair competition in the internet sector. The rules prohibit the use of data, algorithms, or technical means to hijack traffic or influence users' choices. Business operators are also barred from using technology to impose incompatible barriers to other legal internet products and services. In cases of violations, third-party institutions may conduct audits. The move aims to protect internet users and promote fair competition in the sector.

site_title: Koh Boon Hwee, Patsnap founder and iGlobe invest in mental health platform MindFi
summary: MindFi, a corporate mental health and wellness platform, has raised US$750,000 from investors including iGlobe Partners and prominent angel investors. The Singapore-based startup aims to work on product development and localisation for key markets in Asia, building a team of mental health experts and innovators. MindFi's technology provides personalised recommendations based on user data and offers guided self-care programmes. The company, co-founded by Bjorn Lee, now has over 30 enterprise clients across Asia and aims to help grow mental health awareness in the region.

site_title: Palm oil stocks record stronger H1 revenue, profits on higher CPO prices, demand
summary: Palm oil stocks in Singapore-listed companies have seen a significant boost in revenue and profits due to higher crude palm oil (CPO) prices and increased demand. CPO futures have risen 54.1% year-to-date, leading to higher average selling prices and sales volumes. Companies such as Golden Agri-Resources, Indofood Agri Resources, and Wilmar International reported higher earnings and revenue, with some declaring interim dividends. However, Kencana Agri and First Resources were exceptions, with lower revenue and profit due to lower sales volumes and export taxes. Market analysts expect CPO prices to remain high in 2021, with Fitch Solutions forecasting a record high of RM3,400 per tonne.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.78 points, or 0.38%, to 1,508.68 on Tuesday, driven by a higher trading volume. Gainers outnumbered losers 230 to 94.

site_title: At Pentagon, US military officials bitter as they watch chaos in Kabul
summary: US military officials at the Pentagon expressed frustration and concern over the chaotic evacuation of Kabul airport, criticizing the slow pace of the Biden administration's efforts to evacuate US-allied Afghans who fear Taleban retribution. The State Department's delay in granting visas to former interpreters and support staff has exacerbated the situation, with some waiting over two months to escape. Videos showed scenes of panic and fear in Kabul, with crowds attempting to cling to US military transport planes as they prepared to depart.

site_title: Japan's 'father of Sudoku' dead at 69
summary: Japan's renowned puzzle creator, Maki Kaji, known as the "father of Sudoku," has died at 69 due to cancer. Kaji, who popularized the numerical brainteaser worldwide, passed away at home on August 10. A memorial service is planned for a later date. Nikoli, his Japanese publisher, described Kaji as "loved by puzzle fans all around the world" and acknowledged his significant contribution to the world of puzzles.

site_title: Hot stock: Shares in ComfortDelGro down; eyes ASX listing for Australian subsidiary
summary: ComfortDelGro Corporation's shares fell 4.2% to S$1.60 on Tuesday, down S$0.07, after the transport operator announced plans to list its Australian subsidiary on the ASX. The IPO is planned for the last quarter of 2021, following a S$91 million net profit for the six months ended June 2021. The Australian business has generated S$608 million in revenue for the year ended Dec 31, 2020.

site_title: Economists optimistic about Singapore's non-oil export outlook after 12.7% growth in July
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) grew 12.7% in July, exceeding economists' expectations, marking the eighth consecutive month of year-on-year expansion. The growth was mainly driven by non-electronics exports, with contributions from specialised machinery, pharmaceuticals, and petrochemicals. Despite a sequential decline in NODX, economists remain optimistic about the export outlook for the rest of the year, with forecasts ranging from 7-8% growth. The strong July performance is attributed to resilient demand for semiconductor chips and related equipment, as well as the recovery of global trade flows.

site_title: Beijing tightens grip on ByteDance with rare China board seat
summary: China's government has tightened its grip on ByteDance, the world's largest private technology company, by appointing a director to the board of its key domestic subsidiary. This move gives the government more sway and insight into the company's operations. ByteDance sold a 1% stake in Beijing ByteDance to entities including the country's Internet overseer, and granted the government a board seat. The unusual arrangement is a rare instance of the government's direct involvement in the company's governance.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on US gains
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.52% and the Topix index advancing 0.36%, following Wall Street's mostly higher close, which set fresh records.

site_title: Evergrande founder steps down as onshore unit chairman
summary: Evergrande founder Hui Ka Yan has stepped down as chairman of China Evergrande Group's onshore unit, Hengda Real Estate, amid funding troubles. Zhao Changlong has taken his place, following the decision not to pursue a backdoor listing on China exchanges. The move triggered market declines, highlighting investor anxiety over Evergrande's cash crunch and broader implications for China's financial system. The company has been spinning off assets and relying on discounts to cut down on debt, but faces ongoing challenges and potential sources of future funding.

site_title: Former Guavapass CEO snags US$6.3m for new Singapore-based financing startup Jenfi
summary: Singapore-based financing startup Jenfi has raised US$6.3 million in a Series A round led by Monk's Hill Ventures. Jenfi loans up to US$500,000 to digital businesses as non-dilutive capital, taking a small percentage of revenue back as repayment. The startup plans to target underserved digital businesses, with funding from other investors including Golden Equator Ventures and 8VC. Jenfi aims to provide growth capital to entrepreneurs without diluting their ownership.

images.alt_text: Jenfi loans up to US$500,000 to businesses as a form of non-dilutive capital. It then takes a "small" percentage of the startup's revenue back as repayment, it said.

site_title: Berkshire trims General Motors bet, ramps up Kroger stake
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway trimmed its investment in General Motors for the third quarter in a row, cutting its stake by about 10% despite the stock's 3% gain. The conglomerate also boosted its stake in Kroger by 21% during the second quarter. Additionally, Berkshire pulled back on pharmaceutical bets, including AbbVie and Bristol-Myers Squibb, but made a new investment in Merck & Co.'s spin-off, Organon & Co. The firm was an overall net seller of stocks during the period, with some other holdings, such as Chevron and Marsh McLennan, also decreasing.

site_title: Beijing owns stakes in ByteDance, Weibo domestic entities, records show
summary: China's government has taken stakes in domestic entities owned by tech companies ByteDance and Sina Weibo, according to corporate records. Beijing owns a 1% stake in ByteDance Technology, giving it a board seat at a subsidiary holding business licenses for popular apps Douyin and Toutiao. A separate entity, WangTouTongDa, holds a 1% stake in Weibo's main domestic subsidiary, Beijing Weimeng Technology. This move comes amid a widening regulatory crackdown on the tech industry, with regulators concerned about market power and user data management.

site_title: Singtel, SATS, SingPost, ST Engineering lift salary freezes, restore pay as economy recovers
summary: Several Temasek-linked employers in Singapore, including Singtel, SingPost, ST Engineering, and SATS, have lifted salary freezes or restored pay cuts as the economy recovers from the COVID-19 pandemic. The companies, which had implemented cost-cutting measures last year, have now resumed normal pay practices. Market sentiment has improved, and companies are reporting increased profits. The moves are seen as a sign of the labor market improving, with job turnover potentially increasing in fast-growing sectors.

site_title: Forever 21 to launch Singapore site 'very soon'
summary: Forever 21 to launch its official Singapore site "very soon" after closing its last physical store at 313@Somerset in June. The site is the group's biggest focus in the region, aiming to hop on the omni-channel bandwagon. A new physical store is planned once tourism resumes in Singapore, with landlords showing interest. The brand had previously operated three other outlets islandwide in Singapore before the closure.

site_title: Major hedge funds took stakes in Didi before probe announcement: US filings
summary: Major hedge funds, including Temasek, T. Rowe Associates, Tiger Global Management, and George Soros' fund, took stakes in Didi Global Inc before Chinese regulators announced a probe, causing the company's share price to plummet. The filings show that these investors bought 33 million to 2.72 million American Depository Receipts (ADRs) in Didi, which went public in June. The move came just before the regulatory probe announcement on July 2, resulting in a 40% decline in Didi's stock value.

site_title: China central bank rolls over more policy loans than expected to boost growth
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, rolled over 600 billion yuan in policy loans, exceeding expectations to boost economic growth amid a resurgence of Covid cases. The move supported government bonds, which reversed earlier losses. The benchmark 10-year bond yield fell, and ten-year bond futures rose. The PBOC is expected to support growth further, with mounting calls for interest rate cuts and another reserve requirement ratio cut before year-end.

site_title: Santos more than doubles interim dividend
summary: Santos, an Australian gas producer, has more than doubled its interim dividend to 5.5 cents per share, beating a Macquarie estimate of 5 cents. The company posted a six-month underlying profit of US$317 million, up from US$212 million last year, driven by stronger oil and gas prices as economies reopened from Covid-19 lockdowns.

site_title: Blue Origin sues Nasa over SpaceX Moon contract
summary: Blue Origin, a company owned by Jeff Bezos, is suing NASA over the awarding of a $2.9 billion Moon exploration contract to SpaceX, owned by Elon Musk. The company claims the evaluation process was unfair and that multiple awards should have been made. Despite a Government Accountability Office upholding NASA's decision, Blue Origin has lobbied to have the decision reversed. NASA is reviewing the case, stating it will return humans to the Moon in the middle of this decade and build a lunar orbital station in preparation for a crewed mission to Mars in the 2030s.

site_title: Australia: Shares dip on weak corporate earnings, Covid-19 jitters
