The developer is offering discounts of S$80,000 and S$70,000 off the listed prices of its Type A1 one-bedroom and Type B4 two-bedroom units, respectively. After the price cuts, the median price of the 474 square feet one-bedroom apartments will be S$1.41 million. This move is seen as a strategy to attract buyers in a market where prices are rising.

site_title: US authorises Covid boosters for those with weakened immune systems
summary: The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has authorised an extra dose of Covid vaccine for people with weakened immune systems, including solid organ transplant recipients. The move comes as the country struggles with the spread of the Delta variant, which has led to a surge in cases and deaths. The FDA granted emergency use authorisation for a third injection of the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines. The decision follows a similar move by Israel, and is aimed at protecting immunocompromised individuals from severe disease.

site_title: Microsoft protests Amazon win of big US cloud contract
summary: Microsoft is protesting the US government's decision to award a $10 billion cloud computing contract to Amazon, citing a lack of transparency and competition. The contract is for modernizing classified data storage at the National Security Agency (NSA). This move comes after Amazon successfully protested a $10 billion contract awarded to Microsoft in 2019. Microsoft is exercising its legal rights to challenge the decision via the Government Accountability Office, and the NSA has promised to respond accordingly.

site_title: Samsung leader Jay Y Lee released from prison on parole
summary: Samsung Electronics vice chairman Jay Y. Lee was released on parole from jail on Friday, ending an 18-month detention for bribery and embezzlement convictions. Lee's release has been seen as a relief for the company, as key strategic decisions have been delayed. He still needs permission from the justice ministry to resume work and will be expected to make decisions on major investments, including a $17 billion US plant. Lee apologized for causing concern and vowed to work hard to address labor rights issues.

site_title: Tokyo Paralympics to be held without spectators: reports
summary: The Tokyo Paralympic Games will be held mostly without spectators due to Japan's emergency lockdown amid a surge in novel coronavirus infections. Venue limits will be set at under 5,000 people, and organizers are considering inviting school children. The Paralympic events, set to begin on August 24, include swimming, table tennis, wheelchair fencing, and basketball, featuring over 4,000 athletes with various impairments.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.02 points, or 0.33%, to 1,506.99 on Friday, with 165 gainers outnumbering 86 losers. Volume reached 102.57 million lots worth RM41.25 million.

site_title: Facebook delays return to campus as Delta variant rages
summary: Facebook has postponed its workers' return to campus until early next year due to the surge in cases of the Delta variant of the coronavirus. The company set a new target of January for employees to return, citing data-driven approach for prioritizing safety. Facebook also requires office workers to wear masks, regardless of vaccination status. Other tech giants, including Google and Microsoft, have announced similar vaccination requirements for their employees.

site_title: Asia: Markets stutter as traders eye Federal Reserve move, Delta spread
summary: Asian markets declined on Friday, driven by concerns over the Delta virus variant and potential Federal Reserve tapering. US producer prices surged, fueling inflation fears, while China's crackdown on industries and anti-monopoly rules added to market uncertainty. Despite this, traders remain upbeat, with Wall Street's indexes reaching record highs. The Fed's speech at the Jackson Hole gathering is expected to provide insight into its plans, with tapering expected by the end of the year.

site_title: Higher palm oil demand, tight supply boost Golden Agri's optimism for rest of the year
summary: Golden Agri-Resources, a palm oil plantation owner, is optimistic about the rest of the year due to favourable demand and supply dynamics. Demand for crude palm oil has been boosted by countries recovering from the Covid-19 pandemic, while supply has been kept tight due to dry weather conditions in producing countries. The company reported a net profit of US$153.2 million for the first half of the year, with revenue rising 31.4% to US$4.45 billion. Golden Agri expects a "healthy growth" of about 12% in full-year production and plans to focus on replanting and technological innovation to capitalize on higher CPO prices.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit H1 DPU down 2.5% to 8.502 euro cents
summary: Cromwell E-Reit's half-year distribution per unit (DPU) fell 2.5% to 8.502 euro cents, from 8.717 cents a year ago, due to a delay in financing recent acquisitions and higher interest costs. Gross revenue rose 5.7% to 99.0 million euros, and net property income increased 11.4% to 64.3 million euros. The decline in DPU was attributed to the absence of capital gains and higher cash balances.

site_title: Singapore to temporarily relax foreign worker hiring rules: MOM
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower (MOM) has temporarily relaxed foreign worker hiring rules in the construction, marine shipyard, and process (CMP) sectors due to labor shortages amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Work permit renewals for CMP workers expiring between July and December 2021 will be extended for up to two years. Companies can also hire workers from India, Sri Lanka, Thailand, Bangladesh, Myanmar, the Philippines, and mainland China without meeting minimum requirements. A 30-day window will be provided for terminated workers to find new jobs, with support from the Singapore Contractors Association Ltd.

site_title: Olam's food ingredient business headed for London, Singapore listings; H1 profit up 26% to S$421m
summary: Olam International's food ingredient business, Olam Food Ingredients (OFI), is targeting a primary listing on the London Stock Exchange (LSE) and a concurrent listing on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) by the first half of 2022. The company reported a 26.7% increase in net profit to S$421.5 million for the half-year ended June 30, driven by strong growth in its cocoa, coffee, edible nuts, spices, and dairy businesses. OFI's revenue grew 33.7% to S$22.83 billion, with operational profits after tax and minority interests more than doubling to S$436.6 million.

site_title: WHO asks China for more data on Covid-19 origins as Russia deaths spike
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) is urging China to share raw data from the earliest Covid-19 cases to revive its probe into the origins of the disease. China has been criticized for its lack of transparency and access in the investigation, which has faced criticism for its findings and methodology. Meanwhile, Russia reported its highest daily coronavirus death toll since the start of the pandemic, with at least 4.3 million people worldwide affected. The US is also introducing a vaccine mandate for its public-facing healthcare workers amid a surge in hospitalizations driven by the Delta variant.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on Friday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index inching down 0.03% and the Topix index up 0.08%. Investors weighed US gains with concerns over inflation and rising coronavirus infections in Japan. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a surge in US stocks despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Samsung SDI considering building battery plant in Illinois: senator
summary: Samsung SDI is considering building a battery plant in Normal, Illinois, according to Senator Dick Durbin. The plant would supply battery cells for electric-vehicle startup Rivian, which has a factory in Normal. This move could bring jobs and investment to central Illinois. Samsung SDI's decision is part of the company's efforts to expand its battery production capacity to meet growing demand for electric vehicles. The project's details and timeline have not been officially announced.

site_title: Six dead, including suspected gunman in UK shooting
summary: Six people, including the suspected gunman, died in a "serious firearms incident" in Plymouth, England, on Thursday. Devon and Cornwall Police declared a "critical incident" in the Keyham area and ruled it out as terrorism-related. Emergency services responded to reports of gunshots in a residential neighborhood. The incident is under investigation, but no further details have been released.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Friday; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.4% to 3,170.15. Oceanus was the most active counter, with its shares up 8.1% to 4 cents. Genting Singapore posted a profit of S$88.2 million, while banking stocks were down, with DBS falling 0.9% to S$30.97. The US market finished at fresh records, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index advancing 0.3% and 0.4%, respectively.

site_title: High Court grants interim injunction prohibiting ecoWise EGM from convening
summary: The High Court has granted an interim injunction preventing ecoWise Holdings from convening its proposed extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to vote on the removal of deputy CEO Cao Shixuan. The EGM was called by shareholders seeking to remove Cao and appoint three new directors. Cao had claimed the EGM was unfair and discriminatory against him, and the court has temporarily blocked the meeting until the matter proceeds to trial.

site_title: Canadian judge questions arguments for Huawei CFO's extradition as hearings enter final days
summary: A Canadian judge expressed skepticism over the US case against Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou, questioning the validity of the charges. The judge, Associate Chief Justice Heather Holmes, asked if it's unusual for a fraud case with no actual harm and extensive knowledge within the institution about the true state of affairs. Meng's defense lawyers argue that HSBC was not misled and was aware of the subsidiary's true nature. The committal hearings are expected to finish next week, with the judge likely to issue an order on extradition in the autumn.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares start lower on Friday
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day with losses, extending the previous day's retreat, due to fresh crackdown fears after China's economy regulation plans. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.84% to 26,296.19, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. This move was largely attributed to concerns over China's regulatory crackdown on its vast economy.

site_title: First Resources H1 net profit falls 16.7% to US$32.6m on higher export taxes
summary: First Resources, a palm oil producer, reported a 16.7% decline in net profit to US$32.6m for the six months ended June 30, due to higher export taxes in Indonesia. Sales surged 48.4% to US$412.9m, driven by higher average selling prices and production volumes. Gross profit rose 51.9% to US$173.3m. The company declared a higher interim dividend of 1.25 Singapore cents. Indonesia reduced export levies for palm oil products effective July 2, expected to ease the export tax burden in the second half.

site_title: Trudeau to call Canada snap elections on Sunday: media
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau is expected to call snap elections on Sunday, citing a dysfunctional parliament and opposition pushback. Despite a nationwide uptick in Covid infections, Trudeau believes the election timing is opportune, with polls showing the Liberals could regain a majority. Opposition leaders have urged caution, warning of a spike in Covid cases and potential voter discontent. Trudeau's Liberal government faces a test of its ability to navigate a challenging election landscape.

site_title: CapitaLand H1 profit up at S$922.2m from S$96.6m on portfolio gains, market recovery
summary: CapitaLand reported a net profit of S$922.15 million for the first half of 2021, nearly 10 times the S$96.6 million in the same period last year, driven by a nascent economic recovery in Singapore and China. The company's revenue rose 34.7% year-on-year to S$2.73 billion, with operating profits after tax and minority interests increasing 66% to S$433.6 million. The group's fund management fee-related earnings rose 29% year-on-year to S$188.7 million, while funds under management grew 6.9% to S$83 billion.

site_title: HK sees 89,000 leave in past year after Security Law
summary: Hong Kong's population dropped by 1.2% to approximately 7.39 million people in the year through June 2021, with 89,200 residents leaving the city, mainly due to the implementation of the National Security Law. This decline is the second consecutive year, following a historic recession in 2019-20. The outflow is attributed to the curtailment of protest and dissent, as well as damaged personal freedoms.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand, Olam, Golden Agri, Isetan, Sasseur Reit, First Resources
summary: Several Singapore-listed companies released financial updates on Friday, with notable developments including CapitaLand's earnings of S$922.2 million for the first half of 2021, nearly 10 times its profit in the year-ago period, and Olam International's 26.7% increase in net profit to S$421.5 million. Golden Agri-Resources reported a net profit of US$153 million, while Isetan Singapore returned to the black with a profit of S$1.3 million. The companies' shares closed flat or declined on Thursday before the announcements.

site_title: ST Engineering gets S$100m state aid from abroad
summary: ST Engineering, a Singapore-listed company, has received S$100 million in state aid from abroad to support its operations during the post-pandemic recovery. The funds will be invested in facilities and talent to help retain jobs. The company's financial results for the first half of FY2021 showed a focus on this support during its earnings call.

site_title: Apple's iPhone maker predicts slowing gadget sales
summary: Taiwanese electronics manufacturer Hon Hai Precision Industry, the main assembly partner of Apple, has projected a sequential decline in gadget sales, including smartphones, this quarter due to chip and component shortages affecting iPhone production before the holiday season. The forecast raises concerns about meeting demand fueled by the pandemic, with component shortages weighing on output of iPhones, gaming consoles, and servers. Hon Hai chairman Young Liu attributed the decline to high comparison numbers and product transitioning, with total revenue expected to remain little changed sequentially.

site_title: Europe: Stocks extend record rally on lift from insurers, M&A activity
summary: European stocks rose for a ninth consecutive session, hitting a record high, driven by strong earnings from insurers and M&A activity. Insurers Aviva, Zurich Insurance Group, and Aegon NV reported significant gains. Deutsche Telekom also raised its profit outlook. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.1% despite a fall in mining stocks, with Rio Tinto slipping 5.5% on ex-dividend trading. Economic data showed Britain's economy grew 1% in June and factory output fell in the euro zone due to supply bottlenecks.

site_title: BT regional webinar to offer insights on investing in the Indonesian digital economy
summary: The Business Times (BT) Singapore will host a regional webinar "Investing in the Indonesian Digital Economy" on August 31, offering insights on growth trends and opportunities in Indonesia's digital economy. By 2025, Indonesia's digital economy is projected to reach US$124 billion in gross merchandise value. The webinar, led by BT's Garage team, will feature a panel discussing startup investment strategies and what it takes for founders to raise funds successfully in the Indonesian digital economy.

site_title: Airbnb warns of Delta impact on bookings, shares fall over 4%
summary: Airbnb warned that its bookings may be impacted by the Delta variant of the coronavirus and a slowing vaccination pace in the US, causing its shares to fall over 4%. The company expects nights and experiences booked in the current quarter to slow from the second quarter and remain below 2019 levels. Despite this, Airbnb expects the third quarter to be its strongest on record due to easing Covid-19 curbs and increased demand for vacation rentals. Active listings have been stable, with growth in non-urban destinations across Europe and North America.

site_title: Manhattan's newest Covid-age real estate bet: Condos for cars
summary: A Manhattan garage operator, Centerpark, is selling 23 parking spaces as condominiums, with prices ranging from $199,000 to $350,000 each. The move is seen as a response to the pandemic's impact on New York City, with reduced subway ridership and increased demand for personal parking. With garages and street spaces being converted into condos, the average price of parking spots has soared 51% in the past year, with some spots listed for over $550,000.

site_title: The house that wows
summary: A Singaporean property developer commissioned architect Robin Tan to design a unique 10,800 sq ft home that stands out from the neighborhood. The two-storey building features a basement, roof terrace, and cantilevered wings with a beige and silver travertine facade. The design prioritizes street presence while maintaining privacy, with horizontal aluminum fins providing shading and sun protection. The home boasts a sky light in the garage, a dramatic frangipani tree in the T-shaped pool, and unobstructed views of the city skyline. The design balances creativity with consideration for the neighborhood, ensuring the home remains a desirable residence for years to come.

site_title: Sasseur Reit posts 6.7% increase in Q2 DPU to 1.614 S cents; manager eyes potential acquisition
summary: Sasseur Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, reported a 6.7% increase in its Q2 distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.614 Singapore cents. Distributable income rose 19.7% to S$21.7 million, driven by a 6.7% increase in DPU. The Reit manager has retained 10% of the distributable income for future capital expenditure and working capital purposes, with the distribution scheduled to be paid out on September 28.

site_title: Oil prices slip as IEA warns of slowdown in demand recovery
summary: Oil prices fell on Thursday after the International Energy Agency (IEA) warned that the spread of the Delta variant of the coronavirus would slow the recovery of global oil demand. Brent crude futures dropped 13 cents to US$71.31 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude fell 16 cents to US$69.09 a barrel. The IEA's warning comes amid concerns about the impact of the Delta variant on oil demand recovery.

site_title: Britney's father 'to step down' as estate conservator: US media
summary: Britney Spears' father, Jamie Spears, is set to step down as conservator of her estate, reportedly ending a bitter legal battle with his daughter. Britney, 39, had sought to remove him from the guardianship role, citing "abuse." Jamie's lawyer initially disputed the move but later stated he would step back, saying it was in his daughter's best interests. Britney's lawyer welcomed the move, calling it "vindication" and vowing to investigate the conduct of Jamie and others involved in the conservatorship.

images.alt_text: Britney Spears' father is to step down as conservator of her estate, US media reported on Thursday, seemingly ending a bitter legal battle with his daughter.

site_title: Chicago's Drake Hotel hits market in lodging recovery test
summary: The owners of Chicago's iconic Drake Hotel are putting the property on the market, seeking a buyer willing to invest $250 million or more. The hotel, with 535 rooms and 200 feet of retail frontage, is expected to attract interest due to the nascent travel recovery and its prime location on the Magnificent Mile. The Brashears family, which controls a 90% stake, is open to upgrading the hotel or converting a portion to residential condominiums. The sale comes as demand for US travel surpasses concerns over the Delta variant, with revenue per available room reaching a high since 2019.

site_title: Meat and drink in new hotspots in town
summary: Wagyu Jin, a new 16-seater restaurant in Shaw Centre, offers A5-only wagyu by prefecture, providing diners with unique beef experiences. The restaurant sources beef from artisanal and less accessible breeders, offering omakase-style meals featuring various wagyu varieties. Yonezawa beef from Yamagata prefecture is particularly notable for its delicate flavor and high-quality marbling. Meanwhile, Kakure, a new cocktail bar in Scotts Road, offers a unique omotenashi concept with a focus on quiet contemplation and expertly crafted cocktails. Griglia Open Fire Italian Kitchen and Bedrock Origin are also set to open, offering seasonal Italian and seafood dishes, respectively.

site_title: SBS Transit H1 profit up 11.9% on government's wage support
summary: SBS Transit's first-half year net profit rose 11.9% to S$36.5 million, driven by government wage support and a 6.2% increase in revenue to S$640.8 million. Operating profit increased 18.5% to S$38.2 million, with public transport services revenue rising 5.9% to S$621.4 million. The company maintains a "cautious outlook" for the rest of the year, citing rising costs and a slow recovery in public transport ridership. An interim dividend of S$0.0575 per share was declared, representing a 49.2% payout ratio.

site_title: China partly shuts world's third-busiest port after one case of Covid-19 infection
summary: China has partly shut the world's third-busiest container port, Ningbo-Zhoushan, due to a Covid-19 infection among a worker at the Meishan terminal. The shutdown affects all inbound and outbound container services until further notice. The closure may further disrupt global trade, particularly during the holiday season, as trade volumes usually rise towards the end of the year. The port's closure could lead to delays in sailings, impacting cargo handling and shipping. All close contacts of the infected worker are in quarantine.

site_title: US: Stocks end at fresh records after latest price data
summary: US stocks closed at fresh records, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up less than 15 points to 35,499.85, the S&P 500 gaining 0.3% to 4,460.83, and the Nasdaq Composite Index advancing 0.4% to 14,816.26. The record closes mark the third straight day of gains, despite concerns over rising wholesale prices and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Global investors bet on China's rental property
summary: Global investors, including Blackstone and Warburg Pincus, are increasing bets on Chinese rental properties amid Beijing's efforts to provide rental housing. Despite regulatory challenges, China is attracting institutional interest as it seeks to address housing shortages. The government's push for rental housing is seen as a positive development, with investors betting that the political wind is in their favor. This shift in focus is expected to benefit the Chinese property market, potentially offsetting the negative impacts of Beijing's regulatory crackdowns.

site_title: Biden's 'reckless' Afghan policy leading to disaster: top Republican
summary: Senator Mitch McConnell criticized President Joe Biden's policy in Afghanistan, calling it "reckless" and predicting a "massive, predictable, and preventable disaster." The US is evacuating embassy workers as the Taleban advances on Kabul. McConnell stated that the Biden administration is pleading with Islamic extremists to spare the embassy, indicating a lack of control. The situation in Afghanistan is deteriorating, with the US facing a potentially chaotic and unstable outcome.

images.alt_text: The top Republican in Congress blasted President Joe Biden Thursday for his "reckless policy" on Afghanistan, as the United States moved to evacuate embassy workers ahead of the Taleban advance.

site_title: CDL looks to launch nearly 2,000 units in 4 Singapore projects
summary: CDL, a leading Singapore property developer, plans to launch nearly 2,000 housing units in four upcoming projects. The company aims to maintain its gearing at an optimal level, recycle capital, and grow its land bank. CDL is also exploring opportunities in China, despite recent regulations, and has refurbished its US assets, including the M Social New York hotel. The company will consider bringing in a financial partner for the Fuji Xerox Towers redevelopment to keep its gearing optimal.

site_title: Investors renew focus on Fed following signs that inflation has peaked
summary: The US inflation data, released on Wednesday, suggests that inflation may have peaked, reassuring investors that the Federal Reserve will not need to hasten plans to rein in emergency-level economic support. Consumer price increases slowed in July, with the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average closing at record levels. Investors remain concerned about elevated inflation, corporate profit margins, and rising coronavirus cases. The Fed is expected to taper its $120 billion monthly bond purchases, which could impact bond prices and corporate margins.

site_title: Portugal, Spain on wildfire alert as heatwave kicks in
summary: Spain and Portugal are on wildfire alert as a heatwave hits the Iberian peninsula, with temperatures forecast to reach 40 degrees Celsius in some areas. Scientists warn that global temperature rises will make heatwaves more frequent and intense. The heatwave, fueled by hot air from North Africa, has contributed to massive wildfires in Italy, Turkey, and Algeria, killing dozens. Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez urges citizens to take precautions and cooperate with authorities to minimize the risk of wildfires. Portugal's weather office has issued a "maximum" alert for wildfires in some regions.

site_title: The good, the bad, and the ugly of startup ESOP schemes
summary: Employee stock option plans (ESOPs) can be a valuable tool for startups, but some employees have found that the promised benefits don't always deliver. Experts discuss how to improve ESOP schemes to align interests and incentivize staff. Meanwhile, Singapore's arbitration role is expected to continue growing, and China's stock market faces uncertainty after the government took action in key sectors.

site_title: Japan wholesale inflation hits 13-year high as import costs rise
summary: Japan's wholesale prices rose 5.6% in July, the fastest annual pace in 13 years, driven by rising import costs for raw materials. However, analysts question whether companies will pass on these costs to households, keeping consumer inflation around zero despite global commodity inflation. The Bank of Japan's corporate goods price index (CGPI) marked the fifth straight month of growth, but experts expect a slow pass-through to consumer prices.

site_title: Complicated pleasures
summary: Patek Philippe has released a new wristwatch, the Ref 6301P Grande Sonnerie, which features a grande sonnerie, petite sonnerie, and minute repeater. The timepiece is powered by a hand-wound movement and is priced at S$1.7 million. The watch also incorporates two patented innovations linked to the striking mechanisms, allowing for automatic striking of the full hours and quarter hours. Additionally, Louis Vuitton's Tambour Carpe Diem and H Moser & Cie's Heritage Perpetual Calendar Midnight Blue Enamel have been showcased, offering unique complications and designs.

site_title: Golden Agri-Resources swings to black in H1 2021 on palm product output recovery
summary: Golden Agri-Resources reported a net profit of US$153 million for the first half of 2021, reversing from a net loss of US$157 million in the same period last year. Revenue increased 31.4% to US$4.45 billion, driven by higher international crude palm oil prices. The company's plantations and palm oil mills segment saw a 66.9% increase in revenue. Chairman Franky Widjaja attributed the improvement to a stronger financial position, lower leverage, and a strengthened liquidity position, despite industry outlook concerns over tight global vegetable oil supply and weaker-than-expected palm oil production recovery.

site_title: BlackGold's proposed reverse takeover falls through
summary: BlackGold Natural Resources' proposed reverse takeover of Mongolian mining firm Tengri Coal and Energy has fallen through due to a share placement exercise not being completed by the deadline. The deal, valued at S$1 billion, would have led to a takeover of BlackGold. TCE's sole shareholder terminated the sale and purchase agreement.

site_title: Diners and doctors help UK economy to extend recovery
summary: The UK economy grew 1% in June, beating expectations, with the healthcare sector contributing the most to expansion. Despite this, GDP remains 2.2% smaller than pre-pandemic levels, a reminder of the damage caused by lockdowns. The economy is expected to regain its pre-pandemic size by the end of 2021, with the Bank of England predicting 5.75% growth in 2022 and 1.25% in 2023.

site_title: Hong Kong sees 89,000 leave in past year after security law
summary: Hong Kong's population declined by 1.2% to approximately 7.39 million people in the past year, with 89,200 residents leaving the city, mainly due to the implementation of the National Security Law. The population drop is the first in over a decade, following a historic 18-month recession and the pandemic. In response, the UK introduced a new visa for Hong Kong residents, with over 34,000 applications received in the first quarter of this year.

site_title: A rosé by any other colour
summary: Wine experts challenge the common perception that lighter-colored rosés are of higher quality. A recent exploration of dark rosés from around the world, including those from California, France, and Italy, reveals that color is not always a reliable indicator of a wine's character. The article highlights three dark rosés that differ significantly in terms of flavor, acidity, and origin, demonstrating that other factors such as grape variety, production methods, and aging process play a more significant role in shaping a wine's quality.

site_title: Building global supply chain resilience through regional distribution centres in Asean
summary: Singapore, Malaysia, and Thailand are popular locations for regional distribution centers (RDCs) due to their strategic geographical location, supporting facilities and infrastructure, and ease of doing business. These countries offer various advantages for businesses looking to tap into Asean's growth and rising middle class. Singapore is a regional hub for global corporations, while Malaysia has diverse hub locations, including Kuala Lumpur, Johor, and Penang, which offer lower land and labor costs and a supportive investment ecosystem. Thailand is developing its Eastern Economic Corridor, which aims to turn three provinces into a manufacturing hub, and is targeting to have electric vehicles account for 30% of total car production by 2030.

site_title: Japan's 10 trillion yen university fund eyes alternative assets, foreign stocks
summary: Japan's new 10 trillion yen university fund is set to invest in alternative assets and foreign stocks, aiming for higher returns than conservative pension funds. The fund's chief investment officer, Masakazu Kita, plans to include private equity, real estate, and infrastructure, as well as hedge funds. The fund will hire experts in alternative assets to diversify its portfolio and seek better returns.

site_title: Malaysia economy likely to stay afloat despite policy flip-flops, political instability: analyst
summary: Malaysia's economy is expected to stay afloat despite inconsistent policies, the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, and political uncertainty, according to analyst Oh Ei Sun. The country's reliance on natural resources such as palm oil, rubber, oil, and gas will help it weather these challenges. Businesses are shifting towards more profitable ventures, leading to job creation. A rate cut aims to shield the economy from tariff threats, but it also signals growth jitters. Despite these challenges, Malaysia's economy is expected to remain commercially-driven and stable.

site_title: Dollar off four-month high as inflation jitters ease
summary: The US dollar stood near a four-month high against major peers on Thursday, easing inflation jitters. The dollar index was little changed at 92.942 after data showed US inflation slowing in July. Analysts at Commerzbank said this data makes it likely that inflation will ease back to the 2% target, reducing the need for aggressive interest rate hikes. However, other analysts cautioned the dollar's dip could be short-lived, with some predicting new highs beyond 93.50 as taper talk gathers momentum later this quarter.

site_title: Aviva to hand investors at least £4b following asset sales
summary: Aviva plans to return at least £4 billion to investors through asset sales, with an initial £750 million share buyback and the remainder to be paid by the end of 2022. The UK-based insurer's CEO, Amanda Blanc, has committed to making a substantial capital return to shareholders, following a year of focus on core businesses and divestment of non-core units. The payout aims to boost investor confidence and follows recent efforts to overhaul the firm.

site_title: Manulife US Reit's H1 DPU drops 11.5% to 2.7 US cents
summary: Manulife US Reit reported a 11.5% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.7 US cents for the six months ended June 30, down from the year-ago period. Distributable income fell 10.4% to US$43 million due to lower rental income from key tenants. Portfolio occupancy rates declined to 91.7%, but leasing momentum is accelerating, with 127,000 sq ft expected to be signed in the third quarter. The Reit expects revenue to recover, with 60% of tenants planning to return to the office in September.

site_title: UK house prices to rise due to supply shortage, surveyors say
summary: UK house prices are expected to rise further due to a shortage of new properties coming onto the market, according to a Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) survey. The number of estate agents seeing new properties come to market in July fell to its lowest since April 2020, and 66% of respondents predicted price increases in the next year. Detached houses saw a 10% price rise, while apartments saw a 1% increase since the pandemic started. The trend is driven by buyers seeking more space as remote work becomes more common.

site_title: China signals its regulatory crackdown will go on for years
summary: China has released a five-year blueprint outlining a comprehensive regulatory crackdown on key industries, including national security, technology, and monopolies. The plan aims to strengthen law enforcement and promote legislation in areas such as food, medicine, and digital governance. Authorities will also modernize national governance and increase public satisfaction. The crackdown, which has been ongoing, is expected to continue for years, with investors reeling from recent bans and probes into sectors like the US$100 billion after-school tutoring industry and major tech companies.

site_title: Bank of America closing gap with JPMorgan in Asia deals race as revamp pays off
summary: Bank of America has narrowed the gap with JPMorgan Chase in investment banking fees in Asia-Pacific, with the Charlotte-based bank now earning about $700 million in revenue. The bank's investment banking division has doubled in size, with about 300 bankers in the region, and has secured a record $2.1 billion in fees globally in the second quarter. Bank of America is now within $20 million of JPMorgan, which ranks third in the region, and has improved its position in equity underwriting, ranking fifth among international banks.

site_title: A weekend of art miracles
summary: The Singapore International Festival of Arts (SIFA) 2021 finally took place in its delayed final leg, with a series of art miracles performed by the Singapore Symphony Orchestra and Singapore Dance Theatre. The postponed leg debuted at the Esplanade to a limited audience, featuring exceptional performances of William Walton's Passacaglia For Cello, Variations From A Distance by choreographer Pam Tanowitz, and The Light Behind Us by Christina Chan. The festival ended on a high note, offering a rare theatre treat amidst the pandemic, with performances that reminded the audience of the importance of live performance in the arts.

site_title: EU urges all major economies to raise climate goals by Nov summit
summary: The European Union's top diplomat, Josep Borrell, urged major economies to set tougher climate targets by November's global climate summit, aiming for 2030 targets and climate neutrality commitments. The EU and US have already set ambitious targets to reduce emissions. Borrell emphasized the EU's duty to lead by example, given its historical emissions. China, India, and Russia face international pressure to raise their ambition, with China's GDP growth expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: ST Engineering gets S$100m foreign state aid to invest to keep jobs
summary: ST Engineering received S$100 million in additional foreign state aid to support job retention and investments in facilities. The company had initially guided a reduction of S$250 million in state aid but now expects only a S$150 million cut. ST Engineering plans to invest in overseas facilities, including setting up passenger-to-freighter lines in the US, with a significant ramp-up in demand expected. The company's net profit rose 15% to S$296.1 million for the first half of 2021, driven by government support and a boost in order book.

site_title: A museum's disappearing act
summary: The Singapore Art Museum (SAM) is temporarily relocating to various spaces across the island due to renovations, which have been delayed by the pandemic. The museum, known as SAM M.I.A., will appear in a large warehouse space in Tanjong Pagar Distripark and in libraries and tourist attractions. This shift aims to showcase contemporary art in unexpected spaces and engage with the public in a more collaborative manner. The museum's director, Eugene Tan, believes that art is now ubiquitous in everyday life, and the traditional notion of a museum as a sole authority on art is outdated.

site_title: US jobless claims fall; producer prices post solid rise
summary: US jobless claims fell to 375,000 for the week ended August 7, down 12,000 from the previous week. This marks the third consecutive decline in initial claims. Meanwhile, producer prices rose 8.7% year-over-year, the largest annual increase in over a decade, driven by inflation pressures.

site_title: Fine art lending thrives thanks to hedge funds
summary: Fine art lending has seen significant growth due to the credit market's demand for yield. Hedge funds are investing in art-backed loans with yields of 8% or more, making it easier for art collectors to tap into their prized possessions as collateral. This niche of the credit world is growing rapidly, with art-lending businesses experiencing notable increases in growth, such as Bank of America's 15% year-over-year growth and Sotheby's 49% increase in loan book since 2018.

site_title: There is nothing 'private' about private enterprises in China
summary: China's "socialist market economy with Chinese characteristics" aims to balance capitalism and social objectives under the Communist Party's control. The system features public ownership, central party control, and the goal of social equity and justice. The CPC's treatment of private capitalists has evolved, with President Xi Jinping emphasizing the need for private sector capitalists to "help and heed" the party. Recent regulatory crackdowns on Ant Financial Group, Didi Chuxing, and the after-school tutoring sector demonstrate the government's intention to maintain social control and promote common prosperity. China's approach to private enterprise is not anti-capitalist, but rather seeks to regulate and align capitalist forces with the party's ideology.

site_title: Lendlease, SingPost, Paya Lebar Square to form pilot Business Improvement District
summary: Lendlease, SingPost, and Paya Lebar Square Pte Ltd have formed a Business Improvement District (BID) pilot in Paya Lebar Central, Singapore, aiming for greater liveability and interconnectedness. The BID will introduce diverse community spaces and focus on sustainability, active living, and cultural diversity. It will collaborate with the Health Promotion Board and fitness partners to organize health and wellness events. This is the first BID outside the central business district, and the partnership will take an experience-led approach to enhance public spaces and create authentic places and experiences for residents and visitors.

site_title: Swiss Re says disaster losses hit US$77b in first half
summary: Swiss Re reports estimated disaster losses of US$77 billion in the first half of 2021, with US$74 billion caused by natural catastrophes and US$3 billion by man-made disasters. Severe weather events, including winter storm Uri and June storms in Germany, contributed to the losses. The reinsurer warns that climate change and urban development exacerbate catastrophe losses, and the insurance industry must upgrade its risk assessment capabilities to address these growing risks.

site_title: Three new Covid-19 clusters, including Safra Tampines and Chin Swee Road preschool
summary: Three new Covid-19 clusters were reported in Singapore, including Safra Tampines and My First Skool at 54 Chin Swee Road, with a total of 15 new cases. The country's total cases now stand at 66,012, with 119 active clusters and 470 patients warded in hospital. The Ministry of Health noted that fully vaccinated individuals do not suffer serious disease unless they have underlying medical conditions, and that unvaccinated individuals are more likely to become severely ill or die.

site_title: Adidas to sell Reebok to Authentic Brands for up to US$2.5b
summary: Adidas has agreed to sell its underperforming Reebok business to Authentic Brands Group for up to US$2.5 billion. The majority of the share price will be paid in cash, with the rest as deferred and contingent consideration. The deal is expected to close in the first quarter of 2022. Adidas had acquired Reebok for US$3.8 billion in 2006, but failed to revive its performance. Authentic Brands, which has acquired over 30 brands, including Barneys New York and Sports Illustrated, will add Reebok to its growing portfolio.

site_title: CDL's hotel business showing green shoots of recovery from Q2
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL), a Singapore property and hotels group, has seen green shoots of recovery in its hotel business from the second quarter of this year, with overall revenue per available room (RevPAR) more than doubling to S$63.2 from S$29 in Q2 2020. The group's hotel business has narrowed losses to S$47 million for H1 2021, and expects Ebitda to turn positive in Q3/Q4 this year. CDL's executive chairman, Kwek Leng Beng, is optimistic about a stronger rebound by the end of 2021/early 2022, driven by vaccination rates and quarantine-free travel.

site_title: 59 new locally transmitted Covid-19 cases; 19 unlinked
summary: Singapore reported 59 new locally transmitted Covid-19 cases, with 19 unlinked cases, on August 12. Five seniors aged above 70 who are unvaccinated or partially vaccinated are at risk of serious illness. The total cases now stand at 66,012. There were no imported cases.

site_title: Designing future healthcare facilities to cope with pandemics and other health crises
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for healthcare facilities to be designed to cope with future pandemics and health crises. Hospitals struggled to accommodate the overwhelming patient load, leading to attempts to "flatten the curve" to reduce the burden. However, physical space is only one issue; there are also problems with the design of healthcare environments that impact the delivery of care. Companies are exploring new designs to address these challenges and provide better care to patients in the face of future pandemics and health crises.

site_title: Halcyon Agri swings to profit in H1 amid higher rubber prices
summary: Halcyon Agri Corp, a natural rubber supplier, reported a net profit of US$759,000 for the first half of 2021, reversing a net loss of US$40.4 million in the same period last year. Revenue increased 49.6% year-over-year to US$1.15 billion, driven by a rebound in sales volume and improved unit margins. Natural rubber prices surged 30% since 2021, influenced by post-lockdown demand and supply shortages. Despite the profit, the company's adjusted loss attributable to owners was US$3 million, and no dividend was recommended for the first half.

site_title: Rex returns to profitability in H1 as revenue clocks 420% growth
summary: Rex International, an oil exploration and production company, reported a net profit of US$23.9 million for the first half of 2021, a significant turnaround from a net loss of US$21 million in the same period last year. Revenue surged 420% to US$75.8 million, driven by increased oil liftings and higher average realised oil prices. The company aims to maintain its performance in the second half, with plans to lift oil from Oman once a month. No interim dividend was recommended due to the recent turn to profitability.

site_title: The chief sustainability officer: organisational strategist and futurist
summary: The role of Chief Sustainability Officer (CSO) has emerged as a crucial aspect of business strategy and operational decision-making, requiring strong leadership at the C-suite level. With the increasing focus on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) risks, companies are recognizing the need for a CSO to accelerate business action on sustainability. The CSO's role has expanded to cover a widening set of mandates and duties, and their competencies include credibility, sense-making, and orchestration. Despite the growing demand for sustainability professionals, companies are still struggling to access the right people with the right sustainability skillset, highlighting the need for a CSO to shape organizational transformation and bring vision, passion, and purpose to the leadership team.

site_title: SunMoon Food's auditor notes material uncertainty over ability to continue as a going concern
summary: Independent auditor Nexia TS Public Accounting Corporation notes material uncertainty over SunMoon Food Co's ability to continue as a going concern due to cash flows in operating activities amounting to S$890,000 for FY2021, exceeding liabilities by S$472,000. The company's investments in subsidiaries and trade receivables also raise concerns. However, SunMoon Food Co's management claims to have sufficient net positive cash flow to meet obligations from April 2021 to September 2022, based on a 18-month cash flow forecast.

site_title: Yanlord H1 profit up 67% to 823.4m yuan
summary: Yanlord Land Group's net profit rose 67% to 823.4 million yuan for the half-year ended June 2021, driven by 45% revenue growth to 13.2 billion yuan. Property development contributed 86.3% of revenue, with gross floor area sold increasing to 711,738 square meters. Rental and hotel income rose 40.9% to 692 million yuan, fueled by China's real estate recovery. The group plans to launch new projects in China's key regions, including the Yangtze River Delta and Bohai Rim.

site_title: Home prices in the US soar 23%, the fastest rate on record
summary: US home prices surged 23% in the second quarter, the fastest rate on record, reaching an all-time high of $357,900. The median price of existing single-family homes increased due to a scarcity of listings and low mortgage rates. Sales of previously owned homes fell for the fourth consecutive month in May. Housing affordability for first-time buyers weakened, with mortgage payments jumping to 25% of income, according to the National Association of Realtors. Experts predict a slowdown in demand and supply in 2022.

site_title: New York Times puts newsletters behind paywall to boost subscriptions
summary: The New York Times is introducing 18 newsletters behind a paywall to boost subscriptions. The newsletters, written by Times journalists and contributors, will cover topics such as politics, technology, and lifestyle. The move aims to increase revenue, which has slowed down since a record 2020. The Times already produces about 50 newsletters reaching 15 million people weekly, and executives believe email is an effective method for attracting and retaining paying customers. The paywall will be part of a $1 weekly digital subscription, with some existing newsletters remaining free to nonsubscribers.

site_title: GIC-backed Vietnam tech firm considers US$3b SPAC merger
summary: Vietnam's VNG Corp, backed by Singaporean sovereign wealth fund GIC, is considering a US$3 billion SPAC merger to go public in the US. The online gaming and technology firm has been discussing potential deals with special purpose acquisition companies. A deal could value VNG at US$2-3 billion and join other Southeast Asian firms in seeking US listings through mergers. VNG has been exploring a potential Nasdaq listing since 2017, and discussions are ongoing with financial advisers.

site_title: Thailand's Banpu buys Texas plant in US power-market push
summary: Thailand's Banpu Public Co has agreed to spend $430 million to acquire a 768-megawatt electricity plant in Texas, marking the company's first step into the US power market. The deal, set to close in the fourth quarter, will allow Banpu's natural gas to supply the plant, a rare move for US shale producers. This acquisition is seen as a sign of a shift towards a decade-long trend of exploration and production companies maturing from the shale boom and directly supplying gas to power plants.

site_title: Hong Leong Asia H1 net profit up 110% to S$40.7m
summary: Hong Leong Asia's net profit surged 110% to S$40.7 million for the half year ended June 2021, driven by higher sales and revenue in its diesel engines and building materials units. Revenue rose 32.8% to S$2.8 billion, while earnings per share stood at 5.45 Singapore cents. The company's engine-making unit Yuchai saw 33.8% year-on-year growth in engine units, while its building materials unit saw strong demand due to government housing tenders. However, the company faces a challenging operating environment in Malaysia due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: US: Stocks pull back from records as investors weigh data
summary: US stocks pulled back from records as investors weighed a dip in jobless claims and a jump in wholesale prices. Jobless claims fell to 375,000, while producer prices increased 1% in July, exceeding expectations. The Dow Jones and S&P 500 retreated 0.2% and 0.1% respectively, while the Nasdaq Composite Index declined 0.2%. The pullback comes despite the Senate's passage of President Biden's infrastructure package and concerns about the Delta variant of Covid-19.

site_title: Reddit valued at US$10b in new funding round
summary: Reddit has raised up to $700 million in a funding round led by Fidelity Management, tripling its valuation to over $10 billion. The company's influence in the financial world has led to a surge in its value, fueled by small-time traders on its platform. This funding round comes after the company's value doubled to $6 billion in February, driven by the success of its WallStreetBets forum. Reddit now has over 52 million daily active users and has topped $100 million in advertising revenue for the first time.

site_title: China signals regulatory crackdown will go on for years
summary: China has released a five-year blueprint outlining a regulatory crackdown on key industries, including national security, technology, and monopolies. The document aims to strengthen law enforcement and ensure the "healthy development of new business forms" in areas such as digital economy and artificial intelligence. Authorities will also promote openness in government affairs and strengthen the execution of administrative decision-making. The plan, which was previously announced in 2020, has been met with mixed reactions from investors, who are seeking clarity on the enforcement and potential shape of the crackdown.

site_title: Baidu quarterly results top estimates on ad sales, AI demand
summary: Baidu's quarterly results exceeded Wall Street estimates, driven by a rebound in advertising sales and higher demand for its AI and cloud products. The company reported a 21% increase in investments in its products, totaling 15.9 billion yuan. Total revenue rose to 31.35 billion yuan, topping estimates of 30.96 billion yuan, with adjusted profit per share beating expectations. Baidu also announced the appointment of Herman Yu as chief strategy officer, replacing the position previously held by the CFO. The company's autonomous driving service and AI-powered cloud products have helped diversify revenue sources.

site_title: Malaysia will consider GST when time is right
summary: Malaysia's Economy Minister Mustapa Mohamed suggested reconsidering the goods and services tax (GST) at an appropriate time, citing the need for sustainable fiscal footing. The GST was repealed in 2018, but the OECD recommends its re-introduction to boost revenue, which has been falling due to economic contraction and increased spending. The government will deliberate on the OECD's recommendations and consider incorporating them into its economic policies. This comes as Malaysia's fiscal situation remains strained, with a record number of new COVID-19 cases reported.

site_title: Europe: Stocks mixed at open following recent gains
summary: European stock markets opened mixed on Thursday, following recent gains, with London's FTSE 100 index falling 0.3% to 7,201.53 points. The eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices remained flat. Rebounding UK growth and cooling US inflation were key factors.

site_title: UOL back in the black with S$91.3m profit for H1
summary: UOL Group posted a net profit of S$91.3 million for the first half of 2021, a turnaround from a net loss of S$82.1 million last year, driven by a 31% increase in revenue from property development and a sharp drop in fair-value losses. Revenue from property development surged 91% to S$687.5 million, while revenue from property investments rose 5% to S$249.8 million. Despite concerns over rising construction costs, UOL expects office rents in Singapore to continue rising and retail rents to remain under pressure.

site_title: STI posts modest 0.1% gains even as Delta variant fears persist
summary: Singapore shares closed marginally higher, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 2.80 points or 0.09% to 3,182.80, driven by overnight gains in Wall Street and tame inflation data. The market consensus is on a late-Q4 Fed tapering, but risks of an early surprise remain. Meanwhile, worries over the Delta variant and global trade disruptions weighed on trading sentiments, with Asia's key gauges finishing lower. Notable gains included Singtel and Singapore Technologies Engineering, while Wilmar International's 23% jump in net profit for the first half also boosted the market.

site_title: APAC Realty logs 119.7% profit jump on the back of buoyant residential property market
summary: APAC Realty, a mainboard-listed real estate services provider, reported a 119.7% profit jump to S$17 million for the six months ended June 2021, driven by a buoyant residential property market. Revenue rose 107.4% to S$358.4 million, with revenue from new home sales increasing 146% and resale and rental revenue up 95%. The group declared an interim dividend of 3.5 Singapore cents and a one-off special dividend of three cents per share, contingent on its cash and cash reserves.

site_title: Australia: Stocks end flat as Rio Tinto, CBA offset early gains
summary: Australian shares ended flat on Thursday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index rising 0.05% to 7,588.2, as gains from robust blue-chip earnings and gold miners were offset by losses in Rio Tinto and Commonwealth Bank. Rio Tinto shares fell 7% due to an ex-dividend trade, while Commonwealth Bank dropped 2.4% after reporting annual results and a large share buyback. Technology stocks were the biggest losers, with Afterpay declining 1.4%.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Thursday, down 2.47 points to 1,501.97. The index saw a volume of 3.331 billion lots worth RM2.268 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 576 to 383. This is not directly related to the provided Singapore or other articles.

site_title: Ho Bee Land's H1 profit improves 16.5% to S$105.5m
summary: Ho Bee Land's net profit increased 16.5% to S$105.5 million in the first half of 2021, driven by higher rental income and development profits. Revenue grew 46.5% to S$157.3 million, while recurring income from its office portfolio and positive rental reversions contributed to the improvement. However, the company's ancillary food and beverage tenants were severely affected by Covid-19 restrictions, and no dividend was recommended for the first half. The company's development front saw contributions from projects, including its maiden master-planned community residential project in Australia.

site_title: China's Nio aims to take on Volkswagen, Toyota with new brand
summary: Chinese premium electric vehicle maker Nio plans to launch a mass-market brand positioned similar to Volkswagen and Toyota, with a "core team" assembled for the initiative. CEO William Li compared the relationship between Nio and its new brand to Audi-Volkswagen and Lexus-Toyota. The new brand will likely target a lower price range, contrasting with Nio's current models, which are mostly above 300,000 yuan. This move aims to take on global rivals and expand Nio's market presence.

site_title: Temasek establishes new global AI solutions centre for businesses
summary: Temasek, a Singapore investment company, has established a new AI centre of excellence, Aicadium, to help businesses adopt and deliver AI technologies. The centre, based in Singapore and San Diego, aims to overcome common barriers to operational AI, including lack of understanding and talent acquisition. Aicadium will leverage a common machine learning platform to deliver AI-as-a-service, driving digital transformation and social impact across Temasek's portfolio companies. The initiative is part of Temasek's commitment to catalyzing novel solutions and transforming businesses.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end lower after three days of gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended lower on Thursday, following three days of gains, after China announced plans to tighten regulations on various industries as part of a crackdown to strengthen its economy. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.53% to 26,517.82, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also declined. The decline comes as investors react to China's regulatory efforts, which may impact global markets.

site_title: China sentences former senior ICBC banker to life for bribery
summary: China sentenced Gu Guoming, a former senior ICBC banker, to life in jail for bribery, taking about $21 million in bribes from 2005 to 2019. Gu, previously head of ICBC's Shanghai branch, also lost his political rights for life. This conviction marks a crackdown on corruption in the banking sector, following increased scrutiny by China's top anti-graft body since 2019.

site_title: Malaysia's Khazanah to increase high impact investments via US$1.4b fund
summary: Malaysia's Khazanah Nasional will allocate a US$1.4 billion internal fund to increase high-impact investments over the next five years. The fund will be sourced from profits and capital returns from commercial investments, supporting the nation's economic competitiveness and resilience. The investments will focus on environmentally, socially, and governance (ESG) areas, with clear development-specific target outcomes linked to national agendas. This move aims to enhance accountability in development investing and align with the government's new initiative for state-linked investment firms.

site_title: NAB upbeat on post-lockdown outlook after Q3 profit jumps 10%
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) reported a 10% jump in its third-quarter cash profit, adjusted for non-cash and one-off items, to A$1.7 billion. The lender expects a strong rebound in the Australian economy once lockdowns are eased. NAB's CEO, Ross McEwan, remains optimistic about the long-term outlook, citing strong economic growth, government support, and customers' healthy starting positions. The bank has deferred loan balances associated with lockdowns of less than A$1 billion.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks slip for sixth day as chip shares dive
summary: South Korean shares slipped for a sixth consecutive session as foreign investors sold heavy chip stocks, including Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix. The Kospi index fell 0.38% to 3,208.25, with Samsung Electronics down 1.91% and SK Hynix down 4.74%. The losses were offset by a 3.17% gain in LG Chem. Despite the decline, the Kospi has risen 11.65% this year, but has lost 2.3% in the previous 30 trading sessions.

site_title: Genting Singapore posts S$88.2m H1 profit, expects travel recovery to be drawn out, uncertain
summary: Genting Singapore posted a profit of S$88.2 million for the six months ended June 2021, reversing a year-ago loss, as Resorts World Sentosa reopened with fewer visitors. The group expects a drawn-out travel recovery due to new Covid-19 variants and strict re-opening measures. Despite this, Genting Singapore's earnings have improved from S$163.3 million in the second quarter of FY2020, its worst quarterly showing since the resort's opening over a decade ago. The company's outlook remains uncertain due to ongoing pandemic-related challenges.

site_title: China to draft laws for areas including national security, anti-monopoly
summary: China will draft new laws covering national security, anti-monopoly, technology innovation, education, and areas involving foreigners. The government aims to increase control over the economy and society, following recent clampdowns on tech giants and tutoring companies. President Xi Jinping's "rule of law governance" will be extended, with laws consistent with emerging sectors such as the digital economy and artificial intelligence to be developed. Authorities also plan to improve legislation on public health, social conflicts, and biosecurity, with strict enforcement of regulations in areas like food, medicine, and natural resources.

site_title: SBS Transit H1 profit up 11.9% on government's wage support
summary: SBS Transit's half-year net profit rose 11.9% to S$36.5 million, driven by government relief supporting reduced ridership due to the pandemic. Group revenue increased 6.2% to S$640.9 million, with public-transport services rising 5.9% and other commercial services increasing 18.1%. The transport operator declared an interim dividend of 5.75 cents per share, representing a payout ratio of 49.2%.

site_title: Aviva to hand investors at least US$5.6b after sale of non-core businesses
summary: Aviva plans to return at least US$5.6 billion to investors through a share buyback and dividend payments. The UK-based insurer and asset manager will start with an initial £750 million (S$1.4 billion) share buyback and the remaining amount will be returned by the end of 2022. CEO Amanda Blanc stated that the move is part of the firm's commitment to making a substantial capital return to shareholders. Despite a drop in first-half operating profit to £1.1 billion, Aviva's CEO aims to focus on core businesses in the UK, Ireland, and Canada.

site_title: iPhone maker predicts slowing gadget sales just as holidays loom
summary: Hon Hai Precision Industry, Apple's main assembly partner, predicts a decline in gadget sales, including iPhones, due to chip and component shortages before the holiday season. The company expects a sequential decline in sales this quarter, despite the third quarter being a peak production season. Component shortages, which have affected iPhone production, are expected to last into the second quarter of next year, with Hon Hai taking steps to secure semiconductor supplies through partnerships. The forecast raises concerns about meeting holiday demand for iPhones.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: DBS Digital Exchange has received in-principle approval to provide trading services for digital payment tokens, starting August 16. Life insurance sales in Singapore rose 61% to S$2.68 billion in H1. Boustead Projects and its partners acquired S$110 million of mezzanine debt for Orchard Hills Residences. Keppel DC Reit plans to raise around S$200 million through the issue of new units. Temasek established a new global AI solutions center. Corporate earnings showed mixed results, with CDL's hotel business recovering and ST Engineering's profit growing 15%.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares slip as chip stocks take hit from outlook worries
summary: Japanese shares fell on Thursday, with the Nikkei average down 0.20% to 28,015.02, as chip-related shares were hit by concerns about supply returns. The tech sector, particularly SoftBank Group, was also affected due to worries about China's recent crackdown on the tech sector. Meanwhile, travel-related shares were impacted by worsening coronavirus infections, while Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's falling support raised concerns about political stability ahead of an expected election later this year.

site_title: China's anti-sanctions law a new headache for banks in Hong Kong
summary: China's new anti-sanctions law, passed in June, could pose a compliance headache for international banks in Hong Kong, where the city has long been a reliable business gateway to authoritarian China. The law denies visas, deportation, or asset seizures for those who formulate or comply with sanctions against Chinese businesses or officials. Hong Kong's chief executive Carrie Lam confirmed the law will be applied in the financial hub, sparking concerns among banks about being caught between competing sanction regimes. While China may not enforce the law immediately, foreign banks fear the risk of prosecution and may choose to comply with US sanctions instead.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher after Wall Street rallies
summary: Tokyo shares rose 0.36% and 0.45% on the Nikkei 225 and Topix indices, respectively, following Wall Street rallies. Fears of US inflation decreased, allowing shares to gain. The gains come ahead of US GDP data and amid mixed Fed views.

site_title: Life insurance sales in Singapore up 61% to S$2.68b in H1
summary: Singapore's life insurance industry saw a 61% increase in weighted new business premiums to S$2.68 billion in the first half of 2021, driven by single-premium products. Annual premium product uptake rose 35% to S$1.4 billion, while online policy purchases increased to 203,351. The industry also saw growth in individual health insurance and retirement policies, with a 34% increase in retirement policy uptake. Total in-force annual premiums for group insurance rose 20%. The Life Insurance Association of Singapore attributed the growth to the stabilisation of the economy and increasing importance on long-term financial needs amidst the pandemic.

site_title: DBSV gets in-principle approval to provide trading services for digital payment tokens
summary: DBS Vickers (DBSV), the brokerage arm of DBS Bank, has received in-principle approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to provide trading services for digital payment tokens. DBS Digital Exchange (DDEx) will operate 24/7 from August 16, supporting asset managers and companies in trading digital payment tokens. DBS aims to double its investor base by the end of the year, with plans to provide integrated solutions across the digital asset value chain, including security token offerings (STOs).

site_title: AMP reports drop in attributable profit, holds back dividend
summary: AMP, an Australian wealth manager, reported a 28% decline in attributable profit for the first half of 2021 to A$146 million, due to losses from its AMP Capital and Australian wealth management divisions. The company is reviewing dividend payments and capital management strategy after completing a demerger of its Private Markets business and selling its global equities and fixed income business. AMP aims to deliver A$300 million of annual cost savings by 2022.

site_title: ExxonMobil, Chevron look to make renewable fuels without costly refinery upgrades: sources
summary: US oil majors ExxonMobil and Chevron are exploring ways to produce renewable fuels at existing facilities without costly refinery upgrades. The companies aim to make sustainable fuels like renewable diesel, sustainable aviation fuel, and renewable petrol using bio-based feedstocks, without significantly increasing capital spending. This approach could help reduce carbon emissions and capitalize on lucrative tax credits. Chevron has partnered with the EPA and CARB to develop a path to produce fuel for emissions credits, and ExxonMobil has created a task force to determine the capability of refiners to co-process bio-feedstocks.

site_title: Altered bank statement uncovered in Singapore Kitchen Equipment transactions
summary: AUDITORS of Catalist-listed Singapore Kitchen Equipment (SKE) have reported the company to the Minister for Finance after discovering altered bank statements in transactions with major shareholder QKEH. The altered statements, valued at S$1.4 million, were used to fund employee bonuses, donations, and Facebook advertising. An audit found that "certain employees" altered the documents without the CEO's or executive directors' knowledge, but no evidence of fraud or breach of trust was found. The company has halted trading and delayed its annual general meeting and financial results amid the investigation.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Thursday, following three days of gains, amid China's plans to expand tighter regulation across various industries. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.14%, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also dropped 0.28%. This comes after the US and EU trade talks took center stage, despite the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: China's Tesla rival Li Auto makes Hong Kong debut after US$1.5b IPO
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker Li Auto made its Hong Kong debut with a US$1.5 billion IPO, becoming the second mainland firm to list on Wall Street as a hedge against regulatory risks. Shares initially fell 2.8% to HK$116.80, down from its IPO price of HK$118. Li Auto plans to use the funds for research and development, including ultra-fast charging and intelligent vehicle technologies. The move comes amid China's tightening grip on industries, including tech and education, and its goal to have new energy vehicles comprise 25% of car sales by 2025.

site_title: Brokers' take: UOBKH downgrades PropNex to 'hold' on worries 2021 could mark earnings peak
summary: UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) downgraded its call on PropNex OYY to "hold" from "buy" with a higher target price of S$2.09 due to concerns that 2021 may be the peak earnings year for the real estate agency, despite its strong H1 FY2021 results. Analysts believe continued industry news flow may support the share price in the short term but expect a decline in Q4 FY2021 and FY2022.

site_title: Boustead Projects-led consortium to acquire mezzanine debt for Orchard Hills Residences
summary: Boustead Projects, led by a consortium of BP-Real Estate Investments, Roark Capital, and Lim Teck Lee Investments, has agreed to acquire S$110 million of mezzanine debt for Orchard Hills Residences in Singapore. The acquisition is valued at S$117 million, with Boustead Projects owning 50% of the notes. The secured debt is tied to a charge over shares in SC Aetas Holdings, which owns the 18-storey mixed development. The deal is seen as beneficial to Boustead Projects, generating a good financial return and expanding its property portfolio.

site_title: Hot stock: Singtel up 2.6% on Q1 net profit turnaround
summary: Singtel shares rose 2.6% in early trade after the company reported a net profit of S$445 million for the first quarter, compared to a net loss of S$20 million in the same period last year. Operating revenue increased 7.5% to S$3.8 billion, driven by growth in its Australian consumer business. The Australian dollar's 11% appreciation contributed to the increase.

site_title: ST Engineering H1 profit grows 15% on partial recovery of business segments
summary: ST Engineering reported a 15% increase in net profit to S$296.1 million for the first half of FY2021, driven by better performance in urban solutions, satellite communications, and defence segments. Group revenue rose 2% to S$3.65 billion, offsetting weaker commercial aerospace segment performance. The company approved an interim dividend of S$0.05 per share and has an estimated order book value of S$16.8 billion, with S$3.6 billion expected to be delivered in the remaining months of 2021.

site_title: Five ways Malaysia's political crisis could play out, and implications for businesses: report
summary: Malaysia's ongoing political crisis could lead to increased risk of governmental change, policy discontinuity, and regulatory disruption, according to a report by Control Risks. Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin faces calls for resignation and a parliamentary vote of confidence, which may be brought forward. Companies in Malaysia should watch for key triggers that signal a shift in the political state, such as the vote of confidence, to prepare for potential disruptions. The country's economic growth is already showing signs of jitters, with the recent rate cut aimed at shielding the economy from tariff threats.

site_title: Japan to launch indicator combining GDP and carbon emission reduction efforts: Nikkei
summary: Japan is set to launch a new indicator that combines its gross domestic product (GDP) with carbon emission reduction efforts, showing progress in reducing greenhouse gas emissions compared to economic growth. This comes after Japan doubled its 2030 target for cutting carbon emissions to 46% from 26% on 2013 levels. The new measure will be developed in collaboration with the private sector and is expected to provide a more comprehensive view of the country's decarbonization efforts.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CDL, ST Engineering, Manulife US Reit, Singtel, Wilmar
summary: Stocks to watch: CDL, ST Engineering, Manulife US Reit, Singtel, Wilmar. City Developments Limited (CDL) reported a net loss of S$32.1 million for the first half of 2021 due to a tax credit withdrawal and Covid-19 pandemic impact. ST Engineering's net profit rose 15% to S$296.1 million, while Manulife US Reit announced a distribution per unit of 2.7 US cents, down 11.5% from the year-ago period. Singtel posted a net profit of S$445 million, and Wilmar International's net profit increased 23% to US$750.9 million.

site_title: US diplomat Sherman to meet China's new ambassador on Thursday
summary: US Deputy Secretary of State Wendy Sherman will meet with China's new ambassador Qin Gang on Thursday at the State Department in Washington. The meeting comes as the US and China navigate strained relations, with the two nations having signaled a need for concessions to improve ties. Qin Gang, who took office in late July, has a reputation for making pointed public statements, while Sherman previously held high-level talks in China that ended with both sides signaling a need for concessions. The meeting will be their first in person.

site_title: Japan wholesale inflation hits 13-year high as import costs rise
summary: Japan's wholesale inflation surged to a 13-year high in July, with the corporate goods price index (CGPI) rising 5.6% from a year earlier. The increase was driven by higher import costs due to global commodity inflation and a weak yen. Raw materials such as wood, oil, and coal saw significant price hikes. However, it remains uncertain whether companies will pass on the higher costs to households, which could impact consumer inflation, currently stuck around zero.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed after Wall Street hits more records
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Thursday following a record lead from Wall Street, with the Dow and S&P 500 finishing at all-time highs. US inflation data showed a drop in core inflation to 0.3%, easing pressure on the Federal Reserve to unwind monetary policy. Meanwhile, China unveiled plans to tighten regulation across multiple sectors, including tech firms. Despite these factors, Asian stocks, including Singapore's STI, rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by investor optimism and a 5-day rally.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars edge higher, odds narrow on RBNZ hike
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars edged higher on Thursday, with the Aussie dollar at US$0.7363 and the kiwi dollar at US$0.7038. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) is expected to raise its cash rate next week, driven by high inflation expectations and a rapidly growing housing market. A survey showed a sharp rise in one-year inflation expectations to 3.02%, the highest since 2010, and a possible 0.5% rate hike is now priced in by markets.

site_title: China investors turn to renewables, chips, to avoid regulators' attention
summary: China investors are shifting focus to sectors such as semiconductors and renewable energy to avoid regulatory scrutiny. Following months of crackdowns on tutoring and big tech firms, money managers believe the Communist Party's push for common prosperity will lead to sector rotation. Despite selling wiping billions from affected companies' shares, firms in sectors seen as "reform-friendly" have seen surge in share prices, such as those in the semiconductor and renewable energy sectors. This shift is seen as a response to regulatory pressure and a push for common prosperity at the expense of private-sector profit.

site_title: CDL's hotel business showing green shoots of recovery from Q2
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL), a Singapore-based property and hotels group, is seeing green shoots of recovery in its hospitality business. The group's hotel business showed positive gross operating profit for June 2021, with all regions posting growth. Revenue per available room more than doubled to S$63.2 for Q2 2021, driven by easing border restrictions. CDL expects a stronger rebound by the end of 2021/early 2022, with vaccination rates and quarantine-free travel seen as catalysts for the industry's recovery.

site_title: Europe: Shares bag longest winning streak since June
summary: European shares hit a record high, clocking their longest winning streak in two months, driven by optimism over an upbeat earnings season and slowing US inflation. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.4% to an all-time high for an eighth consecutive session. Global shares followed, with the S&P 500 index reaching a record high.
