Analysts predict a record 148.1% jump in second-quarter profit, citing a stronger-than-expected economic recovery.

site_title: DoorDash held talks to buy Instacart: report
summary: US food delivery firm DoorDash Inc held talks to buy grocery delivery company Instacart for $40-50 billion, but the deal talks have fallen apart due to concerns over antitrust regulators' approval. Instacart initiated the talks, while also exploring a sales partnership with Uber. Both DoorDash and Instacart declined to comment on the matter. The talks are the latest in a series of failed deals in the delivery industry.

site_title: UK housing market comes off boil, still hot: RICS
summary: The UK housing market cooled slightly in July, with house prices easing to +79 from +82 in June, according to the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS). The partial removal of a temporary tax cut on property purchases, which had fueled a surge in prices, contributed to the drop in demand from new buyers. Despite this, buyers continued to seek spacious properties, and mortgage lender Halifax reported an unexpected month-on-month increase in house prices for July. The overall tone of the market remains firm, with elevated price expectations.

site_title: Strong quake strikes off Philippines, tsunami warning lifted
summary: A 7.1-magnitude earthquake struck off the Philippines, triggering a brief tsunami warning. The quake hit 63.3km east of Pondaguitan on Mindanao at a depth of 65km. A tsunami warning was issued for two hours before being lifted. The Philippines is prone to quakes due to its location on the Pacific "Ring of Fire".

site_title: Over 4,900 HDB BTO flats launched across five estates
summary: The Housing Board launched 4,989 Build-To-Order (BTO) flats across seven projects in five estates, marking the third sales exercise of the year. The median waiting time for completion is over four years. A highly anticipated project, Queen's Arc in Queenstown, offers 610 three-room and four-room flats. This is the third sales exercise for the year, with a focus on meeting demand for housing in Singapore's prime areas.

site_title: Manulife US Reit posts 11.5% drop in H1 DPU to 2.7 US cents on lower rental income
summary: Manulife US Real Estate Investment Trust (Manulife US Reit) reported a 11.5% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.7 US cents for the six months ended June 30, due to lower rental income from higher vacancies, rent abatements, and lower car park income. Occupancy rates dipped to 91.7% and portfolio occupancy was 4.5 percentage points lower than the 96.2% in H1 2020. Despite this, the company's CEO said leasing momentum is accelerating, with 127,000 sq ft expected to be signed in the third quarter.

images.alt_text: Manulife US Reit saw lower rental income from Michelson, Centerpointe and Capitol in H1.

site_title: Sydney faces tougher Covid-19 lockdown as outbreak grows: report
summary: Police in Sydney will be given greater powers to enforce lockdown orders with additional military support to combat the growing Delta variant outbreak. The move comes after regional town outbreaks in NSW, raising concerns the virus is spreading out of control. Authorities will be empowered to stop residents using loopholes in restrictions to travel outside the city. The measures aim to stem the growing outbreak, which has been in place for seven weeks.

site_title: US legislation aims to break grip on app stores
summary: US senators introduce a bill to loosen Apple and Google's grip on their app stores, making it illegal for them to require exclusive payment systems and forcing them to allow users to download apps from outside their stores. The bill, backed by Democrats and Republicans, aims to address concerns over the companies' control over the app marketplace, which they argue stifles competition and limits consumer choice. The legislation must still pass through Congress before becoming law.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Thursday; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.3% or 8.37 points at 3,188.37. Gainers outnumbered losers 100 to 42, driven by the record half-yearly net profit of 160.3 million yuan (S$33.6 million) announced by Catalist-listed company Jiutian Chemical. The company's shares were down 0.5 Singapore cent or 5.4% at 8.8 cents. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day streak of gains.

site_title: Singtel posts S$445m Q1 net profit, reversing year-ago loss
summary: Singtel reported a net profit of S$445 million for Q1, reversing a year-ago loss due to improved operating and business environment. Underlying earnings increased 30.7% to S$851 million, driven by improved operating and business environment. Notable exclusions include Optus's national broadband network revenue and Jobs Support Scheme credits. The result marked a significant turnaround from the previous year's loss.

site_title: Bank of America closing the gap with JPMorgan in Asia deals race
summary: Bank of America has narrowed the gap with JPMorgan Chase & Co in the Asia-Pacific investment banking market, generating comparable fees in the region. According to Bank of America's co-head of investment banking, Peter Guenthardt, the two firms are "neck-and-neck" in fees generated in Asia-Pacific. This marks a significant three-year rebuild for Bank of America, which has focused on winning big deals to catch up with its rival.

site_title: Crude futures settle higher and add gains on US policy
summary: Oil futures settled higher on Wednesday after the Biden administration ruled out a US call to increase crude output. The market was boosted by a report showing US crude supplies fell last week. Brent crude has risen 35% this year due to Opec-led supply curbs, despite a recent weekly loss. The US government's decision shifts focus away from production by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, a longer-term plan.

site_title: New Zealand plans phased reopening of borders next year: Ardern
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern announced plans for a phased reopening of borders in early 2022, moving away from the current lockdown restrictions. The country will adopt an individual risk-based model for quarantine-free travel, establishing low-, medium- and high-risk pathways. Additionally, the government aims to speed up its vaccination rollout, allowing all eligible ages to book their vaccine by September 1. This move is seen as a step towards reconnecting New Zealanders to the world, but Ardern emphasized that the country is not yet ready to fully reopen.

site_title: Sterling slips for 4th day versus resurgent dollar
summary: The British pound has fallen for the fourth consecutive day against the US dollar, reaching a new two-week low of $1.3813. The decline is attributed to the resurgent dollar, driven by impressive US jobs data and Federal Reserve remarks about tapering bond buying. The pound has also slipped off 18-month highs against the euro. UK second-quarter GDP figures, due on Thursday, may determine the currency's direction, with analysts predicting a 4.8% expansion. A slowdown in economic momentum could spell downside risks to the Bank of England's growth projections.

site_title: India urged to beef up economic integration with South-east Asia: DPM
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat urged India to strengthen economic integration with South-east Asia, citing the region's complementary strengths. He highlighted the importance of digital connectivity and the potential for India to join the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) when ready. Heng also emphasized the benefits of a stronger partnership between India and Singapore, including growth in urban solutions, agri-tech, and fintech, with opportunities for joint exploration and collaboration.

site_title: VIDEO: Mega trends for the next normal
summary: GuocoLand Group CEO Cheng Hsing Yao and OCBC Bank CEO Helen Wong discussed mega trends at a forum, including Asia's emergence as a global economic powerhouse, shifting demographics, and the rise of the middle class. They also touched on the future of manufacturing, climate change, and its impact on cities and urban planning. The conversation highlighted the importance of these trends in shaping the "next normal" and how they will impact economies and societies globally.

site_title: Moving the discussion away from a personal wealth tax
summary: Singapore policymakers may consider shifting the country's tax structure away from taxing income towards taxing wealth via a corporate wealth tax and property-related taxes. A 0.2% corporate wealth tax could generate around S$1.7 billion of additional tax revenue, comparable to a one-point hike in the Goods and Services Tax (GST) rate. However, the tax may not be as progressive in Singapore due to the country's wealth concentration in private housing, making property-related taxes a more viable option.

site_title: SAM is M.I.A. - and better
summary: The Singapore Art Museum (SAM) has temporarily vanished from its physical location due to renovations, but is instead "M.I.A." or "Museum In Action". It appears in various places, including a temporary warehouse space and libraries, before re-emerging. This campaign allows SAM to engage with a wider audience and explore new creative possibilities. The museum's relocation is part of its effort to adapt to the pandemic's impact on the art world.

site_title: US health authorities urge pregnant women to get Covid vaccine
summary: US health authorities have urged pregnant women to get vaccinated against Covid-19, citing safety and effectiveness data that shows no increased risk of miscarriage. According to a recent study, nearly 2,500 pregnant women who received an mRNA vaccine before 20 weeks of pregnancy experienced miscarriage rates around 13%, comparable to the typical 11-16% rate. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) emphasizes the benefits of vaccination outweighing potential risks, making it more urgent for pregnant people to receive the vaccine.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 end at records after inflation report
summary: US stocks ended at records for the second consecutive session after a closely-watched inflation report showed moderation in price growth. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.6% and the S&P 500 climbed 0.3%, while the Nasdaq Composite Index slipped 0.2%. Despite the moderation, inflation could still linger at high levels, according to analysts. Individual companies like Southwest Airlines advanced as investors shrugged off recent booking slowdowns and cancellations due to rising Covid-19 infections.

site_title: Schooling should decide what's next; to the rest of us - cut athletes some slack
summary: Singaporean swimmer Joseph Schooling, who won the country's first Olympic gold medal in 2016, faces a tough decision on his future in the sport. At 26, he is past his prime and faces competition from younger and more talented athletes. Fellow athletes and the author of a letter to the editor suggest that Schooling should consider his options and not be burdened by the expectations of his country. The author notes that many athletes sacrifice academically for the sake of their sport, and that Schooling should be given slack for his performance.

site_title: Investors look under radar for winners from US infrastructure bill
summary: Investors are searching for stocks that could benefit from a potential $1 trillion US infrastructure bill, which is expected to be passed later this year. Companies in the materials, industrial, real estate, and utilities sectors are seeing increased interest, with shares of companies like Crown Castle International Corp and Williams Companies Inc rising. Some investors are also adding to positions in companies like Norfolk Southern Corp and American Water Works Company Inc, which they believe will benefit from infrastructure spending.

site_title: Biden says he trusts Federal Reserve to take action on inflation if needed
summary: US President Joe Biden expressed trust in the Federal Reserve to take action on inflation if needed, amid a report showing US consumer price increases slowed in July. Inflation remains at a 13-year high, but experts believe bottlenecks and price spikes will reduce as the economy heals. Biden's administration is working to relieve bottlenecks and address concerns, including intensifying pressure on Opec to cut petrol prices and investigating anti-competitive behavior in petrol markets. The Fed's most recent projections do not see an interest rate increase until 2023, but debate over faster action continues.

site_title: Crypto currency platform loses estimated US$600m in cyber heist
summary: A cryptocurrency platform, Poly Network, has lost an estimated $600 million in digital tokens after a massive hacking attack, one of the largest in the crypto market. The heist, which occurred in July, has raised concerns about the security of decentralized finance (DeFi) platforms, which are largely unregulated. The stolen funds are comparable to a 2018 hack of Tokyo-based Bitcoin exchange Coincheck, which resulted in $530 million lost. The incident has sparked fears of regulators cracking down on the sector, which has seen record-breaking losses from theft, hacks, and fraud.

site_title: Regional recovery hopes could be further dampened by China curbs
summary: Southeast Asia's economic recovery hopes are fading amid a fresh coronavirus wave, with low vaccination rates and renewed lockdowns crimping economic activity. The region's economies, including the Philippines, Thailand, and Malaysia, are expected to experience downside growth risks, while Singapore remains a bright spot. The global recovery remains on track, but China's return to lockdowns and travel curbs due to the Delta variant poses significant economic risks to the world. Economists have revised downwards their full-year projections for the region's economies, citing a "cloudy patch" in the region.

site_title: Dubai Airports reports drop in H1 traffic, but expects rebound
summary: Dubai Airports reported a 41% drop in first-half passenger traffic to 10.6 million, but expects a rebound due to fewer travel restrictions and upcoming events like Expo 2020 Dubai and the Dubai Airshow. The airport is gearing up for a massive influx of visitors, particularly from the UK, after Britain lifted the UAE's travel restrictions. Dubai Airports expects to handle over 1 million passengers between August 12-22 as summer holidays end.

site_title: Companies, investors must continue adapting to megatrends amid pandemic
summary: Top CEOs emphasize the need for companies to adapt to megatrends such as climate change, urbanization, and the growth of Asia's middle class, despite the COVID-19 pandemic. GuocoLand's CEO Cheng Hsing Yao and OCBC's CEO Helen Wong discussed the importance of sustainability, green buildings, and innovative technologies in their webinars. They highlighted the need for a holistic approach to addressing these megatrends, incorporating not only environmental considerations but also social and economic aspects. Companies are advised to prioritize agility, adaptability, and resilience in managing these changes.

site_title: China Everbright Water H1 net profit rises 36% to HK$548.2 million
summary: China Everbright Water, a Singapore-listed environmental services group, reported a 36% increase in net profit to HK$548.2 million for its first half of 2021, driven by solid market expansion and steady business growth. Revenue rose 47% to HK$3.11 billion, while earnings per share increased to 19.16 Hong Kong cents. The company secured several wastewater treatment and engineering projects and declared an interim dividend of 5.75 Hong Kong cents per share.

site_title: Australian consumer sentiment at one-year low on lockdowns
summary: Australian consumer sentiment has reached a one-year low due to ongoing coronavirus lockdowns, according to the Westpac-Melbourne Institute index, which fell 4.4% in August. This marks the third drop in four months and reverses the 1.5% bounce in July. The decline is attributed to the economic setback caused by lockdowns in major cities, affecting economic recovery.

site_title: Greece counts cost as island fire 'slowly coming under control'
summary: A wildfire on the Greek island of Evia has been slowly brought under control by nearly 900 firefighters, but the island's tourism season has been severely damaged. The fire, which has raged for nine days, has scorched over 93,000 hectares of land, killing three people and leaving hundreds homeless. Authorities have pointed to climate change as a contributing factor, with the European Forest Fire Information System reporting a significant increase in burned area compared to previous years.

site_title: Climate crisis: Focus on methane, not just carbon dioxide
summary: A new UN-backed report highlights the urgent need to cut down on methane pollution, which has 80 times the heat-trapping power of carbon dioxide, to mitigate the climate crisis. Reducing methane emissions by 45% this decade could help avoid nearly 0.3 degrees of warming globally by the 2040s. The US must act, with Congress recommended to reduce methane pollution from oil and gas extraction by 90% by the end of the decade and phase out routine methane flaring.

site_title: How Cuomo's book became a cautionary tale
summary: Governor Andrew Cuomo's book manuscript was highly sought after by major publishing companies, with several companies vying for it in a frenzied auction. The book, which was expected to be a bestseller, had Cuomo's rising national profile as the man who steered New York through the coronavirus pandemic. However, the book's publication has become a cautionary tale, with the controversy surrounding Cuomo's handling of the pandemic overshadowing its potential success. The manuscript was ultimately published, but the controversy has likely impacted its sales and reception.

site_title: Thai police crack down on protest with rubber bullets, tear gas
summary: Thai police used rubber bullets and tear gas on protesters for a second day, defying a ban on public gatherings in Bangkok. Demonstrators, fueled by anger over the government's handling of the coronavirus crisis, including a slow vaccine rollout and financial hardship, gathered at Victory Monument. The protests come as Thailand reports over 21,000 new cases, its worst outbreak yet.

site_title: SICC's The New Course ready to host major golf events
summary: Singapore Island Country Club (SICC) is set to host major golf events once again, thanks to the opening of its new 27-hole The New Course, which boasts a "wow" factor. The 77-year-old Australian golf course designer Graham Marsh created the course, inspired by the 1960s and 1970s Singapore Open. The New Course features three nine-hole layouts and offers three 18-hole combinations, increasing SICC's golfing capacity by 23%. The club aims to stage major events, including the Lexus Cup and Asia-Pacific Amateur Championship, to rekindle interest in golf in Singapore.

site_title: Fed's Evans wants to see 'few more' job reports before bond taper
summary: Chicago Fed President Charles Evans expressed caution against premature tightening of monetary policy, citing the need for more job reports and certainty on price increases before the Federal Reserve begins tapering its $120 billion monthly bond purchases. Evans believes the current inflation spike is temporary and wants to see "a few more" job reports before making a decision. He also emphasized the importance of the Fed reaching its 2% inflation target and achieving maximum employment, suggesting that some years of inflation above 2% may be necessary.

site_title: Using tech to enhance the banking experience
summary: Banks must carefully evaluate their digital banking strategies to balance convenience and security in a rapidly evolving landscape. The increasing adoption of digital banking has led to higher fraud levels, particularly in Asia-Pacific, where daily transactions are on the rise. To mitigate these risks, banks must choose the right technologies, such as eKYC, biometrics, and liveness detection, that ensure customer identity verification while minimizing costs and security risks. A seamless and secure digital banking experience is crucial, and banks must prioritize simplicity, reliability, and user-friendliness to remain competitive and ahead of their adversaries.

site_title: Ikea's malls arm branches out into housing with new centre in China
summary: IKEA's shopping malls arm, Ingka Centres, has launched the sales process for 500 flats at its first-ever mixed-use retail and residential development in Changsha, China. The project, valued at over $838 million, is expected to start moving in residents in March 2022. Ingka Centres is shifting towards entertainment and social spaces, with a focus on omnichannel models and digital services, as Chinese consumers increasingly shop online. The development will feature common living and work spaces designed in cooperation with IKEA, aiming to appeal to people working from home.

site_title: COP26: Is Boris Johnson up to first big post-Brexit test?
summary: The UK is under-prepared to host the COP26 climate summit, with concerns growing about the country's ability to deliver a strong outcome. A landmark UN report warns of a "code red for humanity" due to global warming, and the UK's lack of preparedness could lead to a weak COP26 outcome and undermine this year's sustainability agenda. However, with US President Joe Biden's ambitious climate plan and diplomatic efforts to convince other countries to step up their emissions reductions, there is still a chance for the UK to demonstrate leadership and secure a positive outcome at COP26.

site_title: Consumer inflation in US moderates while remaining elevated
summary: US consumer inflation rose 0.5% in July, moderating from the previous month but remaining elevated at 5.4% from a year ago. Core CPI, excluding food and energy, increased 0.3% and 4.3% from the prior month and July 2020, respectively. Price measures of food, energy, shelter, and new vehicles contributed to the July gain, while airfares and auto insurance costs declined. Despite some easing of reopening surge, ongoing challenges such as materials shortages and hiring difficulties are expected to continue putting upward pressure on prices.

site_title: Temasek's ultra-long tenured bonds unlikely to kick-start corporate trend
summary: Temasek Holdings has issued a 50-year Singapore dollar bond with a yield of 2.8% per annum, sparking demand for longer-dated bonds in the SGD market. However, analysts believe this trend may not be adopted by average corporate companies, who are more likely to use 10- to 15-year bonds or perpetuals for financing and refinancing needs. These options offer more flexibility and are recognized as equity instruments, reducing the risk of long-term uncertainty.

site_title: HK bourse sees drop in quarterly profit as IPOs slow
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing (HKEX) reported a 7% drop in quarterly profit to HK$2.77 billion, down from HK$2.97 billion a year earlier, due to a slowdown in initial public offerings and trading. Despite this, the company's first-half profit rose 26%. HKEX's shares have gained 22% this year, outperforming the Hang Seng Index. The company's CEO, Nicolas Aguzin, stated that the macro backdrop remains challenging but the exchange remains focused on enhancing market attractiveness and driving business forward.

site_title: Hudson shoulders Franklin's demons in biopic Respect
summary: Jennifer Hudson was personally chosen by Aretha Franklin to play her in the biopic Respect, a few years before the Queen of Soul's death in 2018. Hudson shares Franklin's vocal talent and personal struggles, including a history of domestic abuse and her late son's death. The film's director, Ryan White, worked closely with Franklin to ensure the movie was a true representation of her life. Hudson's performance as Franklin received critical acclaim, bringing the legendary singer's story to the big screen.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

UOB announced plans to issue A$750 million in three-year senior unsecured floating-rate notes. Entertainment and content provider GHY Culture & Media reported a 73% decline in net profit to S$3.5 million for the six months ended June. Tourism attractions firm Straco Corp received a notice from the collective sale committee for two office units worth around S$7.5 million. Petroci Holding filed a claim against two Rex International subsidiaries, while Jiutian Chemical Group posted a record half-yearly net profit of 160.3 million yuan. Yoma Strategic reported a 2.1% growth in revenue for its third quarter.

site_title: Tailwinds giving property agencies a boost
summary: Singapore's property market is experiencing a strong rebound, with real estate agencies reporting robust earnings and property developers benefiting from buoyant demand. PropNex's net profit more than doubled to S$16.52 million in Q2 2021, driven by a 147% year-on-year surge in revenue. Transaction volumes in the private residential market and HDB resale market are also on the rise, with analysts projecting over 10,000 new homes to be sold by developers this year.

site_title: CSE Global H1 profit falls 33.3% amid volatile energy prices, US winter
summary: CSE Global's net profit declined 33.3% to S$10.1 million in the first half of 2021 due to lower revenues and favourable exchange differences. Revenue fell 8.3% to S$234.5 million, impacted by project delays and lower time and material revenues in the Americas region. The company secured a S$200 million+ pipeline of projects, with opportunities in infrastructure and digitalization.

site_title: Indies Capital bets on boom in South-east Asian unicorns with secondaries play
summary: Indies Capital Partners, a Singapore-based alternative asset manager, has launched its second fund focused on South-east Asian tech secondaries, with a first close of over 70% of its targeted $80 million fund size. The firm, which has a track record of investing in secondaries of South-east Asian startups, aims to capitalize on the growing demand for secondary shares in mature tech players. Fund II will focus on companies with valuations above $300 million, with the goal of providing intermediate liquidity to investors and offering a risk-adjusted return for limited partners.

images.alt_text: "The whole digital ecosystem in South-east Asia has a long way to go, penetration rates are still very low," says Mr Ong.

site_title: US: Dow hits record high at open after inflation data
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average hit a record high at the open on Wednesday, rising 36.22 points, or 0.10%, to 35,300.89. This follows data showing that growth in inflation appeared to have peaked in July. Economically sensitive stocks gained after the passage of an infrastructure bill, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher. The gains come despite US-EU trade talks and new Trump threats.

site_title: Deliveroo doubles orders value in first half
summary: Deliveroo reported a significant increase in the value of orders on its platform, more than doubling in the first half of 2021. Despite the easing of pandemic-related curbs in Britain, growth remained strong for both restaurant and grocery orders. CEO Will Shu attributed the growth to high consumer demand and the expansion of its consumer base, working with more food merchants than any other platform in the UK.

images.alt_text: Food delivery company Deliveroo said the value of orders on its platform more than doubled in the first half, with no material impact from the wider reopening of restaurants in its biggest market, Britain, in the second quarter.

site_title: Hackers return portion of record crypto heist haul
summary: Hackers have returned approximately $4.8 million worth of stolen cryptocurrency assets to Poly Network, a firm specializing in transferring cryptocurrency, following a record $600 million heist. The theft, considered the largest in decentralized finance history, occurred in June. Cybersecurity experts, including SlowMist, are tracking the thieves and investigating possible identity clues. The US Department of Justice and FBI have not commented on the incident, which is part of a growing trend of DeFi-related hacks, totaling $432 million in thefts this year.

site_title: US consumer prices up 0.5% in July, up 5.4% past 12 months
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.5% in July, a slower pace than in June, according to the Labor Department. Energy prices drove inflation, increasing 1.6%, while food prices rose 0.7%. Excluding volatile food and energy goods, the core CPI rose 0.3%. Over the past 12 months, consumer inflation remained at 5.4%, while the core rate slowed to 4.3%. The rate of energy price increase surged 41.8% compared to July 2020, driven by the reopening of the economy.

site_title: CDC recommends pregnant women get Covid-19 vaccine
summary: The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends that pregnant women receive the Covid-19 vaccine, citing no increased risk of miscarriage. The agency found similar miscarriage rates after vaccination as expected. Pregnant women can receive any of the three approved vaccines, and the CDC now recommends vaccination for all individuals 12 years and older, including those pregnant or breastfeeding. This guidance comes as Covid-19 cases surge across the US, with hospitals in several states running out of beds.

site_title: Air taxi maker Archer seeks US$1b in damages from Boeing-backed rival
summary: Archer Aviation, a flying taxi developer, is seeking US$1 billion in damages from Wisk Aero, a rival backed by Boeing and Google co-founder Larry Page's Kitty Hawk Corp. Wisk accused Archer of stealing trade secrets involving electric Vertical Take-Off and Landing aircraft, prompting Archer to countersue. Archer claims Wisk's actions caused "substantial damage" and plans to hold Wisk accountable despite Wisk's denial of wrongdoing. The case raises stakes in the competitive urban air mobility space, where Archer plans to launch its first electric flying taxi in 2024.

site_title: Centurion H1 net profit falls 58% to S$8.7 million on fair-value loss, lower student accommodation revenue
summary: Centurion Corp reported a 58% decline in net profit to S$8.7 million due to a fair-value loss and lower student accommodation revenue. The company expects occupancy to pick up as business and travel activities resume and vaccines are rolled out globally. Despite near-term headwinds, recovery is in sight for some of its assets.

site_title: Thai police face off again with protesters near PM's residence
summary: Thai police clashed with protesters for a second day near Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha's residence, demanding his resignation for mismanaging the country's coronavirus crisis. Hundreds of protesters threw paint and hurled objects at police, who responded with tear gas and rubber bullets. The protesters, who have been calling for Prayuth's resignation since the worsening of the pandemic, have also blocked roads with barbed wire fences and shipping containers. 48 people were arrested, and nine police officers were injured in the clashes. The protests are part of a youth-led movement seeking to topple Prayuth, who has been in power since a 2014 military coup.

site_title: Construction recovery uneven amid manpower, supply constraints
summary: Singapore's construction industry is recovering from the COVID-19 pandemic, but the recovery is uneven, with some companies experiencing significant growth while others face challenges. Construction and property group Chip Eng Seng reported a 182.2% jump in construction revenue, while Pan-United, a ready-mix concrete producer, saw a 45% increase in revenue. However, other companies, such as Wee Hur Holdings and OKP Holdings, reported net losses due to higher costs and weaker margins. Supply and skilled manpower constraints, as well as volatile tender prices, are expected to continue affecting the industry.

site_title: In-store and e-commerce have transformed into digital commerce
summary: Retail commerce has transformed into digital commerce, with in-store and online shopping blending together. This shift has empowered brands to scale globally, reach new markets, and gain market share. However, the pace of digital transformation varies across regions, with some markets witnessing a more competitive e-commerce landscape. Businesses must adapt their payment capabilities to target regions, considering their complexities and nuances. The digital transformation has empowered consumer groups, internet infrastructure, and smartphone usage in growing markets, but also poses challenges for companies to match their payment solutions to the market.

site_title: US Senate Democrats pass sweeping US$3.5t spending resolution
summary: US Senate Democrats passed a $3.5 trillion spending resolution, starting weeks of debate on President Joe Biden's top priorities, including universal preschool and affordable housing. The 50-49 vote along party lines marks a significant step forward for Democrats, who will need to craft a package that wins support from both progressives and moderates. The resolution follows a bipartisan $1 trillion infrastructure bill passed earlier, and Democrats plan to push the package through using the "budget reconciliation" process, with the House expected to consider it on August 23.

site_title: Ivory Coast's national oil company files claim against Rex International units
summary: Ivory Coast's national oil company, Petroci Holding, has filed a claim against two subsidiaries of Singapore-based Rex International: Rex Oman Limited and Masirah Oil (MOL). The claim, filed in the British Virgin Islands, alleges conduct by MOL that led to a dilution of Petroci's interest in the company. Rex International denies the claims, calling them "frivolous, baseless and unmeritorious," and says there will be no material financial impact.

site_title: Samsung unveils new foldable smartphones with lower prices to expand market
summary: Samsung unveiled new foldable smartphones, the Galaxy Z Fold3 and Z Flip3, with lower prices, starting at $1,799.99 and $999.99, respectively. The devices feature 7.6-inch main screens, improved design, durability, and compatibility with a stylus. The price drop aims to expand foldable demand beyond niche devices. Foldable phones are expected to account for 0.6% of total smartphone shipments this year, up from 0.06% in 2020, with Samsung leading the market with 88% market share.

site_title: Cathay Pacific's dire run eases as H1 losses narrow from year earlier
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways reported a net loss of HK$7.6 billion (S$1.32 billion) in the first half of 2021, narrowing from a HK$9.9 billion deficit in the same period last year. The airline attributed the improvement to cost cuts, including slashing jobs and pay, as well as cargo operations. Despite a 43% drop in sales, Cathay aims to reach 30% of pre-Covid capacity by the end of the year and lower its average monthly operating cash burn to less than HK$1 billion. Analysts remain cautious, citing uncertainty over travel demand due to ongoing border restrictions and the Delta variant.

site_title: KTL to import seafood into Singapore; eyes lab-grown diamond foray
summary: KTL Global, a Singapore-based company, has signed a three-year strategic collaboration agreement with three companies to enter the lab-grown diamond industry. The company will also import 120 containers of fish and seafood annually into Singapore under a separate agreement with China-based QuanYing Technology. KTL aims to diversify its food supply and enhance food security in Singapore. The company's shares closed at 11.6 Singapore cents last Friday after requesting a trading halt earlier this week.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's GDP grew 14.7% year on year in the second quarter, surpassing preliminary estimates. The country's non-oil domestic exports are expected to grow 7-8% for the full year, marking its best performance since 2017. Fixed asset investment commitments reached S$3.6 billion in Q2, with manufacturing investments accounting for the largest share. Global sovereign wealth funds, including GIC and Temasek, saw significant growth. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.85% in the latest session.

site_title: Prudential new business profit jumps 25%, outlook uncertain
summary: Prudential, a British insurer, reported a 25% increase in half-year new business profit to $1.18 billion, driven by digital operations. Despite a cautious outlook due to vaccination programme uncertainty and short-term economic fluctuations, the company expects a gradual return to normal economic patterns. Prudential will pay a first interim dividend of 5.37 cents per share and is considering a global equity offering of $2.5-3.0 billion.

site_title: Moya's H1 profit up 23%
summary: Moya Holdings Asia posted a 23% increase in net profit to S$20.4 million for the six months ended June 2021, driven by revenue growth of 8% to S$125.4 million. The company's earnings per share rose to 0.48 Singapore cents, while its net asset value per share stood at 7.95 Singapore cents. Moya will focus on organic growth of its PT Moya Tangerang unit and expand through new tenders and mergers and acquisitions.

site_title: Thailand to start human trials on Covid-19 shots via nasal spray
summary: Thailand is set to begin human trials on COVID-19 nasal spray vaccines by the end of this year, following promising results in mouse trials. The vaccines, developed by the National Center for Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology, will test protection against the Delta variant. The trials will be followed by second-phase trials in March next year and production is targeted for mid-2022, pending approval from the food and drug regulator.

site_title: Chesapeake to buy Blackstone-controlled shale gas driller for US$2.2b
summary: Chesapeake Energy agreed to acquire Vine Energy, a shale gas driller controlled by Blackstone Group, for $2.2 billion. The deal values Vine at $15 per share and increases Chesapeake's Haynesville position. The acquisition is part of the US shale sector's trend of consolidation to achieve cost savings and boost dividends. Chesapeake, which emerged from bankruptcy earlier this year, aims to scale up and compete with its largest domestic rival, EQT. The deal is seen as strategic, with analysts citing the combined acreage footprints of both companies.

site_title: 61 new locally transmitted Covid-19 cases; 17 unlinked
summary: There were 61 new locally transmitted Covid-19 cases reported in Singapore on August 11, with 17 unlinked cases. Three seniors aged above 70 with unvaccinated or partially vaccinated status are at risk of serious illness. The total number of cases in Singapore is now 65,951, with two imported cases detected and isolated upon arrival.

site_title: Pines club members appeal against S$1,500 award in class action on Peter Kwee and Co
summary: The Pines club members have appealed against a High Court judgement awarding them S$1,500 each in a class action lawsuit against Peter Kwee's company and Exklusiv Resorts over the relocation of the clubhouse. The appeal seeks to overturn dismissal of claims against Kwee and Exklusiv Resorts for alleged deceit and negligence. The court ruled that Exklusiv Resorts breached contract by relocating the clubhouse, and the plaintiffs will pay 35% of the defendants' legal fees.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close higher for a third straight day
summary: Hong Kong shares rose for a third straight day, with the Hang Seng Index gaining 0.20% to 26,660.16, driven by bargain-buyers following a recent sell-off. Investors monitored US inflation data, while Asian markets edged up.

site_title: Jiutian Chemical posts record H1 earnings of 160.3m yuan
summary: Jiutian Chemical Group reported a record half-yearly net profit of 160.3 million yuan (S$33.6 million), up 356% year-over-year, driven by strong demand for its main products, dimethylformamide (DMF) and methylamine. Revenue rose 86.5% to 887.2 million yuan. The company attributed the growth to China's post-pandemic economic recovery. However, the second half of the year may be affected by severe flooding and production plant closures. Jiutian Chemical plans to expand its production capacity with a 100,000-tonne methylamine plant.

site_title: US calls on Opec and its allies to pump more oil
summary: US President Joe Biden's administration is pressuring Opec and its allies to boost oil output to combat rising gasoline prices, a threat to global economic recovery. The US calls for more competitive markets, warning that unchecked high prices risk harming the recovery. The administration also directed the Federal Trade Commission to investigate potential illegal practices contributing to higher US gasoline prices. The push comes as Opec+ has been gradually easing a record output cut since 2020, and international benchmark Brent crude is trading at nearly a third higher than the beginning of the year.

site_title: Straco's office units in International Plaza, set for collective sale, valued above book
summary: Straco Corp, the owner of the Singapore Flyer, has received a collective sale notice from International Plaza Singapore, where it owns two office units valued at around S$7.5 million, quadruple its carrying value. The units span 4,218 square feet and are part of a 50-storey development with 962 units. The collective sale, which involves 791 units, represents 80.33% of the total share value and 83.58% of the total strata area, may be Singapore's largest collective sale in history.

site_title: Uneven recovery as manpower, supply constraints weigh on construction sector
summary: The construction sector in Singapore is experiencing uneven recovery due to manpower and supply constraints. Companies like Chip Eng Seng and Pan-United reported significant revenue growth, while peers Wee Hur and OKP Holdings reported net losses. Suppliers like Union Steel and BRC Asia also saw revenue increases, but at a slower pace than expected. Experts attribute the mixed results to the industry's struggles with labor shortages and disrupted global supply chains, with construction costs and tender prices expected to remain volatile for the rest of the year.

site_title: 69-year-old unvaccinated Singaporean dies from Covid-19; three new clusters
summary: A 69-year-old unvaccinated Singaporean died from complications due to Covid-19, marking the 43rd death in the country. The man, who developed symptoms on July 28, was admitted to Tan Tock Seng Hospital and tested positive for the coronavirus. This new case is part of three new Covid-19 clusters in Singapore.

site_title: GHY Culture & Media posts S$3.5m net profit, down 73%
summary: GHY Culture & Media reported a 73% decline in net profit to S$3.5 million for the six months ended June 2021, down from S$13.0 million in the same period last year. Group revenue rose 18% to S$43.8 million. Earnings per share decreased to 0.32 Singapore cents, down from 1.43 cents.

site_title: STI falls 0.85% as traders snub upbeat macro data
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 27.36 points, or 0.85%, to 3,180.00 on Wednesday, despite upbeat macro data showing Singapore's GDP rose 14.7% in the second quarter. Investors took profits, mainly in banking stocks, amid concerns over the Delta variant and US Federal Reserve's tightening timeline. Major Asian gauges closed mixed, while the US market edged to fresh records.

site_title: Vicom H1 net profit up 23.7% to S$12m
summary: Vicom, a vehicle inspection company, reported a 23.7% increase in first-half net profit to S$12 million for the six months ended June 2021. The company's group revenue rose 23.4% to S$49.2 million, driven by a strong second quarter and reduced lockdowns compared to the previous year. Vicom declared an interim dividend of 3.04 cents per share, with a payout ratio of 90%. The company's results were released after trading hours on Wednesday.

site_title: JTC awards Gul Avenue tender for S$3.47m to Sing Teck Leong Marketing & Resources
summary: JTC has awarded the tender for the industrial site at Gul Avenue (Plot D) to Sing Teck Leong Marketing & Resources Pte Ltd for S$3.47 million. The site has a 20-year tenure, 5,832.6 sqm site area, and a gross plot ratio of 1.4, zoned "Business 2". The project completion period is 60 months.

site_title: Picasso's leaving Las Vegas for auction block
summary: MGM Resorts is auctioning 11 Picasso paintings and works in October at the Bellagio hotel in Las Vegas, with a potential sale value of $100 million. The collection, which includes modern pieces by Bob Dylan and David Hockney, was started by real estate developer Steve Wynn over 20 years ago. The auction features five paintings, including a 1938 piece valued at $20-30 million, and large-scale portraits with presale estimates of $30-15 million. The sale aims to diversify the collection and give a greater voice to under-represented artists.

site_title: Geo Energy revenue grows 37% on higher coal prices and demand
summary: Geo Energy Resources reported a 37% increase in revenue to US$220.3 million for the first six months of 2021, driven by higher coal sales volume and prices. The average Indonesian Coal Index price rose to US$47.78 per tonne, up from US$30.61 the previous year. This growth is attributed to increased demand and higher prices, resulting in a record revenue for the company.

site_title: HSBC Singapore expands services for mass affluent clients to their kids living abroad
summary: HSBC Singapore has expanded services for its mass affluent clients, including their children living abroad, with no minimum balance requirement. HSBC Premier customers' immediate family can now access international mortgage services, forex conversion services, and relationship manager support in destination countries for their children aged 18-30 in Australia. This move aims to support clients' children who may face difficulties returning home due to travel restrictions.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 7.71 points to 1,504.44 on Wednesday, driven by higher volumes. The index saw 654 losers compared to 433 gainers. This marks a positive day for Malaysian stocks, despite the overall market uncertainty.

site_title: Looming high base not expected to deter rebound in Singapore's exports in 2021
summary: Singapore's export sector outperformed expectations in the first half of 2021, with non-oil domestic exports (NODX) growing 7-8% year-on-year, leading to forecast upgrades and a projected full-year growth of 8%. This growth was driven by a 9.9% increase in the first six months, with electronics and petrochemicals contributing to the surge. However, economists warn of a slower second half due to regional Covid-19 outbreaks, supply-side bottlenecks, and US-China tensions.

site_title: Global state-owned investors' AUM hits US$30t; GIC and Temasek lead growth
summary: State-owned investors' assets under management (AUM) have reached an all-time high of $30 trillion, driven by a rally in global stocks and bonds. Singapore's GIC and Temasek Holdings led the growth, with estimated gains of 37.5% and 24.5%, respectively. Global SWF predicts the SOI industry will reach $50 trillion by 2030, with funds increasingly investing in domestic markets and shifting from "imposed investments" to "opportunistic deals" as economies recover.

site_title: Australia: Shares end at record high as CBA boosts financials
summary: Australian stocks closed at a record high on Wednesday, driven by Commonwealth Bank of Australia's (CBA) announcement of a 20% profit jump and a record $4.41 billion share buyback. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.3% to 7,584.6, with miners and the "big four" lenders also gaining. The financial sub-index hit a four-year high, and investors await earnings results from National Australia Bank and Westpac.

site_title: Wilmar proposes S$0.05 dividend per share as H1 profit grows 23%
summary: Wilmar International reported a 23% increase in its first-half net profit to US$750.9 million, driven by better performance in its feed and industrial products segments. The company proposed a dividend of S$0.05 per share, its highest interim dividend since listing. Revenue grew 30.4% to US$29.53 billion, mainly due to higher commodity prices and increased sales volume. Wilmar's chairman and CEO, Kuok Khoon Hong, attributed the results to satisfactory performance despite challenging operating conditions.

site_title: WeWork launches drive to support South-east Asia's startup ecosystem
summary: WeWork has launched its Growth Campus initiative in Singapore and other South-east Asian cities, providing US$8 million in investment and support to the startup ecosystem. The initiative offers subsidized workspace, virtual mentoring, and education to start-ups and scale-ups, aiming to enhance productivity, collaboration, and creativity. WeWork's goal is to help startups grow and kickstart the sector as the region's economic recovery evolves, with the initiative open to start-ups, accelerators, investors, and corporates with innovation agendas.

site_title: BT's Top Stories from Last Week
summary: Keppel offers to privatize Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) at S$3.4 billion, contingent on a media business carve-out. Rising HDB resale prices pose challenges, while OCBC reports a 59% increase in Q2 net profit. Grab posts a US$111m negative Ebitda in Q1 and a US$652m net loss. Director Lim Huey Ching is charged with obstructing justice in the Hin Leong Trading collapse. China's GDP growth is set to slow, raising pressure on policymakers, and Citigroup sets a target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026.

site_title: Singapore is top destination for overseas real estate investments in H1: report
summary: Singapore's real estate market saw a 97% increase in overseas investments in the first half of 2021, reaching $4.7 billion. This surpasses previous records, with more than half of the capital coming from cross-border investors, making Singapore the top destination for overseas investments for the first time.

images.alt_text: RCA noted a widening gap between top and bottom quartile central business district (CBD) office pricing in the region which it said was reflective of a divergence in investor preferences.

site_title: Canadian Michael Spavor jailed for 11 years in China on spying charges
summary: Canadian businessman Michael Spavor was jailed for 11 years by a Chinese court on spying charges, in a case deemed politically motivated by Ottawa. Spavor was detained in 2018 along with fellow Canadian Michael Kovrig, who is also awaiting trial. The verdict comes as relations between Canada and China are at a low point, with China accusing Canada of politicizing cases. The sentencing follows a day after another Canadian citizen received a death sentence for a drug smuggling conviction.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end higher on earnings, rising US yields
summary: Japanese shares closed higher for a fourth straight session, driven by strong earnings from Bridgestone and other firms. The Nikkei share average rose 0.65% to 28,070.51, while the broader Topix gained 0.92% to 1,954.08. Rising US bond yields also supported banking stocks. However, Softbank Group fell 1.76% after its earnings announcement, citing uncertainty over China's regulatory environment.

site_title: Parcel Perform raises US$20m from Cambridge Capital, SoftBank Ventures Asia and others
summary: Parcel Perform, a Singapore-based startup, has raised US$20 million in a Series A round led by Cambridge Capital and SoftBank Ventures Asia. The funding will be used to build technology offerings, expand its AI solutions, and establish a regional headquarters in North America. The company manages over 100 million parcel-tracking updates daily and has integrated with more than 700 carriers worldwide. Revenue has grown five times since the COVID-19 pandemic, with brands such as Nespresso and Decathlon Group using its software-as-a-service platform. The company plans to grow its staff size to 150 by year-end.

site_title: Ravi Thakran's Turmeric Capital latest to weigh Singapore SPAC listing
summary: Three companies, including Turmeric Capital led by former L Catterton Asia head Ravi Thakran, are exploring SPAC listings in Singapore, potentially among the first to list a blank-cheque company in the city-state. Turmeric Capital is working with advisers to raise about S$300 million, with Mr. Thakran as chairman and CEO. The Singapore Exchange has closed its market consultation for SPAC listings, with the framework undergoing regulatory approval, and proposed requirements include a minimum S$300 million market capitalization threshold.

site_title: Australia extends Covid-19 lockdown in Melbourne for seven days
summary: Australia's lockdown in Melbourne has been extended for seven days until August 19 as authorities combat the highly infectious Delta variant. Victoria state Premier Daniel Andrews stated that opening the lockdown would lead to a surge in cases similar to those in Sydney. The decision aims to prevent a rapid spread of the virus.

site_title: Europe: Stocks open higher after Asia, US gains
summary: European stocks rose at the open, following gains in Asia and fresh records on Wall Street. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.4%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 rose 0.1%, and Paris' CAC 40 climbed 0.3%. The US paved the way for its $1.2-trillion infrastructure project, leading to fresh records on the Dow and S&P 500. Asian markets also gained, as investors brushed off new Trump threats.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher, extending rallies on Wall Street
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, extending Wall Street's rally, despite thin trade due to summer holidays. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.66% and the Topix index gained 0.66%, reaching 28,071.09 and 1,949.06 respectively. Investors took heart from fresh records on Wall Street, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to new highs despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Australian consumer sentiment at one-year low on lockdowns
summary: Australian consumer sentiment reached a one-year low in August, falling 4.4% due to coronavirus lockdowns in three major cities. The Westpac-Melbourne Institute index, which measures consumer sentiment, is down 30.9% from August last year. Despite the decline, optimists still outnumber pessimists, but the margin is narrowing. The drop marks the third decline in four months, hindering economic recovery.

site_title: Over 4,900 HDB BTO flats launched, including in Queenstown, Jurong East for the first time in a decade
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) launched 4,989 Build-To-Order (BTO) flats across seven projects in five estates, with prices starting from S$237,000 for a three-room flat and S$1.07 million for a five-room unit. The Queenstown project, Queen's Arc, offers 610 three-room and four-room flats with prices starting from S$382,000 and S$540,000, respectively. The long waiting time for these flats is mainly due to additional preparation works required for the site.

site_title: Asia: Markets up as traders weigh recovery, eyes on US inflation
summary: Asian markets rose as investors weighed the impact of the Delta variant and the future of Federal Reserve financial support, despite concerns about a prolonged pandemic recovery. The US$1.2 trillion infrastructure spending bill passed the Senate, but its passage through the House is uncertain due to partisan differences. The Dow and S&P 500 ended at new record highs, and investors remain upbeat about the economy's eventual recovery, despite rising new infections. The release of US inflation data later in the day may influence the Fed's decision on tapering its bond-buying program.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares start lower on Wednesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.43% lower on Wednesday, following a tepid lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index fell to 26,491.74, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also decreased. The decline comes as profit-takers moved in after a two-day run-up, with investors now focusing on US inflation data later in the day.

site_title: South Korea adopts electronic travel authorisation to stave off infectious disease
summary: South Korea is implementing an electronic travel authorisation (ETA) system for overseas visitors starting September 1, as a long-term measure to prevent infectious diseases and limit undocumented immigrants. The system requires travellers to share their previous two weeks of travel history and will enable a prompt entry ban on certain countries in case of an outbreak. The system, which will be the fifth in the world, will initially be available for visitors from 49 countries, including the US, UK, and France. The system aims to reduce customs and processing times for travellers and is expected to be efficient in preventing the spread of diseases.

images.alt_text: South Korea is implementing for the first time an electronic travel authorisation (ETA) system for overseas visitors from September, as the Covid-19 pandemic forces open the way for a policy previously opposed by the country's tourism industry.

site_title: Cathay Pacific posts narrower H1 loss as costs fall
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways reported a narrower first-half loss of HK$7.57 billion, down from HK$9.87 billion last year, due to cost-cutting measures and strong air cargo demand. Revenue fell 42.7% to HK$15.85 billion. The airline expects to reduce its monthly cash burn in the second half as rules ease and passenger capacity rises. A full-year loss of HK$9.85 billion is predicted, representing an improvement from the prior year.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks finish lower on virus anxiety
summary: South Korean stocks fell for a fifth straight day, with the Kospi index dropping 0.70% to 3,220.62. The decline was driven by concerns over a potential decline in chip prices and a record high in domestic Covid-19 cases, which rose to over 2,200 new cases. Tech giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix fell 2.12% and 6.22% respectively, while LG Chem and Naver also dropped. Foreigners were net sellers of 1,603 billion won worth of shares, with the Kospi up 12.08% this year but down 1.3% in the previous 30 trading sessions.

site_title: Temasek's ultra-long tenured bonds unlikely to kick-start corporate trend: analysts
summary: Temasek's 50-year Singapore dollar bond, priced at 2.8% yield, has sparked demand for longer-dated SGD bonds in the market. However, analysts believe it won't kickstart a trend among corporate companies. DBS global head of fixed income Clifford Lee noted that the bond issue satisfies the investment needs of real money accounts. The successful issue demonstrates robust investor appetite for longer-dated bonds in the SGD market, but it's unlikely to prompt a shift towards longer tenures among corporations.

site_title: Singapore is fourth-most expensive market to build in Asia due to skills shortage, high materials costs: survey
summary: Singapore's construction market is the fourth-most expensive in Asia, driven by a skills shortage and high materials costs, according to a survey. Tender prices are expected to rise 10-15% this year, with construction output rising marginally by 5% in Q1 2021. Labour costs have increased due to the lack of skilled labour, with significant rises in mechanical and electrical works. The public sector is expected to lead construction demand, with more than 60% of awarded contracts coming from the public sector.

site_title: China Everbright Water H1 net profit rises 36% to HK$548.2m
summary: China Everbright Water, a mainboard-listed environmental services group, reported a 36% rise in net profit to HK$548.2 million for its first half ended June 30, 2021. Revenue rose 47% to HK$3.11 billion. The company secured four wastewater treatment projects and one reusable water project, and declared an interim dividend of 5.75 cents per share, up from 3.74 cents a year ago. Shares closed at 25.5 Singapore cents, up 8.51%. The company aims to improve its intelligence and digitalization level, ensure project quality, and drive technological innovation.

site_title: Rising asset risks on virus surge, but credit strength to remain intact for Asean, Indian banks: report
summary: Asean and Indian banks face rising asset risks due to new coronavirus infections and low vaccination rates. However, strong loss-absorbing buffers, policy support, and focused virus impact will maintain credit strength. India's economy is expected to return to growth in fiscal 2022, while Vietnam, Malaysia, and Singapore will benefit from resuming global economic activity. Divergent economic growth due to pandemic scarring is expected, but robust trade within Asia and growing young populations in economies like India and Indonesia will support banks' profitability. Governments' ability to support domestic labor markets will be crucial.

site_title: Yoma Q3 revenue up 2.1%; flags 'severe impact' on business from third Covid-19 wave in Myanmar
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings reported a 2.1% year-over-year growth in revenue to US$19.6 million for the third quarter ended June 2021, driven by strength in property sales. However, the company warned that new Covid-19 measures in Myanmar will have a "severe impact" on its business, particularly in its food and beverage, and motor segments. Revenue from its property segment rose 30.9% to US$8.9 million, while financial services, F&B, and motor segments contracted.

site_title: Economists' forecasts for Singapore's 2021 growth fall within upgraded official range
summary: Singapore's official full-year growth forecast for 2021 has been upgraded to 6-7%, within the range of economists' forecasts, according to the Ministry of Trade and Industry. Manufacturing is expected to remain the key driver of growth, with the sector's output up 17.7% year-on-year. The recovery is still stabilizing, and monetary policy is expected to remain on hold at the next meeting in October. The upgraded forecast takes into account the better-than-expected first-half performance and latest external and domestic economic developments.

site_title: UOB to issue A$750m in floating rate notes due May 2024 in Sydney, priced at 100.3%
summary: UOB is issuing A$750 million in floating rate notes due May 2024, priced at 100.3% of the principal amount. The notes will be combined with an existing series worth A$250 million, also due in May 2024. ANZ has been appointed as the sole lead manager and book runner for the notes, which are expected to be rated Aa1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by Standard & Poor's Rating Services.

site_title: Commonwealth Bank reports surge in profits
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia reported a 19% surge in full-year profits, reaching A$8.65 billion, driven by the country's economic rebound after pandemic lockdowns. The bank cut provisions for loan losses and announced a A$6 billion share buyback and increased its final shareholder dividend. Despite a prolonged Sydney lockdown expected to cost the economy billions, economists predict at least one quarter of negative growth. The bank's CEO, Matt Comyn, emphasized the need for ongoing economic support and preparedness for different economic scenarios.

site_title: Rex International unit acquires 20% interest in two North Sea exploration licences
summary: Rex International's subsidiary, Lime Petroleum, has acquired a 20% stake in two North Sea exploration licences, PL867 and PL867B, pending regulatory approval. The acquisition is part of Rex's efforts to build up its reserves and resources portfolio. Exploratory drilling is expected to commence in late-2022, targeting a large prospect called Gjegnalunden. Lime also signed a call option for a 20% farm-in to licence PL1041, which could begin drilling in November this year if exercised before October 1, 2021.

site_title: Singapore ups trade forecasts again as Q2 non-oil exports surge by better-than-expected 10.1%
summary: Singapore has upgraded its trade forecasts for the third time this year, citing strong second-quarter growth in sectors such as electronics and petrochemicals. Non-oil domestic exports (NODX) are expected to grow by 7-8% year on year, while total merchandise trade is tipped to expand by 13-14%. The upward revision is attributed to better-than-expected growth in NODX, higher oil prices, and robust global semiconductor demand.

site_title: Chinese tech firms 'self-correct' to get ahead of potential regulatory fury
summary: Chinese tech firms are "self-correcting" to avoid potential regulatory fury, imposing restrictions or exiting businesses before authorities take action. KE Holdings, China's largest real estate platform, shut down VIP services without regulatory pressure, while Tencent Holdings introduced new limits on kids' time spent on its popular video game. The trend is driven by the government's emphasis on promoting socialist values and reinining capitalist expansion. Companies are aligning strategies with government priorities, and "self-correction" is becoming a major corporate trend in China.

images.alt_text: This year it quietly shut down its VIP services that promised fast-turnarounds for property sellers in exchange for exclusive listings and which had featured prominently on its popular Lianjia and Beike apps, two people familiar with the matter said.

site_title: Singapore stocks little changed at Wednesday's open; STI dips 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% or 7.39 points to 3,199.97 at 9:03am on Wednesday, despite a strong second-quarter growth in sectors like electronics and petrochemicals. The country's official growth forecast for 2021 has been upgraded to 6-7% from 4-6%. Healthcare providers Healthway Medical and Thomson Medical Group saw significant gains, while Ntegrator International and local banks fell. The global market was influenced by the US Dow and S&P 500 closing at new highs, and European shares extended gains to record highs.

site_title: TikTok tops Facebook as most downloaded app of 2020
summary: TikTok surpassed Facebook as the world's most downloaded app in 2020, according to market tracker App Annie. Despite efforts by former US President Donald Trump to ban it, TikTok's popularity surged, driven by its short-form videos and 1 billion global users. The app's climb to the top spot was despite US President Joe Biden revoking executive orders seeking to ban TikTok and Chinese-owned WeChat due to national security concerns. TikTok's popularity prompted Facebook-owned Instagram to add video features, while the app continues to expand its features, including longer video posts.

site_title: Hong Kong bourse operator's profit rises 26% on trading volume boost
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEX) reported a 26% rise in first-half profit to HK$6.61 billion, driven by increased trading volume and high market volatility. Trading volume rose 60% year-over-year, with record highs through the stock connect scheme linking Hong Kong with Shanghai and Shenzhen. HKEX ranked third globally for initial public offerings in the first half, with 48 companies raising $30.2 billion. The company attributed the growth to a string of Chinese listings and market volatility.

site_title: Centurion H1 net profit falls 58% on decline in student accommodation revenue
summary: Centurion Corp, a mainboard-listed company operating purpose-built worker and student accommodation, reported a 58% decline in net profit to S$8.7 million for the half year ended June 30, due to a fair-value loss of S$14.5 million on its properties. However, the company's PBWA segment saw a 7% rise in revenue year on year, while its PBSA segment fell 25% year on year due to travel restrictions. Despite the challenges, Centurion believes occupancy is expected to pick up as business and travel activities resume and vaccines are rolled out globally.

site_title: Singapore secured S$3.6b in fixed asset investment commitments in Q2
summary: Singapore secured S$3.6 billion in fixed asset investment (FAI) and S$1.4 billion in total business expenditure (TBE) in Q2, according to the Economic Survey of Singapore. Manufacturing investments accounted for the largest share of FAI, with electronics and biomedical manufacturing contributing S$1.3 billion and S$603 million respectively. US investors contributed more than half of total FAI, while services clusters attracted the highest amount of TBE commitments. The investments are expected to generate S$3.6 billion of value-added and create over 5,900 jobs in the coming years.

site_title: Boeing 737 MAX test plane takes flight in China: Flightradar24
summary: A Boeing 737 MAX test plane took to the skies in China, marking the first test flight of the model in the country after a nearly two-and-a-half-year regulatory grounding. The 737 MAX 7 test plane departed Shanghai's Pudong International Airport, with no destination listed, after refuelling stops in Seattle, Honolulu, and Guam. This flight is a significant step towards Boeing's goal of ending the regulatory grounding in China, a key travel market. The test flight's success is seen as a positive development for Boeing's efforts to regain market share.

site_title: Amazon loses bid to stop New York from probing Covid-19 standards
summary: A federal judge dismissed Amazon's lawsuit to block New York's attorney general from investigating the online retailer's COVID-19 standards. US District Judge Brian Cogan ruled that the state has a legitimate interest in ensuring employers comply with labor laws and health safety measures. Attorney General Letitia James has accused Amazon of prioritizing profits over safety and improperly disciplining employees who protested working conditions. The case is ongoing in state court, with James seeking a court-appointed safety monitor.

site_title: Oil up 3%; forecast for better US fuel demand feeds rebound
summary: Oil prices rose 3% on Tuesday, rebounding from recent losses, as forecasted US fuel demand for the year suggests a rebound. Brent crude rose to $70.63 a barrel and US oil to $68.29 a barrel. Despite a surge in COVID-19 cases in the US, job growth and increasing mobility boosted petrol consumption, with US petrol consumption expected to average 8.8 million barrels per day in 2021. A US$1 trillion infrastructure package passed by the Senate could further boost demand for oil products.

site_title: Facebook shuts down vaccine disinformation 'laundromat'
summary: Facebook has shut down a disinformation operation dubbed a "laundromat" that spread Covid-19 vaccine hoaxes through social media influencers. The operation, orchestrated by marketing firm Fazze in Russia, targeted India, Latin America, and the US. Facebook removed 65 accounts and banned Fazze, and the campaign's efforts were largely unsuccessful, with few signatures on petitions and minimal engagement on social media posts. The shutdown serves as a warning to users to verify information and do their own research, according to Facebook's global threat intelligence lead.

site_title: Ntegrator International receives statutory demand for S$177,000 in unpaid fees
summary: Ntegrator International, a CATALIST-listed communications network specialist, received a statutory demand for S$177,432.06 from its previous sponsor, Asian Corporate Advisors, for unpaid fees related to various services including an annual general meeting, acquisition, and placement of shares. The company disputes the alleged fees and is seeking legal advice to determine its next course of action, with shares closing at 1.2 Singapore cents on Tuesday, down 0.1 cent or 7.7%. If the demand is not paid within three weeks, the sponsor may commence winding-up proceedings against the company.

site_title: Messi signs two-year deal with PSG
summary: Lionel Messi has signed a two-year contract with Paris Saint-Germain, with an option for a third year, after leaving Barcelona after 21 years. The 34-year-old Argentine forward, who was a free agent, has agreed to a deal worth 35 million euros per year. Messi will join a PSG attack featuring Neymar and Kylian Mbappe, and will wear the number 30 jersey. The signing is seen as a major coup for PSG, who are chasing the Champions League title.

site_title: New Zealand central bank to get new governance board after legislative changes
summary: New Zealand's central bank, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand, will have a new statutory governance board starting mid-2022 following legislative changes. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand Bill, passed in Parliament, replaces outdated parts of the RBNZ Act 1989. The new board will be responsible for decision-making except for monetary policy, and the Governor will remain chair of the Monetary Policy Committee. Finance Minister Grant Robertson said the legislation will make New Zealand's financial system "fit for purpose."

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 end at records as infrastructure bill advances
summary: US stocks ended at fresh records on Tuesday as the Senate approved a $1.2 trillion infrastructure package, sending the Dow and S&P 500 up 0.5% and 0.1% respectively. Industrial companies and commodities producers advanced, with Caterpillar, US Steel, and Alcoa benefiting from the expected business from the infrastructure push. The passage of the bill helped offset concerns about the Delta variant of Covid-19 and a make-or-break vote in the House of Representatives looms.

site_title: PropNex Q2 net profit more than doubles to S$16.5m
summary: PropNex, a Singapore-based real estate agency, reported a net profit of S$16.5 million for the second quarter, more than doubling from the year-ago period. Revenue jumped 147.2% to S$260.5 million, driven by higher commission income from agency services and project marketing services. The company declared an interim dividend of 5.5 Singapore cents per share, the highest since its listing. Earnings per share rose to 4.46 Singapore cents, more than doubling from 1.96 cents in the year-ago period.

site_title: WHO urges power players to end 'disgraceful' jab inequity
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has urged the 20 leaders with power to address the "disgraceful" global imbalance in Covid-19 vaccine access, urging them to increase vaccine coverage in poorer nations by the end of September. The WHO aims for 10% vaccination coverage in every country by September, 40% by the end of the year, and 70% by mid-2022. The organization has been critical of rich countries hoarding vaccine supply while developing nations struggle to immunize their most vulnerable populations, with nearly 4.5 billion vaccine doses administered worldwide, but a stark disparity in access.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, rising 5.72 points, or 0.38%, to 1,502.45. The market saw a significant volume of 472.96 million lots worth RM224.03 million, with 304 gainers and 204 losers.

site_title: Sabana Reit's dissident unitholders were right to fight its manager, but it's time to make peace
summary: Sabana Reit's dissident unitholders, Quarz Capital Management and Black Crane Capital, are calling for a truce with the Reit's manager after a year of conflict. The two unitholders initially opposed a merger with ESR-Reit due to concerns over a potential discount to book value, but the market value of Sabana Reit's units has risen 25% since the deal was put to a vote. Quarz and Black Crane are now demanding that the manager extract value from the Reit's property portfolio and seeking to appoint independent directors. The conflict may hinder the Reit's ability to move forward, but the rise in market value may reduce the likelihood of unitholders being "ripped off" in a merger deal.

site_title: Google employees who work permanently from home may get pay cut
summary: Google employees who switch to permanent remote work may experience pay cuts, especially those with long commutes, due to a location-based pay structure. A company pay calculator shows varying pay cuts ranging from 5% to 25% depending on the location. Long commuters, such as those from nearby counties to major cities, may see significant pay cuts. Google claims to pay employees at 100% of their prior wage, but critics argue that this doesn't account for the impact on families and the cost of living.

images.alt_text: A Google employee living in Stamford, Connecticut will be paid 15% less if she works from home, while a colleague from the same New York City office who lives in New York City will see no cut from working from home.

site_title: Singapore's 2021 growth forecast upgraded to between 6-7%
summary: Singapore's economic growth forecast for 2021 has been upgraded to 6-7%, up from 4-6%, according to the Ministry of Trade and Industry. The country's GDP grew 14.7% year-on-year in the second quarter, driven by strong growth in manufacturing and construction sectors. Despite this, the economy remains 0.6% below pre-pandemic levels. The upgraded forecast takes into account better-than-expected performance in the first half of the year and ongoing vaccination efforts. The economy is expected to continue recovering gradually, with outward-oriented sectors like manufacturing and finance expected to see stronger growth, while consumer-facing sectors may recover more slowly.

site_title: Higher share of loss-making deals in resale homes in June after heightened Covid-19 curbs disrupt market
summary: Singapore's resale property market saw a spike in loss-making deals in June, rising to 13.8% after a record low of 10.5% in May, due to tightened Covid-19 curbs and restricted home viewings. The share of loss-making transactions eased from 14% in March and 12.2% in April. Experts attribute the increase to sellers becoming more flexible on pricing to close deals quickly. The market is expected to remain volatile, with the potential for further fluctuations in the coming months.

site_title: Peeling off the greenwashing label
summary: Investors in Asia's ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) funds face a risk of "greenwashing" where funds mislead with their marketing, rebranding portfolios as socially responsible investing. A study by the Singapore Management University found that 21% of hedge funds endorsing the United Nations' Principles for Responsible Investment (PRI) have inadequately low ESG exposure, underperforming high-ESG signatories and non-signatory hedge funds. To avoid greenwashing, investors should assess fund managers by their track record, ESG focus, and ability to influence underlying companies. DBS Private Bank recommends evaluating fund factsheets and marketing materials, and considers funds with BBB ratings and above as holding a higher level of ESG principles.

site_title: Europe: Record streak keeps rolling as investors cheer earnings
summary: European stocks reached record highs for a seventh consecutive session, with the Stoxx 600 index gaining 0.4% to an all-time high of 472.95 points.
