The deal follows increased regulatory scrutiny and a trend of Australian firms simplifying their operations. Westpac expects an after-tax accounting loss of about A$1.3 billion on the sale, with the transaction expected to be completed in the second half of 2022. The sale will add about 12 basis points to Westpac's Level 2 Common Equity Tier 1 capital ratio.

site_title: Australian PM's popularity slumps amid Covid lockdowns
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison's popularity has plummeted to 48% amid Covid-19 lockdowns, the lowest level since the pandemic began. His government's vaccine rollout has been criticized, with at least 20 coronavirus leaks into local communities. Morrison's lead over opposition leader Anthony Albanese has also slipped, with Labor maintaining a six-point lead over the ruling coalition ahead of an election due by May. The nation remains vulnerable to snap lockdowns, with Sydney in its seventh week of lockdown.

site_title: Saverin-backed exchange becomes India's first crypto unicorn
summary: CoinDCX, backed by Facebook co-founder Eduardo Saverin's B Capital Group, has raised $1.1 billion, making it India's first cryptocurrency unicorn. The exchange plans to expand its user base to 50 million and focus on educating users on crypto and blockchain. Despite local authorities' pushback against crypto assets, CEO Sumit Gupta believes the industry will be regulated at the right time, citing India's tech-savvy population and potential for dominance in the space.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 6.93 points to 1,496.73 on Monday, with 520 gainers outnumbering 449 losers. Volume reached 3.683 billion lots worth RM2.204 billion.

site_title: Shenzhen sees plunge in resale home transaction volume: report
summary: Shenzhen, a major Chinese residential real estate market, experienced an 84.5% decline in resale home transaction volume in July compared to the previous year, following the implementation of price-control measures. The city had previously seen a sharp rise in home prices due to loose residency requirements and supply constraints. The decline in transaction volume and resale home prices is part of a broader effort to curb price increases and speculation in China's property market, which has regained strength since the Covid-19 crisis.

site_title: Wolfsburg, we have a problem: How Volkswagen stalled in China
summary: Volkswagen's Chinese joint venture, SAIC Volkswagen, faced a crisis in 2019 after its Passat sedan failed an unofficial safety test, simulating a head-on collision. The test, developed by a Chinese insurance industry body, exposed the car's weak front-end structure, leading to a viral backlash. In response, Volkswagen strengthened metal components at a cost of around $84 per vehicle, affecting hundreds of thousands of cars. The incident damaged the company's reputation and financial performance in China, with sales of the Passat plummeting 32% and profit per vehicle falling to around $800.

images.alt_text: There's been no respite for SAIC Volkswagen in 2021, with sales falling 7.8 per cent in the first six months compared with a year earlier when the pandemic raged.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust H1 DPU rises 55.2% to 2.98 Singapore cents
summary: DASIN Retail Trust reported a 55.2% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.98 Singapore cents for its first half ended June 2021, from 1.92 cents a year ago, excluding a distribution waiver by major unitholders. Without the waiver, DPU rose 97.8% to 2.67 Singapore cents.

site_title: At 26, Joseph Schooling still has many more years left in his tank
summary: Singaporean swimmer Joseph Schooling, 26, returned empty-handed from the Tokyo Olympics, sparking concerns about his form and preparation. Despite his Olympic champion status, Schooling struggled in the 100m butterfly and freestyle events, with times nearly three seconds off his personal best. His coach attributed his struggles to a lack of power in training. Schooling has expressed determination to bounce back, with his sights set on the 2024 Paris Olympics and the Asian Games in 2023, where he aims to defend his butterfly titles. Fans and officials alike are rallying behind him, acknowledging his exceptional talent and the challenges he has faced.

site_title: UN issues dire warning with 'code red for humanity' report
summary: The UN's Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) has issued a dire warning, labeling it a "code red for humanity" due to the world's dangerously close proximity to runaway warming. The report states that greenhouse gas levels in the atmosphere are high enough to guarantee climate disruption for decades if not centuries, and that humans are "unequivocally" to blame. The IPCC warns that if immediate, rapid, and large-scale action is not taken to reduce emissions, the average global temperature will likely cross the 1.5 deg C warming threshold within the next 20 years, with catastrophic impacts including heat so intense that crops fail or people die just from being outdoors.

site_title: NAB to buy Citigroup's Australia consumer unit for A$1.2 billion
summary: NAB to acquire Citigroup's Australia consumer unit for A$1.2 billion, consolidating 90% of the country's credit cards industry. The deal adds 1 million customers to NAB, making it the nation's second-largest credit card provider. The acquisition includes a A$4.3 billion unsecured lending portfolio and 800 Citi employees, with regulatory approvals needed. The deal is expected to close by March 2022 and will require equity of about A$1.2 billion, as NAB pays cash for the net assets plus a A$250 million premium.

site_title: Too early to talk about 'post-pandemic' world economy
summary: The article emphasizes that it's too early to discuss a post-pandemic world economy due to ongoing challenges posed by the Delta variant and inadequate global vaccine production. The author argues that public health should remain the top priority, and economies should focus on maintaining basic economic functions and avoiding poverty. The US, UK, and East Asian countries serve as examples of the consequences of inadequate response to the pandemic. The article also highlights the dangers of misinformation and conspiratorial thinking, particularly in the US, where a significant portion of the population believes false claims about vaccines and the pandemic.

site_title: Balancing act for Brussels between Beijing and Biden
summary: The European Union's Comprehensive Agreement on Investment with China may be delayed due to rising bilateral tensions. The EU's High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Josep Borrell, has announced a report reviewing the EU's relationship with China, citing the need for a common European approach. The agreement, signed in December 2020, faces uncertainty as EU member countries have been engaged with Chinese officials, and the European Parliament has criticized Chinese sanctions and human rights issues. Ratification may not happen until 2023, and even then, it's unlikely to lead to a significant warming in ties between Brussels and Beijing.

site_title: ByteDance eyes HK IPO amid Beijing's tech crackdown: FT
summary: ByteDance, the owner of TikTok, is planning to list in Hong Kong by early next year despite China's tech crackdown, according to a Financial Times report. The company has been addressing data security concerns and has submitted filings to Chinese authorities. This move comes as Chinese regulators widen their oversight of technology firms, following President Xi Jinping's regulatory reforms targeting the education tech sector. ByteDance's plans for an offshore listing were put on hold earlier this year due to data-security risks, but the company is now moving forward.

site_title: UK heat strategy pushed to Sept as climate pressure grows
summary: The UK's long-awaited heat strategy for reducing carbon emissions from heating drafty homes is set to be published in September, with options including phasing out gas boilers and a potential carbon tax to make polluters pay. The strategy aims to support the UK's goal of reaching "net zero" greenhouse gas emissions by 2050. Business Secretary Kwasi Kwarteng is in talks with the Treasury about incentives for homeowners to make their buildings more energy efficient and is also exploring the possibility of a carbon tax. The plans come as the UK gears up to host a key climate change summit in the fall.

site_title: Why Japan's demographics have not scared off Singapore property groups
summary: Singapore property groups are investing in Japan despite the country's shrinking population and subdued economic growth, drawn by the attractive yield and cheap borrowings. Recent purchases, including a 98.47% stake in a Tokyo office building and three rental housing properties in Sapporo, demonstrate investors' confidence in Japan's stable returns. The yield spread between prime office cap rates and 10-year government bond yields is higher in Tokyo compared to other major Asian cities, making Japan an attractive destination for investors seeking stable income streams.

site_title: Amazon, Walmart's Flipkart must face India antitrust probe, top court says
summary: The Indian Supreme Court has ruled that Amazon and Walmart's Flipkart must face antitrust investigations ordered by the Competition Commission of India. The companies were accused of promoting select sellers and stifling competition. The ruling comes after Amazon and Flipkart mounted legal challenges, but the court expects them to volunteer for the investigations and provide transparency. The companies face allegations of exclusive launches, promotion of select sellers, and deep discounting practices, and must answer 32 questions from the CCI within four weeks.

images.alt_text: Amazon and Flipkart are major players in an e-retail market India forecasts will be worth US$200 billion by 2026.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore stocks have experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with the Singapore Exchange (SGX) tracking fund flows in the market. Meanwhile, OCBC Bank has announced the retirement of CEO Helen Wong and the appointment of Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, as her successor. Tan Teck Long is set to take over as CEO of OCBC. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) are also planning to deepen their cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: US: Stocks are mixed on stimulus, virus outlook
summary: US stocks were mixed on Monday as investors weighed concerns over a potential pull-back in stimulus and a resurgence in the delta virus variant. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial indexes fell, while the Nasdaq 100 edged higher. Crude oil touched its lowest in three weeks, and precious metals, including gold and silver, also declined. Strong US payrolls data and comments from the Dallas Fed president raised expectations that the Federal Reserve may soon start paring back its monetary stimulus, potentially making precious metals less attractive.

site_title: Chinese cities kick off new tests as more Covid cases reported
summary: China reported 125 new confirmed Covid-19 infections, including 94 locally transmitted cases, on Monday, as the Delta variant continues to spread in over a dozen cities. Mass testing has been implemented in several cities, including Yangzhou, Nanjing, and Nantong, in an effort to curb the outbreak. Authorities have also removed officials deemed negligent in control efforts. Experts expect China to quash the outbreak, despite economic costs, and maintain its zero-Covid strategy. The country's total infections stand at 93,826, with 4,636 deaths.

site_title: Adani Wilmar's India IPO could boost Wilmar's share price, earnings: analysts
summary: Adani Wilmar, a 50% joint venture of Wilmar International, is set to launch an initial public offering (IPO) in India to raise up to $821.4 million. The funds will be used for capital expenditure, strategic acquisitions, and repayment of borrowings. Analysts predict the IPO could boost Wilmar's share price and earnings, with some estimating a potential rerating catalyst for the parent company. The IPO timeline is expected to take 8-12 weeks, and analysts expect the company to launch new products and expand its customer base to increase market share.

site_title: Chinese chipmakers slump after Beijing sends speculation warning
summary: China's chipmakers, including Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp (SMIC), Hua Hong Semiconductor, and Will Semiconductor Co, dropped 5-5.7% in Hong Kong after Beijing warned regulators will crack down on speculators in the chip market. The warning, issued in state media, came after a probe into possible chip price manipulation and amid a broader crackdown on the tech sector. The move presents another challenge for investors in an uncertain regulatory landscape, which has seen stocks of major tech firms like Alibaba Group and Tencent Holdings also decline.

images.alt_text: China's microchip industry is feeling the heat of Beijing's regulatory scrutiny.

site_title: Oil sinks to three-week low as virus spread menaces outlook
summary: Oil futures plunged to a three-week low, falling below $66 a barrel in New York after a 8% slide last week. The resurgence of Covid-19, particularly the Delta variant, threatens fuel demand and has led to a downgrade of Goldman Sachs' economic growth forecast for China. Despite the market's concerns, the Opec+ alliance is stabilizing supply levels, limiting further price losses in the short term. The prompt timespread for Brent has narrowed, indicating a bullish signal.

site_title: Euro zone bond yields dip from highs on Fed, inflation data
summary: Euro zone bond yields decreased from highs driven by US jobs data last week, influenced by US inflation data due later this week. German 10-year yields fell to -0.47% and the 30-year yield turned positive, bringing the German yield curve back into negative territory. Analysts attribute the decline to low supply and liquidity over the summer, as well as investor appetite for carry trades. Despite concerns over potential lockdown restrictions, the data had little impact on the market, with investor morale also falling to a three-month low.

site_title: ecoWise seeks 4-week extension to fill audit committee vacancies
summary: Ecowise Holdings has applied to the Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) for a four-week extension to appoint independent directors to its audit committee. The deadline for filling vacancies was originally Aug 4, but the company now seeks an extension to Sept 3. This comes after two independent directors resigned in May, leaving the audit committee with only one member. The company expects to complete the appointment process by Sept 3 after conducting due diligence and assessing suitable candidates. Shares have been suspended from trading since June 18.

site_title: US dollar buoyed by Friday's payrolls report
summary: The US dollar reached a four-month high against the euro on Monday, driven by strong labour market data that encouraged investors to expect the Federal Reserve to reduce pandemic-era stimulus and raise interest rates. The US currency strengthened to US$1.1742 to the euro, while the benchmark 10-year Treasury yield jumped eight basis points. Analysts noted that market participants had pushed forward the Fed's tapering announcement, and speculators cut their net long US dollar positions, but the immediate dollar spike may be fizzling due to concerns over rising Covid-19 cases in Asia.

site_title: Renault, Geely to explore new hybrid-focused venture
summary: Renault and Geely have signed a framework agreement to form a hybrid vehicle joint venture (JV) in China, focusing on producing Renault-branded petrol-electric hybrid cars. The JV will utilize Geely's technologies, supply chains, and manufacturing facilities, with Renault handling sales and marketing. The venture aims to expand to South Korea and other fast-growing Asian markets, potentially developing full electric battery cars. The partnership strengthens Geely's strategy of sharing technologies and reduces development costs, while Renault seeks to rebuild its presence in China. The JV is expected to export vehicles.

site_title: Chinese chipmakers slump as beijing sends speculation warning
summary: Chinese chipmakers experienced a slump after Beijing sent a warning to regulators, urging them to crack down on speculators in the chip market. Stocks for Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp (SMIC), Hua Hong Semiconductor, Will Semiconductor, and Hubei Tech Semiconductors dropped significantly, with SMIC falling 5% and others dropping 5.7%. The warning comes amid a probe into possible chip price manipulation and a broader crackdown on the tech sector, which has already affected companies like Alibaba and Tencent. The move adds uncertainty to the sector, which has benefited from a global semiconductor shortage.

site_title: Singapore's global lead towards no net-carbon emissions
summary: Singapore's global lead in reducing carbon emissions is crucial in the fight against climate change. The International Monetary Fund proposes a minimum carbon price of $75 per tonne to achieve a 23% reduction in global emissions by 2030. Singapore, with its high per-capita income and experience with a carbon tax, could be a powerful voice in this effort. To increase the impact, green investments must be promoted, with mechanisms for risk sharing and international carbon markets. The big carbon emitters, including China, the US, and India, must make strong commitments at the UN Climate Change Conference in Glasgow in November.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks drop at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks dropped 0.80% at the open on Monday, following strong US jobs data that fueled speculation of a sooner-than-expected Fed move to wind down ultra-loose monetary policy. The Hang Seng Index fell to 25,969.23, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes also declined.

site_title: Building a business resilience strategy in a cloud environment
summary: Singaporean SMEs face increased complexity in hybrid working arrangements, requiring business resilience and adaptability to thrive in a volatile recovery period. Embracing a cloud-first strategy can drive competitiveness, standardise processes, and provide 24/7 accessibility for employees. Cloud integration should be informed by business goals, focusing on improving the bottom line and building robust client relationships. Despite concerns over cost and security, Alibaba Cloud's survey reveals that nearly 90% of Singaporean organisations use cloud services, and security infrastructure is in place to instil trust and assurance in customers.

site_title: Deadly Delta variant derails regional recovery
summary: The deadly Delta variant has disrupted the regional recovery in Southeast Asia, with HSBC and ANZ slashing growth estimates for Asean-6 economies. The variant has exposed the region's soft underbelly, with Indonesia and Malaysia experiencing record case counts and fatalities. Vietnam's slow vaccination campaign has also led to a slowdown in economic growth. Experts warn that the pandemic could lead to long-term effects, including permanent business closures and deeper poverty in rural areas. Despite this, some analysts expect an Asean recovery by early 2022, driven by domestic demand and supply chain relocation.

site_title: Greenpac looks to expand to US, Europe with sale to family office Treis
summary: Singapore-based sustainable packaging company Greenpac has been sold to family office Treis for around S$100 million, with the goal of expanding into the US and Europe. The deal involves a merger of Greenpac with its sister companies Salpac and Sal Packaging, creating a vertically-integrated international group. Greenpac's founder and CEO Susan Chong will continue to lead the company, which plans to open offices in the US and Europe and expects revenue from new markets to grow to 40-50% over the next four years.

images.alt_text: Home-grown sustainable packaging company Greenpac has been sold to family office Treis as the company looks to beef up resources as it seeks to expand abroad in the US and Europe.

site_title: Indonesia launches online push to streamline investment permits
summary: Indonesia has launched an online platform, "Online Single Submission," to streamline investment permits, aiming to make it easier and quicker to do business. The website processes investment proposals based on risk levels, with lower risk investments requiring only registration and medium ones meeting national standards. The move is part of President Joko Widodo's efforts to attract foreign investment and overcome hurdles such as red tape and poor infrastructure. The platform eliminates application costs for enterprises up to five billion rupiah in size, and the government hopes it will increase investors' confidence and create jobs.

site_title: Coming months crucial for Malaysia's battered economy
summary: Malaysia's economy is expected to face a crucial period in the coming months, with the fate of Budget 2022 set to be determined in October. The country's vaccination programme is expected to gain pace, and Parliament will reconvene in September with Prime Minister subjecting himself to a vote of confidence. Analysts consider the budget's outcome the biggest economic risk, as the country navigates the ongoing impact of the pandemic and tariff threats. The move to shield the economy from tariff threats has been signaled by a rate cut, which has raised concerns about growth.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise as banks, property shares gain; Alibaba weighs on tech sector
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 0.4% on Monday, driven by gains in banking and property shares, as slowing economic growth in China sparked hopes of policy easing. Tech shares, however, fell due to a decline in Alibaba, which was hit by a sexual assault allegation. The China Enterprises Index also rose 0.4%.

site_title: A-Sonic's receives notice of International Plaza collective sale; units valued above book
summary: A-Sonic Aerospace received a notice from the collective sale committee of International Plaza, where it occupies office units. The units are valued at S$6.6 million, above the carrying value of S$1.4 million. The company's shares closed at 58.5 Singapore cents, up 1.7% on Friday. A-Sonic warned shareholders and investors to exercise caution, as there is no assurance of the collective sale and no certainty on the expected valuation. The collective sale of International Plaza, potentially the largest in Singapore's history, is expected to be launched soon.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly up but Fed taper talk, Delta temper gains
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday, despite concerns over the Federal Reserve's potential to start tapering monetary policy and the spread of the Delta Covid variant. The US jobs report showed a strong rebound in the economy, but investors remain cautious. Oil prices fell as governments reassess their growth outlooks and some, including China, reimpose lockdowns. The Fed's accommodative stance is under pressure to act, with some predicting a taper announcement in September and actual tapering in November.

site_title: Thailand's investment pledges more than double in H1
summary: Thailand's investment applications more than doubled in the first half of 2021, reaching 386 billion baht (S$15.64 billion), driven by the electronics and medical sectors. Foreign direct investment (FDI) projects increased four-fold, with Japan, the US, and China as top source countries. The electrical and electronics sector attracted the most investment, with 61 billion baht of projects, up 136% year-on-year. This surge in investment comes despite the ongoing impact of the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: 69 new locally transmitted Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including 20 unlinked
summary: Singapore reported 69 new locally transmitted COVID-19 cases, including 20 unlinked cases. The locally linked cases include 39 individuals already in quarantine and 10 who were not in quarantine. The unlinked cases include two seniors above 70 who are unvaccinated or partially vaccinated. The total number of cases in Singapore stands at 65,836, with 42 deaths. The country also reported three imported cases, bringing the total number of patients in the hospital to 542, with 37 seriously ill and eight in critical condition.

site_title: China central bank to keep monetary policy 'flexible and appropriate'
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), has decided to maintain a flexible and appropriate monetary policy to ensure stability amidst the ongoing pandemic and uneven economic recovery. The PBOC aims to keep liquidity ample and provide support for technology innovation, small firms, and the manufacturing sector. This move aims to address the challenges posed by the evolving global pandemic and complex external environment.

site_title: National Australia Bank to buy Citi's Australia consumer unit in A$1.2b deal
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) has agreed to acquire Citi's Australian consumer unit in a deal valued at approximately A$1.20 billion. The acquisition will create the second-largest credit card provider in the country, with 800 Citi employees and senior management joining NAB. The deal is expected to result in annual pre-tax cost savings of A$130 million over three years. NAB will invest in a new technology platform to support the combined business, and Citi's consumer lending assets in Australia totaled A$12.20 billion at the end of June.

site_title: Australia: Miners hold back shares even as financials gain
summary: Australian shares ended flat on Monday, closing at 7,538.4 points, despite strong gains in financials. Gold and mining stocks fell, with Evolution Mining and Newcrest Mining down 2.4% and 2.7%, respectively, due to solid US jobs data and concerns of an interest rate hike. Financial stocks rose 1.3% led by National Australia Bank's acquisition of Citigroup's local consumer unit and insurer Suncorp Group's strong annual results.

site_title: US Senate inches toward passing US$1t infrastructure bill
summary: The US Senate voted 69-28 in favor of a $1 trillion bipartisan infrastructure bill, a major step towards its passage. The bill, a top priority for President Joe Biden, could be sent to the House of Representatives after a vote on debate limits, potentially paving the way for its passage by the end of the week. The legislation aims to invest in roads and bridges, marking the largest US investment in the sector in decades.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.15 points, or 0.3%, to 1,493.95 on Monday, driven by a higher volume of 66.4 million lots worth RM25.1 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 184 to 89.

site_title: Europe: Mixed feelings
summary: Europe's stock markets experienced mixed feelings, with the FTSE 100 and STOXX 600 indices showing contrasting trends. The FTSE 100 fell due to a 2% drop in oil prices, affecting oil companies like Royal Dutch Shell and BP. In contrast, the STOXX 600 rose, supported by dealmaking activity and strong earnings season. Deliveroo's shares rose 6.5% after a stake acquisition, while Hargreaves Lansdown fell 8% after FY results.

site_title: Australia PM's ratings hit 18-month low as lockdowns linger
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison's public approval rating has hit an 18-month low of 47% due to growing frustration over lockdowns and a sluggish vaccination drive. The poll, conducted by The Australian newspaper, also shows the Liberal-National Party coalition trailing opposition Labor by 47-53 on a two-party preferred basis. With fewer than 23% of Australians fully vaccinated, states have implemented stop-and-start lockdowns to quell outbreaks of the Delta variant, despite relatively low pandemic numbers in Australia. Morrison's approval rating has almost halved since the peak of the pandemic last year.

site_title: Energy infrastructure player Yinson sees blue ocean in green tech
summary: Malaysia-listed energy infrastructure company Yinson Holdings is aiming to become a frontrunner in green technology, with a focus on renewable energy projects and collaborations with startups. The company has established a "green technologies division" to invest in sustainable solutions and has made notable investments in startups such as Lift Ocean and Oyika. Yinson's executive vice-president, Eirik Barclay, believes the potential for growth in the green tech sector is enormous, particularly in emerging markets like India and South America. The company's green technologies division is also exploring opportunities for partnerships and investments in the coming years.

site_title: Oil slumps on China travel curbs, strong US dollar
summary: Oil prices dropped 2% on Monday due to a rising US dollar and concerns over new pandemic curbs in Asia, particularly China, which may slow global fuel demand recovery. Brent crude futures fell to $69.29 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell to $66.96 a barrel. New restrictions in China, including flight cancellations and travel warnings, have raised concerns about potential demand erosion, while a strong US dollar makes oil more expensive for holders of other currencies.

site_title: Australia's New South Wales state expands Covid-19 lockdown
summary: New South Wales in Australia expanded its Covid-19 lockdown to the rural town of Tamworth due to concerns the virus may have spread from Sydney into the countryside. The lockdown was announced after people known to have Covid-19 traveled from Sydney to Tamworth without authorization. The state reported 283 locally acquired cases of Covid-19 in the past 24 hours, amid a surge of the highly infectious Delta variant.

site_title: Gold tumbles as robust jobs data bolsters bets of early Fed tapering
summary: Gold prices fell 4.4% to a four-month low as robust US jobs data raised expectations of an early Federal Reserve interest rate hike, increasing the cost of holding non-interest-bearing bullion. US employers hired the most workers in nearly a year in July, boosting the economy and fueling concerns of faster rate hikes. The data also boosted the dollar and US Treasury yields, hurting gold's appeal as an inflation hedge.

site_title: Work-from-home driving UK property price surge, says BOE
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) attributes the UK's recent surge in property prices to a shift in consumer preferences for bigger houses due to increased need for office space at home. Deputy Governor Ben Broadbent notes that working from home has made space more valuable, particularly in city centers. The BOE also cites a proliferation of high loan-to-value (LTV) mortgages, which have helped consumers afford more expensive homes. The housing market is expected to remain solid despite the phasing out of the stamp-duty break, with annual price growth continuing to slow but remaining positive.

site_title: China: Stocks rise on hopes of policy easing
summary: China's stocks rose 1.3% on Monday, driven by a rebound in blue-chip stocks and hopes of policy easing amid slowing economic growth. The CSI300 index rose to 4,985.56, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose to 3,494.63. Factory gate inflation climbed 9% in July, and domestic export growth slowed, sparking concerns about the economy. Analysts expect policy easing, including a potential 50bp RRR cut, to support the job market. The consumer staples sector and real estate indexes led the gains, while new energy and semiconductor companies fell.

site_title: China's July factory price growth quickens, adds to business cost pressures
summary: China's factory gate prices rose 9% in July, exceeding analyst expectations, and adding to business cost pressures due to high raw material costs. The producer price index (PPI) also accelerated by 0.5% on a monthly basis. Consumer inflation eased slightly, with the consumer price index (CPI) rising 1% from a year earlier. The economic expansion is losing steam due to intensifying strains from higher commodity prices and global supply chain bottlenecks, despite China's efforts to tame rising commodity prices.

site_title: Indonesia launches online push to streamline investment permits
summary: Indonesia launched an online platform to streamline investment permits, aiming to simplify the process and attract foreign investment. The "Online Single Submission" website assesses investment proposals based on risk levels, reducing application costs for eligible businesses. President Joko Widodo's administration hopes the move will increase investor confidence, create jobs, and boost economic growth. The website is part of the controversial Job Creation law, which aims to promote business-friendly reforms. Indonesia's economy showed signs of recovery, with 7.07% GDP growth in the second quarter.

site_title: Philippine central bank vows easy monetary policy, Q1 GDP revised to -3.9% from -4.2%
summary: The Philippine central bank has vowed to maintain easy monetary policy to support a strong and sustainable economic recovery from the coronavirus pandemic. The country's GDP contracted by 3.9% in Q1, revised from an initial 4.2% contraction, but is expected to grow 7.7% in 2022 and 6.5% in 2023. Governor Benjamin Diokno emphasized the need for accommodative policies, citing a strong second-quarter recovery, while policymakers will meet on Thursday to decide on key interest rates.

site_title: Third Pfizer vaccine dose has similar side effects to second: Israeli survey
summary: An Israeli survey found that most people who received a third dose of Pfizer's Covid-19 vaccine experienced similar or fewer side effects compared to the second shot. The survey, conducted on Clalit healthcare providers, showed that 88% of participants felt "similar or better" after the third dose. Common side effects included soreness at the injection site, with 31% of participants reporting some side effect. The results suggest that the third booster dose may be beneficial for personal risk management, particularly for individuals over 60.

site_title: Asia: Stocks slip as gold slides, oil takes a spill
summary: Asian stocks declined on Monday as gold prices plummeted and oil prices dropped due to concerns over the spread of the Delta variant. The dollar reached four-month highs against the euro after a US jobs report boosted bond yields. The US Senate moved closer to passing a $1 trillion infrastructure package, but investors remain uncertain about the Federal Reserve's plans for tapering stimulus. Despite a strong US payrolls report, stocks have been underpinned by a robust earnings season, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: Renault to explore hybrid vehicles with Geely
summary: Renault and Geely are jointly developing petrol-electric hybrid vehicles for China and South Korea markets. Renault will use Geely's hybrid car system to produce vehicles under the Renault brand in China, while exploring hybrid car production with Geely in South Korea. This move comes after Renault's former China chief, Weiming Soh, took charge, following the company's exit from a Chinese joint venture last year. The partnership aims to meet increasingly tough auto regulations globally and capitalize on China's strict rules on greenhouse gas-emitting vehicles.

site_title: NetEase's music service to delay Hong Kong IPO launch: sources
summary: NetEase's music streaming arm, Cloud Village, is delaying the Hong Kong IPO launch initially set to raise about $1 billion. The IPO was postponed due to uncertainty in market conditions, according to sources. The IPO was expected to be one of the largest first-time share sales in Hong Kong by a technology company this year.

site_title: China Telecom eyes 54b yuan Shanghai IPO, world's biggest in 2021
summary: China Telecom is planning a Shanghai initial public offering (IPO) that could raise up to $8 billion, the largest IPO in 2021. The firm priced its offer at 4.53 yuan per share, worth 47.1 billion yuan, but could raise up to 54 billion yuan if an over-allotment option is exercised. China Telecom was delisted in the US in January due to a ban on investments in Chinese companies deemed to support the military. The IPO will be used to fund 5G and cloud-network infrastructure, part of China's digital transformation drive.

site_title: South Korea opens Covid-19 vaccine reservations for all adults
summary: South Korea began reserving COVID-19 vaccines for all adults over 18, aiming to immunize 70% of adults by September. The country has had a slow vaccination uptake, with 45% having received at least one dose and 15% fully vaccinated. As of Sunday, 1,492 new cases were reported, bringing the total infections to 212,448 and 2,125 deaths. The country is scrambling to stave off a rise in sporadic outbreaks, particularly among young, unvaccinated residents.

site_title: Alibaba manager accused of sexual assault to be fired: memo
summary: Alibaba Group Holding will fire a manager accused of rape after a female employee reported being raped by her boss in a hotel room in China. Two executives who mishandled the allegation have resigned. CEO Daniel Zhang has stated that the company will rebuild its thinking and actions to prevent similar incidents. Alibaba has a "zero-tolerance policy" against sexual misconduct and will conduct training programs and establish a reporting channel to address employee rights protection. A police investigation remains ongoing.

site_title: China's Wuhan completes citywide Covid tests on 11 million residents
summary: China's Wuhan city has completed citywide Covid-19 testing of over 11 million residents, providing "basically full coverage" of the population except for children under six and students on summer break. The testing campaign, which began on Tuesday, has found 37 locally transmitted cases and 41 local asymptomatic carriers. The city's recent resurgence of cases, fueled by the Delta variant, has broken a year-long streak without domestic cases, casting doubt on China's record of controlling the virus. Authorities have mobilized 28,000 health workers for the testing campaign.

site_title: BT Mark to Market: CapitaLand's big restructuring (Ep 10)
summary: CapitaLand, a Singaporean real estate company, has undergone a significant restructuring, making it the third-best performing STI component stock so far this year. The company's repeated rebranding efforts have sparked investor interest, with its stock price rising in response to the new plan. CapitaLand's restructuring has also led to it surpassing City Developments, another prominent Singaporean developer. Investors are left to consider whether to hold onto the stock after its recent surge.

site_title: Manufacturing in Singapore through the decades
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector has undergone significant evolution over the last 60 years, shifting from labour-intensive goods to high-value technologies and products. The nation's strategy to focus on pharmaceuticals, tech, and medical industries has led to a rise in high-value-added sectors, contributing to a 0.5% increase in manufacturing's share of gross domestic product to 21.5% in 2021. This growth is attributed to the success of high-value areas, with pharmaceuticals and electronics being key drivers. The sector's growth has also contributed to the nation's resilience in recent years.

site_title: Supply disruptions, bottlenecks likely to stay inflationary in 2022: IIF
summary: A new study from the Institute of International Finance (IIF) suggests that supply disruptions and bottlenecks are likely to continue inflationary pressures in 2022, contradicting the views of central banks. The IIF's managing director, Robin Brooks, states that US supply chain disruptions are severe, leading to longer delivery times and higher mark-ups, which will result in further price rises. The study also notes that companies are raising prices aggressively to cover higher costs, with mark-ups in the US far surpassing those in other countries, leaving room for upside inflation surprises in 2022.

site_title: Tearful Messi confirms he is leaving Barcelona, in talks with PSG
summary: Lionel Messi has confirmed he is leaving FC Barcelona, citing financial issues after the club's inability to afford him. The 34-year-old Argentine player, who spent two decades at the club, is in talks with French club Paris St Germain (PSG) over a possible move. Messi, who broke down in tears during a news conference, expressed his desire to continue playing football as long as possible and win another Champions League trophy.

site_title: Board governance of SPACs
summary: SPACs, or Special Purpose Acquisition Companies, are gaining traction in Asian markets as a way for companies to access equity markets without going through an initial public offering (IPO). Effective governance is crucial for SPACs, particularly for independent directors, who must understand the value creation process and risks involved. They must also monitor the acquisition process, including selecting a target firm, approving the acquisition, and ensuring a smooth post-acquisition combination. Poor governance can lead to conflicts of interest and a power imbalance in the boardroom, and regulatory scrutiny is increasing.

site_title: Airbus A321 delays flare again as planemaker begins ramping up
summary: Airbus has encountered production issues with its A321neo model, causing delays in handovers to customers this year. The company is struggling with pandemic and supply-chain issues as it ramps up jetliner production rates following coronavirus lockdowns. The A330neo wide-body has also been affected to a lesser extent. This setback comes as Airbus aims to increase production rates, with customer Air Lease Corp reporting some A321neo handovers have been pushed back.

site_title: Japan PM Suga's support slides to record low as Olympic Games close: survey
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's support has dropped to a record low of 28% in a survey, following the closure of the Tokyo Olympic Games. The survey also found 60% of respondents do not want Suga to stay as premier, and 56% think holding the Games was a good idea. The low support comes amidst a resurgence of coronavirus infections and a slow vaccination rollout, overshadowing the Olympics. Suga and Olympics organizers have denied a link between the Games and the spike in cases.

site_title: US dollar rallies towards biggest weekly gain since June
summary: The US dollar surged towards its biggest weekly gain in seven weeks, driven by a strong jobs report showing 943,000 jobs added in July, exceeding forecasts. This led to higher bond yields and a risk-on tone, with the dollar rising 0.9% against the Swiss franc and 0.4% against the Japanese yen. The report also reignited speculation about a potential interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve as early as late 2022, with Treasury yields rising to 1.3% and the yield on the 10-year Treasury note touching 1.3%.

site_title: 18 months into pandemic, overseas Singaporeans miss that familiar taste of home
summary: Singaporeans living abroad miss various aspects of their homeland, particularly food, culture, and family. With the ongoing pandemic, many are reluctant to return home due to travel restrictions and quarantine rules. Despite this, some have adapted to their new lives and found ways to stay connected with their loved ones and maintain their cultural heritage. Those who have chosen to stay abroad, like Jason Ng, Eric Chin, and Kelvin Oh, express a desire to return home once the pandemic subsides, with some even considering bringing their families to their adopted countries.

site_title: Tokyo counts cost of US$15b pandemic Olympics 'gamble'
summary: Tokyo is grappling with a massive bill of nearly $15 billion for hosting the pandemic-affected Olympics, which drew criticism for its safety measures and high cost. Despite initial concerns, the Games were widely supported by the public, with 56% of Japanese backing the event. However, the country is now facing a crisis with soaring coronavirus cases, with Tokyo under a state of emergency and only around a third of the population fully vaccinated. The Games' organizers have defended their decision, citing the event's "unifying power of sport" and its role in bringing people together.

site_title: Local businesses champion Singapore spirit, spread National Day joy
summary: Local businesses in Singapore are teaming up to celebrate the country's National Day, promoting the spirit of unity and caring for one another, particularly frontline workers and marginalized communities. Companies such as Standard Chartered Bank, Marina Bay Sands, and Tong Eng Group are collaborating through the "Company of Good" initiative, which aims to pool resources to make a collective impact on the community. These partnerships include goodie bag distributions, card-making for healthcare workers and seniors, and virtual engagement programs to spread joy and support during the pandemic.

site_title: Prioritising employee experience in a digital-first world
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated digital adoption, forcing companies to rethink their business priorities and focus on employee experience (EX). A survey by KellyOCG found that a continuous state of flux in the future workplace requires a holistic EX powered by frontier technology to remain market-competitive. This approach can unlock enhanced employee engagement, boost productivity, and empower talent. As businesses adapt, they must prioritize EX to thrive in a digital-first world.

site_title: Sembmarine shareholders seek answers from management on rights issue, outlook
summary: Sembcorp Marine's shareholders expressed concerns about the proposed 3-for-2 rights issue, citing the low price of eight Singapore cents, which they believed would not be sufficient for those who bought in at "higher prices". Shareholders also questioned the company's strategy to turn around its business and when it would return to profitability. The company faces supply chain disruptions, a lack of skilled manpower, and a significant share price decline over the years. An extraordinary general meeting to vote on the rights issue is scheduled for August 23.

site_title: Business optimism began to dip even before Phase 2 Heightened Alert: survey
summary: Business optimism in Singapore has dipped, even before the implementation of tighter Covid-19 measures, according to a quarterly business climate survey. The net balance in business prospects decreased to 27% in Q2, down two points from the prior quarter. The highly transmissible Delta variant is believed to have played a part in respondents' bleaker outlook. However, sales growth improved, with the net balance increasing to 9% in Q2, while foreign firms posted improved performance, including expanded profits and new business.

site_title: 'Real progress' for lower-wage workers is essential part of inclusive growth: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of making progress for lower-wage workers in his National Day Message, calling it an essential part of inclusive growth. The government has given more support to this group during the Covid-19 pandemic, and a tripartite workgroup is developing proposals to improve their lives and prospects. Lee also acknowledged concerns over foreign work-pass holders, stating that while they bring skills and expertise, they can also compete with local workers and create social frictions. He emphasized the need to manage these issues carefully to maintain social harmony and uphold the country's values of openness and acceptance.

site_title: S&P 500 makes a bullish break
summary: The S&P 500 index made a bullish break above a previously identified bearish ascending wedge, driven by declining bond yields and strong earnings reports from 59% of S&P 500 companies, with 88% beating earnings forecasts. The index rebounded strongly after a retest of the break level, suggesting the area has flipped into strong support. The fundamental view is positive, with the index benefiting from a cyclical recovery and high revenue growth, although concerns over COVID-19 cases and potential monetary policy tightening may limit the rally.

site_title: 'Overprotection' may trip Indonesia's booming e-commerce
summary: Researchers warn that Indonesia's booming e-commerce market may be hindered by "overprotection" and an "unpredictable" regulatory regime. Heavy regulations on vendors could exacerbate existing structural barriers, including poor infrastructure and tech skills shortages. The authors argue for a clear regulatory framework to support a conducive ecosystem, citing concerns that current rules may burden micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises. Foreign e-commerce operators may also face challenges under these regulations, which aim to protect domestic enterprises but could harm consumers and micro-retail businesses.

site_title: China education firms to end most foreign-tutor classes
summary: China's largest private education firms, including VIPKid and GoGoKid, will stop providing classes taught by foreign-based tutors to students in the country, effective immediately. The move follows a government directive aimed at rectifying the $100 billion sector, which includes a ban on hiring foreigners as teachers and introducing school curricula to children under six. Existing classes from foreign teachers can still be finished, but new classes will not be sold. The companies plan to focus on overseas markets and adult education programs.

site_title: Are high dividend yields in the Singapore market blinding investors to chronically low total returns?
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) delivered weak returns, with a 10-year total return of 39.8% with dividends reinvested, and 32.6% without. This is largely due to the dominance of dividend yields, with the STI offering a 3.18% dividend yield as of end-July. The FTSE All-World Index and S&P 500 Index outperformed the STI, with total returns of 177.6% and 316.5%, respectively. The article suggests that investors may be prioritizing dividend yields over total returns, and that Singapore companies need to review their dividend policies and capital expenditure programs to improve performance.

site_title: UK scale-up platform Tech Nation sets foot in South-east Asia
summary: Tech Nation, a UK-based startup accelerator, has launched its first overseas office in Singapore, marking its entry into South-east Asia. The move is part of the UK government's £8 million Digital Trade Network initiative, aimed at turning the UK into a global tech powerhouse. Tech Nation will focus on Singapore, Japan, South Korea, and Australia, with partnerships including the Singapore Economic Development Board and Golden Gate Ventures. The organization has previously supported over 40 UK startups in entering the Singapore market, and has helped attract talent to the UK, with a high endorsement rate for Singaporean applications for the Global Talent Visa.

images.alt_text: "There is brilliant innovation in (Singapore's) public sector and the private sector. There is almost this flywheel of innovation," says Stephen Kelly, chairman of Tech Nation.

site_title: Turning 56, with eye on the future
summary: Singapore is poised for a transformative decade ahead, with experts suggesting the city-state focus on emerging technologies such as 5G, AI, and sustainable living. Key areas of focus include building a strong foundation for a smart and sustainable city, leveraging its status as a global innovation hub, and developing a robust cybersecurity strategy. Experts also emphasize the need for Singapore to shift from an "earn-a-living" to a "live-a-life" mindset, prioritizing well-being and sustainability. The decade ahead is expected to bring significant opportunities for growth, particularly in fintech, pharmaceuticals, and green technologies, with Singapore poised to become a global leader in these areas.

site_title: US consumer credit grows at record rate in June
summary: US consumer credit grew at a record rate of $37.69 billion in June, driven by increased credit card usage and robust consumer spending. This follows a $36.69 billion increase in May, exceeding economists' expectations of $23.00 billion. The surge in credit growth could explain sustained consumer spending in the second quarter, despite the ebbing of government stimulus money. Consumer spending accounted for double-digit growth, lifting the level of gross domestic product above its peak in 2019.

site_title: Re-engineering government digital infrastructure to lock in digitalisation gains
summary: Singapore's government has invested heavily in re-engineering its digital infrastructure to drive digitalisation gains. The country aims to sustain its efforts and lock in the benefits, with a focus on three shifts: adopting cloud-based solutions, architecting systems with greater reusability, and procuring technology products and services through bulk tenders. The government has earmarked over $3.8 billion in ICT contracts, with 70% directed towards improving digital services for citizens and businesses. The efforts are expected to accelerate delivery, improve security, and reduce costs, ultimately improving the lives of citizens and businesses.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sabana Reit will not hold an EGM to endorse Chan Wai Kheong as an independent non-executive director, despite a joint requisition letter from Quarz Capital and Black Crane Capital. Axington's proposed S$405 million acquisition of Veivo Web Technology has fallen through due to failed discussions. Meanwhile, OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to take over after Helen Wong's retirement. Singapore stocks have seen a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while CGSI downgraded Grab to 'hold' due to expected earnings growth slowdown.

site_title: Lack of used cooking oil a drag on Maersk's plan for green shipping
summary: Maersk, a major shipping company, is struggling to achieve its goal of becoming carbon-neutral by 2050 due to a lack of used cooking oil, the primary source of biofuel for its vessels. Despite efforts to scale up production, the world's demand for used cooking oil is not keeping pace, and prices are high in Europe. Maersk is instead investing in low-emission ships powered by green methanol and plans to order more ships with dual-engine technology. The company is calling for a global effort to expand production capacity of green fuels.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange's shipping insights report for August 6, 2021, reveals that the Capesize market broke out of its recent range, with the 5TC reaching a peak of $36,150 on Thursday before easing slightly on Friday. The Pacific routes strengthened throughout the week, while the Brazil to China C14 market remained under pressure. The North Atlantic region continues to be the laggard due to low vessel and cargo counts. In other sectors, the Supramax, Suezmax, Aframax, and Handysize markets showed varying levels of activity, with some rates increasing and others remaining firm.

site_title: Cooling measures doing little to slow housing boom in New Zealand
summary: New Zealand's housing market continues to surge, with nearly 15,000 homes sold for over NZ$1 million in the last 12 months, despite government efforts to slow the market. The government's policy tweaks, including new taxes for property investors and checks on "flipping" activity, have had little impact, and investors are showing no signs of exiting the market. Economists expect the central bank to raise interest rates to address high-risk borrowing and unsustainable house prices, which have reached record highs and are making the market unaffordable for low and mid-income earners.

site_title: A drought-hit California town finds itself sinking into the ground
summary: Corcoran, California, a town of 20,000, is sinking into the ground due to intensive farming practices that pump large amounts of water from underground sources to irrigate fields. Over the past 100 years, the town has sunk the equivalent of a two-story house. The phenomenon, caused by groundwater depletion, threatens infrastructure, groundwater wells, and levees. The town is experiencing a vicious cycle of drought, water restrictions, and increased groundwater pumping, exacerbating the subsidence issue. Local residents, many of whom work for large agri-businesses, are reluctant to speak out against the problem due to fear of job loss.

site_title: Brunei clamps down after first local virus cases in 15 months
summary: Brunei imposes strict COVID-19 curbs after seven locally transmitted cases are detected, the first in 15 months. The government closes places of worship, limits social events to 30 people, and moves school classes online. Restaurants are barred from serving dine-in. The country has largely remained coronavirus-free, with only three deaths since the pandemic began. The cases are linked to a government-run virus monitoring centre and an imported case from the Middle East. Brunei has also ramped up its vaccination process, with nearly 32% of its population getting at least one jab.

site_title: The Hour Glass leads July buyback consideration tally
summary: The Hour Glass led the July buyback consideration tally in Singapore, with a total of S$11 million, followed by ST Engineering and OCBC, which contributed S$308 million of the S$379 million in total buyback consideration for the past seven months. The buyback activity declined seasonally in July, with only 10 primary-listed stocks participating, compared to 28 in June. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 1.2% in July, with dividends boosting the total return to 13.2%, making it one of the top three performing APAC benchmarks for the past seven months.

site_title: Farewell Tokyo 2020, hello Paris 2024
summary: The Tokyo 2020 Olympics officially concluded with a closing ceremony, handing the Olympic flag to Paris 2024's mayor. The ceremony featured a surreal park scene in Tokyo, showcasing everyday life amidst the pandemic. Despite the challenges, the Games achieved a record medal haul for Japan and a top finish for the US. Notable moments included gymnast Simone Biles' mental health advocacy and Belarusian sprinter Krystsina Tsimanouskaya's defection. The Games resulted in a $15 billion financial loss for Japan, but organizers prevented a Covid-19 super-spreader event.

site_title: Global supply snags could mean fewer toys under Christmas tree
summary: Global supply chain disruptions, exacerbated by shipping container shortages and a shortage of truck drivers, are causing delays and price increases in the toy industry, potentially impacting Christmas toy sales. Despite efforts by major toy makers like Hasbro and Mattel to diversify their sources and ports, bottlenecks remain, with some products stranded overseas. Experts warn that the situation is unlikely to return to normal before next year, with a global semiconductor crunch and wood shortage also affecting supply.

site_title: Myanmese wait hours to withdraw cash, but most ATMs are empty
summary: Myanmar's economy is crippled by a cash shortage since the military seized power six months ago, with most ATMs empty and randomly selected ones stocked with cash daily. Desperate citizens wait hours to withdraw cash, with some turning to barter and trading items like motorbikes for oxygen. Experts warn of a full-blown financial crisis, citing a 20% devaluation of the kyat, widespread currency hoarding, and a two-values system for cash and online funds. The junta blames pandemic border closings for the crisis, but economists predict the financial crisis will worsen without political change.

site_title: HK minister signals adopting China's anti- sanctions law
summary: Hong Kong's justice secretary, Teresa Cheng, has signaled the city's intention to adopt China's anti-sanctions law, which could undermine Hong Kong's reputation as a global financial hub. The law, passed in June, aims to counter foreign sanctions and could be added to Hong Kong's mini-constitution, pending approval by the Chinese parliament. This move is seen as a significant development, with critics warning it could tarnish sentiment among foreign firms. The decision is expected to be made during a meeting in Beijing on August 17-20.

site_title: Saudi Aramco Q2 profit soars on higher prices and demand recovery
summary: Saudi Aramco reported a near four-fold rise in Q2 net profit to 95.47 billion riyals (S$34 billion), beating expectations, driven by higher oil prices and demand recovery. The company's results follow strong quarterly reports from other oil majors, including Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch Shell. Oil prices have gained over 35% since the start of the year, supported by Opec+ output cuts. Aramco CEO Amin Nasser said the company is resilient and flexible, with global oil demand expected to reach 99 million barrels a day by the end of the year.

site_title: Sabana Reit again rejects EGM requisition over appointment of director
summary: Sabana Reit will not hold an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to endorse the appointment of independent non-executive director Chan Wai Kheong, despite a joint requisition from Quarz Capital and Black Crane Capital. The Reit manager believes seeking unitholder endorsement at the next annual general meeting is in their best interest, allowing them to focus on improving performance. The manager is "puzzled" by the objections to Mr. Chan's suitability, as he was one of Quarz's proposed nominees.

site_title: Singapore in 'more resilient position' due to higher vaccination rate, says PM Lee
summary: Singapore is in a "more resilient position" due to its higher vaccination rate, said Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. The country's vaccination program has led to over 85% of the elderly receiving at least one dose, and more than two-thirds of residents being fully vaccinated. Despite some areas where the government "could have done better" in managing the pandemic, Singapore has kept everyone safe, with very few lives lost to Covid-19. The country is now poised to carefully re-open its economy, moving towards a new normal.

site_title: ecoWise's EGM resolutions, even if passed, will not be valid: board
summary: ecoWise Holdings has announced that resolutions passed at its proposed EGM on Aug 13 will be deemed invalid due to "valid notice not having been given" for the meeting. The company cited a lack of compliance with regulations regarding notice periods and the classification of proposed resolutions. The proposed removal of executive director Cao Shixuan and appointment of three new directors were deemed invalid, as the notice did not specify the effect of the proposed resolutions. The company's shares have been suspended from trading since June 18, 2021.

site_title: Five more Covid-19 cases linked to CHIJ Katong Convent cluster; eight patients in ICU
summary: Singapore reported 73 new locally transmitted coronavirus cases on Sunday, including 21 unlinked cases. The total number of active clusters is now 130, with eight patients in ICU, up from four the previous day. Five more Covid-19 cases were linked to the CHIJ Katong Convent cluster, taking the total to eight. Over 3.8 million people in Singapore have been fully vaccinated, and vaccination efforts continue to show evidence in preventing serious disease.

site_title: Institutional investors return to S-Reits in Q32021
summary: Institutional investors returned to the Singapore Reit (S-Reit) sector in Q32021, with seven S-Reits in the Straits Times Index (STI) generating an average total return of 5.2% in the third quarter, outperforming the STI's 1.6% gain. Top performers included Keppel DC Reit, Ascendas Reit, and Mapletree Industrial Trust, with net inflows of S$54.1 million from institutional investors in July 2021. The sector's outperformance extended to the broader S-Reits and property trusts sector, with the iEdge S-Reit Index generating a 3.6% total return since June.

site_title: Thousands of homes, farms hit by floods in North Korea: state TV
summary: North Korea reported over 1,000 damaged homes and 5,000 evacuated residents due to flooding caused by heavy rains in the South Hamgyong Province. Thousands of hectares of farmland were also affected, with river levees collapsing. The country's food crisis worsened, with a forecast of a 860,000-tonne food shortage this year. The floods come as North Korea faces a moribund agricultural sector and weak infrastructure, making it vulnerable to natural disasters.

site_title: Axington's proposed acquisition of Web technology firm falls through
summary: Axington's proposed S$405 million acquisition of Veivo Web Technology, a Hong Kong-based web technology firm, has fallen through due to discussions failing to materialize in the past month. The acquisition, expected to result in a reverse takeover of Axington, has lapsed as the memorandum of understanding (MOU) has expired. The company will not pay the minimum S$30 million in cash and issue new shares at S$0.19 per share as planned. The lapse is not expected to have a significant impact on Axington's financial performance.

site_title: Show appreciation to Covid-19 frontliners, selfless Singaporeans this National Day: President
summary: President Halimah Yacob urged Singaporeans to show appreciation to Covid-19 frontliners and selfless individuals who have helped others during the pandemic. She encouraged those who haven't been vaccinated, especially seniors, to get vaccinated soon. Singapore has made significant progress in vaccination coverage, with over two-thirds of the population fully vaccinated. The government also announced the easing of restrictions over the next few weeks, aiming to adapt and manage the disease while protecting the nation.

site_title: White House says 50% of Americans fully vaccinated against Covid-19
summary: The White House announced that 50% of the US population, or approximately 165 million people, are now fully vaccinated against Covid-19. This increase comes in response to the surging Delta variant. The vaccination milestone marks a significant step in the country's efforts to combat the pandemic.

site_title: Time to get personal about personal finance
summary: A recent survey by Franklin Templeton found that young Singaporeans (18-35) are eager to invest but anxious about making the right decisions due to limited budgets, fear of losses, and lack of investment knowledge. Experts suggest that personal finance begins with defining one's goals and values, rather than comparing oneself to others. They emphasize the importance of freedom, control, and autonomy in investing, and advise against taking unnecessary risks. Financial professionals also highlight the need for financial education, literacy, and access to unbiased advice to empower individuals in achieving financial independence.

site_title: QSR Malaysia's fast food giant QSR revives IPO plan: report
summary: Malaysia's largest fast food chain operator QSR Brands (M) Holdings Bhd has revived plans for an initial public offering (IPO) worth hundreds of millions of dollars. The IPO, which was initially attempted in 2019, was shelved due to investors deeming its valuation too lofty. QSR, which operates KFC and Pizza Hut franchises, has engaged Maybank Investment Bank and RHB Investment Bank as advisors. The company's controlling shareholder, Johor Corp, is seeking to raise around RM2 billion (S$642 million).

site_title: Unvaccinated 63-year-old Singaporean man dies of Covid-19; Jem among 5 new clusters
summary: A 63-year-old unvaccinated Singaporean man died of Covid-19 complications on Thursday, August 5, bringing the total deaths to 41. The Ministry of Health reported five new clusters, including one at Jem mall in Jurong East, with 126 active clusters and 65,605 total cases. The number of new cases fell to 97, with 93 locally transmitted and four imported, and hospital cases decreased to 546.

site_title: 'Real progress' for lower-wage workers is essential part of inclusive growth: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for "real progress" for lower-wage workers to achieve inclusive growth, citing the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic's impact on this group. He also addressed concerns over foreign work-pass holders, acknowledging the competition for jobs but stressing the benefits of a skills-based economy. Additionally, Lee highlighted the importance of managing issues of race and religion, citing recent racist incidents but emphasizing the need for mutual understanding and respect. The government will continue to address these issues through a tripartite workgroup and policies to support lower-wage workers and integrate foreign workers into Singaporean society.

site_title: Sydney posts fresh Covid-19 record as Melbourne races to trace outbreak
summary: Australia's New South Wales reported a record 319 community Covid-19 cases on Saturday, with five more deaths. Melbourne is tracing the source of its outbreak, which has led to lockdowns in three major cities. Despite a seventh week of lockdown in Sydney, authorities urge residents to stay at home and express frustration at people ignoring restrictions. Australia's vaccine hesitancy remains a challenge, with just over 20% of the population fully vaccinated. The nation's "Covid zero" policy is being questioned as lockdowns struggle to contain the Delta variant.

images.alt_text: Australia's state of New South Wales reported another record day of Covid-19 cases on Saturday, as authorities in the country's second city of Melbourne rushed to trace the source of its outbreaks.

site_title: Tencent will inspect WeChat's 'youth mode' after prosecutors initiate lawsuit
summary: Tencent has announced it will investigate WeChat's "youth mode" after Beijing prosecutors initiated a civil lawsuit claiming the feature does not comply with laws protecting minors. The lawsuit was filed by a subsidiary of Tencent against Shenzhen Tencent Computer Systems Co Ltd, citing concerns over the app's limitations on young users. WeChat's "youth mode" limits access to some games and functions, and the investigation will also consider user suggestions and responses to the lawsuit.

site_title: China's July export slowdown may signal more bumps ahead
summary: China's July export growth unexpectedly slowed to 19.3% from a year earlier, driven by new Covid-19 cases, lockdowns, and floods affecting industrial production. Despite a strong economic rebound from the pandemic, the slowdown in exports may signal a slowdown in the country's industrial sector in the second half. Imports also lost momentum, lagging a 36.7% growth in the previous month. China's trade surplus rose to $56.58 billion in July, but analysts forecast that growth rates are starting to moderate.

images.alt_text: Containers stacked at Yantian port in Shenzhen. China's exports in July rose 19.3 per cent from a year earlier, compared with a 32.2 per cent gain in June.

site_title: India to scrap retrospective tax law in olive branch to global firms
summary: India has proposed scrapping a retrospective tax law that taxed companies retrospectively, potentially settling multi-billion-dollar tax cases with Cairn Energy and Vodafone. The amendment will nullify taxes on indirect transfer of Indian assets before May 2012 if companies withdraw litigation and give an undertaking to not claim damages. This move aims to boost investor confidence, resolving at least 17 disputes worth 500 billion rupees, and could help India's economic recovery. The government will refund disputed amounts but not interest owed to them.

site_title: China July trade surplus with United States at US$35.4b
summary: China's trade surplus with the US reached US$35.4 billion in July, up from US$32.58 billion in June. The surplus for the first seven months of the year stands at US$200.32 billion. Amid worsening US-China relations, a July meeting between US Deputy Secretary of State Wendy Sherman and Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi did not yield specific outcomes. The lack of progress in US-China relations raises concerns about the country's economic outlook, as China's GDP growth is expected to slow.

site_title: China's export slowdown in July may signal more bumps ahead
summary: China's export growth unexpectedly slowed in July, rising 19.3% from a year earlier, due to outbreaks of Covid-19 cases and global semiconductor shortages. Imports also lost momentum, lagging forecasts. The slowdown may signal a slowdown in the country's industrial sector in the second half. Analysts predict China's economy will continue to grow, but at a slower pace, with growth rates moderating. The country's trade surplus with the US rose to $35.4 billion, but overall growth is expected to exceed 8% this year.

site_title: US charges two in plot to attack Myanmar's anti-junta UN envoy
summary: US prosecutors have charged two Myanmar citizens, Phyo Hein Htut, 28, and Ye Hein Zaw, 20, for allegedly plotting to attack and kill the country's UN ambassador, Kyaw Moe Tun, who supports the democracy movement. The plot, foiled by US investigators, involved hiring assailants to force Kyaw Moe Tun to resign or kill him. The suspects could face up to five years in prison. The charges are the latest in a crackdown on the military regime in Myanmar, which has killed over 900 people since a coup in February.

site_title: ecoWise responds to CEO's allegations; says it 'regrets' the forum he used
summary: ecoWise Holdings has responded to CEO Lee Thiam Seng's allegations that the company acted without his approval, stating it "regrets" the forum used by Lee to voice his disagreements. The company's majority directors said they followed internal processes in relation to the termination of Zico Capital, a sponsor that was let go without Lee's consent. The company also defended its decision not to announce an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) convened by shareholders, citing a Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) notice of compliance that required the company to adopt safeguards to fulfill regulatory requirements.

site_title: Oil falls in biggest weekly decline in months on demand worries
summary: Oil prices fell 1% on Friday, posting the biggest weekly decline in months, due to worries about travel restrictions to curb the spread of the Delta variant of Covid-19, which may derail global energy demand. Brent crude oil futures fell 59 cents to $70.70, while US WTI crude futures dropped 81 cents to $68.28. The decline was also attributed to a stronger dollar and concerns over the global recovery. Global oil demand is expected to be impacted by travel restrictions in China and Japan, and US President Joe Biden warned of rising Covid-19 cases.

site_title: Does the law of gravity apply to financial markets?
summary: Investors often mistakenly apply the law of gravity to financial markets, believing that a market peak will inevitably lead to a decline. However, empirical evidence from historical data shows that markets often continue to rise after reaching an all-time high, with an average of 14% of trading days featuring a new high. This trend has persisted for 13 years since the Global Financial Crisis, with only one year experiencing a decline. Focusing on long-term compounding and avoiding short-term market fluctuations can lead to better investment outcomes, rather than trying to time the market.

site_title: ExxonMobil suspended from climate advocacy group it helped form
summary: ExxonMobil was suspended from the Climate Leadership Council (CLC) for its perceived lack of commitment to addressing climate change. The decision comes after an Exxon lobbyist stated that a carbon tax would not gain enough political support, contradicting the company's CEO. ExxonMobil was a founding member of the CLC, but will continue to be part of the Alliance for Market Solutions. The CLC's CEO stated that Exxon's actions are "not aligned" with the council's goals, and the World Resources Institute called for companies to support a price on carbon.

site_title: Europe: Stellar earnings fuel stocks to best week in nearly five months
summary: European stocks reached a record high for the fifth straight day, closing at 469.97 points, driven by strong quarterly earnings from major banks and energy companies. The Stoxx 600 index gained 1.8% for the week, with bank stocks leading the way at 4.4% and energy stocks advancing 3.6%. Analysts at UBS attributed the rally to positive business survey data and expectations of a global economic rebound.

site_title: Two plead guilty to assaulting police officers in attack on US Capitol
summary: Two individuals, Scott Fairlamb and Devlyn Thompson, have pleaded guilty to assaulting police officers during the January 6 attack on the US Capitol. Fairlamb, a 44-year-old New Jersey gym owner, faces up to 4.5 years in prison for assaulting a policeman, while Thompson, 28, from Washington state, could get up to 20 years for his role in the attack. Both men have also pleaded guilty to other charges, including obstructing an official proceeding. Over 570 people have been arrested and charged in relation to the attack, with many more facing severe felony charges.

site_title: US job growth exceeds forecast as unemployment rate falls
summary: US employers added 943,000 jobs in July, exceeding forecasts, with the unemployment rate falling to 5.4% as the labor market continues to recover. The labor force participation rate edged up to 61.7%, but companies struggle to fill vacant positions due to ongoing pandemic concerns and generous unemployment benefits. The stronger labor recovery could impact President Biden's long-term social measures proposal and Fed officials may consider tapering asset purchases if the labor market continues to gain momentum.

site_title: GK Goh to sell Boardroom stake to Temasek-related consortium for S$312m
summary: GK Goh Holdings is selling its 92% stake in corporate-services provider Boardroom to a Temasek-related consortium for approximately S$312 million. The deal values Boardroom at around S$312 million, with the consortium offering S$1.48828 per share. The sale is part of GKGH's plan to maximize shareholder value and position Boardroom for growth. The disposal will be subject to shareholder approval, and GKGH will continue to own aged care and healthcare businesses.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 end at records after strong jobs data
summary: US stocks closed at fresh records on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 finishing up 0.4% and 0.2% respectively, despite a decline in the Nasdaq. The economy added 943,000 new jobs in July, lowering the unemployment rate to 5.4%. Strong jobs data is expected to accelerate the Federal Reserve's timeline to scale back stimulus initiatives, potentially leading to a stronger jobs market in 2022. Financial shares led the market, while travel stocks fell due to ongoing uncertainty from the Delta variant.

site_title: Finances don't add up, but can Barcelona and La Liga afford not to keep Messi?
