site_title: Brokers' take: Best is over for Sheng Siong as supermarket dash eases, analysts say
summary: Analysts at Maybank Kim Eng, RHB, and Phillip Securities have downgraded Sheng Siong Group due to its earnings retreat from the year-ago high base. The supermarket operator reported an 11.9% drop in net profit and an 8.8% decline in revenue for the first half of 2021. Analysts attribute the decline to the easing of the "supermarket dash" amid Singapore's vaccination efforts, with future sales and profitability expected to normalize as the economy resumes normal activities.

site_title: Credit Bureau Asia to enter Vietnam with financial data provider FiinGroup
summary: Credit Bureau Asia has signed a memorandum of understanding to enter Vietnam with financial data provider FiinGroup, forming a joint venture to provide analytics and data solutions to financial institutions. The partnership aims to support credit-granting institutions and data companies, with plans to establish a private credit bureau by the end of 2021. Credit Bureau Asia's founder and executive chairman, Kevin Koo, and FiinGroup's chairman and CEO, Nguyen Quang Thuan, expressed optimism about the partnership, citing opportunities for growth in the analytics and data solutions space.

site_title: Shops at Changi Business Park area forced to shut amid low footfall due to work-from-home measures
summary: Shops at the Changi Business Park area, known as "the east's central business district," have been forced to shut due to low footfall caused by work-from-home measures. Business has fallen by 70-80% as employees stay at home, with some merchants unable to withstand rental pressure. To mitigate the issue, landlords and the mall are implementing marketing plans, digital measures, and rent rebates. Despite the challenges, some landlords remain optimistic, expecting companies to prefer office areas with cheaper rents, and anticipate an increase in tenants as vaccination rates rise and restrictions ease.

site_title: Ferrari delivers solid earnings ahead of new CEO's arrival
summary: Ferrari delivered solid earnings ahead of its new CEO's arrival, with adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization rising to 386 million euros in the second quarter. The company slightly missed revenue expectations but boosted its annual free cash flow forecast. Ferrari has been slow to adopt electrification, but its new CEO, Benedetto Vigna, aims to put the company on course for the era of battery technology and digital services. The company will unveil its first battery-powered vehicle in 2025 and start sales of its first SUV in 2022.

site_title: Singapore Purchasing Managers' Index picks up to 51.0 in July on rosy factory sentiment, but Delta variant hammers regional sector
summary: Singapore's factory sector saw a 0.2-point increase in its Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) to 51.0 in July, its highest score since December 2018, driven by rosy factory sentiment. The electronics industry, a key sector, also experienced 12 consecutive months of growth. The PMI readings above 50 indicate expansion, while those below 50 signify contraction. This positive trend suggests the country's economy is on the path to recovery, despite regional challenges posed by the Delta variant.

site_title: MOH apologises for slow conveyance in quarantine orders, communication lapses
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore has apologized for slow conveyance in quarantine orders and communication lapses during the recent surge in COVID-19 cases. The backlog was cleared over the weekend, with the MOH ramping up quarantine operations to handle the increased load. The surge led to slower conveyance to government quarantine facilities and communication gaps for some individuals under quarantine. The MOH has also introduced measures to reduce the need for conveyancing, including allowing individuals to serve home quarantine if their homes are suitable.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rally after last week's major losses
summary: Hong Kong shares rallied on Monday, recovering from last week's losses as investors snapped up bargains. The Hang Seng Index rose 1.06% to 26,235.80, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also climbed 1.97% and 2.15%, respectively. The rally comes despite concerns over China's crackdown on tech and private tuition firms.

site_title: No buy-the-dip for STI; most Asian markets rally
summary: The Singapore stock market, one of the few in Asia to close in the red on Monday, saw most Asian markets rally despite industrial activity data from China. The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 0.18% due to concerns over operational risks at Aztech Global. However, other markets such as Hong Kong's Hang Seng, Shanghai Composite, and Nikkei 225 rose, with foreign investors pumping in nearly a billion dollars into the Hong Kong to Shanghai/Shenzhen Connect.

site_title: One-off loan conversion boosts OUE Lippo Healthcare's H1 profit to S$113.8m
summary: CATALIST-LISTED OUE Lippo Healthcare reported a net profit of S$113.8 million for the six months ended June, boosted by a one-off S$110 million gain from a shareholder loan conversion. Excluding the gain, the company posted a S$3.67 million net profit, reversing the year-ago loss. Revenue dipped 2% year-on-year to S$9.67 million due to the weaker Japanese yen to Singapore dollar.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes up more than 1.8%
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index rose 1.82% to 27,781.02, driven by investors buying on dips ahead of corporate earnings this week. The broader Topix index also advanced 2.05%. The gains follow a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and fresh records in the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts trim Aztech Global's target prices on component shortage risks
summary: Analysts at DBS and CGS-CIMB have lowered their target prices for Aztech Global due to operational risks from component shortages. Despite the company's net profit more than doubling to S$29.4 million in the first half, analysts remain cautious, citing industry-wide shortages and higher component prices. The lower target prices reflect concerns about Aztech's ability to secure components, which could impact its gross margin. The company's order book growth continues to be strong, but securing components remains a challenge.

site_title: European factories on a hiring binge as orders go up
summary: European factories are hiring at a record pace to meet strong orders, with job creation particularly pronounced in Germany and Austria. Despite supply-chain bottlenecks and rising costs, confidence in the euro area's outlook remains high, with the International Monetary Fund raising its economic forecasts. The European Central Bank expects a "strong" increase in output in the current quarter, but warns of risks from resurgent infections and supply constraints. Manufacturers face substantial input costs and selling prices, with new orders and backlogs of work increasing. The euro area's economic sentiment gauge reached its highest level since 1985.

site_title: Hot stock: iFast up 8% on finalisation of Hong Kong pension contract
summary: iFast Corporation shares jumped 8% on Monday after finalizing its Hong Kong pension project contract, which the company expects to have a "very material financial impact" from 2023. The contract, won by PCCW Solutions, will see iFast as the prime subcontractor for MPF scheme operation services. The shares reached a high of S$8.66 before easing to S$8.57.

site_title: Virus flares in Wuhan as Delta variant challenges China's defences
summary: China is facing its largest Covid-19 outbreak since the virus emerged in 2019, with the Delta variant spreading rapidly across the country, including the original epicentre of Wuhan. Over 300 cases have been reported, with the variant reaching nearly half of China's 32 provinces in two weeks. China's strict anti-virus measures have been breached, with the Delta variant exploiting easing of masking and social distancing measures in some areas. The country's vaccination rate is around 60%, but its locally-developed shots have been found less effective against Delta, with only 4% of infected cases experiencing severe disease.

site_title: Singapore to receive Novavax vaccine by end-2021; Sinovac vaccine evaluation to be completed before month-end
summary: Singapore is set to receive the Novavax vaccine by the end of 2021, with the Health Sciences Authority (HSA) evaluating the Sinovac-CoronaVac vaccine completion by the end of August. Individuals who have had allergic reactions to mRNA Covid-19 vaccines are being offered the Sinovac vaccine, with those who complete the vaccination process considered fully vaccinated. As of July 31, 61% of the population has completed the full vaccination regimen, with efforts underway to reach out to seniors who have not booked appointments.

site_title: Small but connected: How Singapore stands its ground as a global logistics hub
summary: Singapore has maintained its position as a global logistics hub despite the COVID-19 pandemic, handling 36.9 million TEUs of containers in 2020 and retaining its position as the world's largest bunkering port. The country's strong infrastructure, connectivity, and technology have enabled it to facilitate the flow of goods and services, with plans to double cargo handling capacity at Changi Airport and build the Tuas mega port. Singapore's network of Free Trade Agreements has also boosted its draw for companies, with 13 bilateral and 11 regional FTAs covering 60% of the world's GDP.

images.alt_text: While the Covid-19 pandemic has been a litmus test for the local logistics sector, Singapore has stepped up boldly to the challenge, with an eye on the future: Christopher Ong, managing director for DHL Express Singapore.

site_title: BT Explains: Keppel's bid to take SPH private
summary: Keppel Corporation has announced a surprise bid to take Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) private, valuing the media and property group at S$3.4 billion. The proposed deal, which will be approved by SPH and Keppel shareholders, includes a total consideration of S$2.099 per share, representing a 39.9% premium to SPH's last traded price. The deal will cast more light on the restructuring of SPH's media business, which will be transferred into a company limited by guarantee. Keppel will consolidate ownership in its existing partnerships with SPH and gain indirect ownership of 20% of SPH Reit, a real estate investment trust (REIT) that owns commercial properties in Singapore and Australia.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 1.60 points lower at 1,493.00 on Monday, with 594 losers outnumbering 440 gainers. The index saw a trading volume of 3.429 billion lots worth RM2.380 billion.

site_title: Europe: M&A frenzy, earnings power stocks to new highs
summary: European stocks reached new highs on Monday, driven by a flurry of mergers and acquisitions, as well as strong results from HSBC and Axa. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.8% to a record 465 points, with Meggitt and HSBC leading the gains. Axa's 180% surge in first-half net income also contributed to the rally. Meanwhile, the US stock market continued its upward trend, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What happened today
summary: Keppel Corporation made a S$3.4 billion offer to privatise Singapore Press Holdings' non-media business through a scheme of arrangement, contingent on media restructuring. Singapore expects to receive the Novavax vaccine by the end of 2021 and will complete the evaluation of the Sinovac-CoronaVac vaccine by August. SP Group partnered with BCG Energy on a solar project in Vietnam, and Matrixport raised over US$100m in its Series C round. The Singapore stock market closed in the red on Monday, with most Asian markets rallying instead.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS downgrades Dairy Farm International to 'hold', lowers target price to US$3.96
summary: DBS Group Research downgraded Dairy Farm International to "hold" and lowered its target price to US$3.96, citing weaker-than-expected performance and normalising demand in the grocery retail business. The research team expects challenges in the convenience stores segment due to a potential lockdown in China and lower margins in the online channel. However, the health and beauty segment is expected to see a sharp recovery when travel resumes between China and Hong Kong, and the home furnishing segment is expected to perform better in the second half of 2021.

site_title: Landmark S$3.4b deal paves way for SPH restructuring, enlarges Keppel's footprint
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) has agreed to a S$3.4 billion deal with Keppel Corp, allowing Keppel to expand its asset base and earnings. SPH shareholders will receive a total consideration of S$2.099 per share, representing an 11.6% premium over SPH's last close. The deal will result in SPH delisting and becoming a wholly-owned subsidiary of Keppel, with the media business restructuring expected to be completed in December. Analysts have welcomed the deal, citing synergies between the two companies and a potential win-win solution for both parties.

images.alt_text: The S$3.4 billion deal announced by two of Singapore's most established companies, Keppel Corp and Singapore Press Holdings (SPH), would allow the former to grow its asset base and earnings.

site_title: Lion-OCBC Securities China Leaders ETF up 1.5% on SGX debut
summary: The Lion-OCBC Securities China Leaders ETF debuted on the Singapore Stock Exchange (SGX) with a 1.5% gain, reaching a high of S$2.029. The China-focused ETF tracks the Hang Seng Stock Connect China 80 Index and will pay annual dividends to investors. The listing comes amid volatility in the Hang Seng Index, following Beijing's measures to tighten its grip on the economy. Notable companies in the index include Tencent, Kweichow Moutai, and Meituan, which have faced regulatory challenges.

site_title: Australia's deal boom set to intensify on cheap cash, pandemic confidence: bankers
summary: Australia's merger-and-acquisition (M&A) boom is expected to intensify due to low interest rates and pandemic confidence. The country saw its highest-ever M&A year in 2021, with deals like Square's $29 billion purchase of Afterpay and Oil Search's $6.2 billion takeover bid from Santos. The market is likely to continue with record deal activity, driven by confidence in the economy's recovery from the pandemic.

site_title: Xi Jinping's capitalist smackdown sparks a US$1t reckoning
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping is implementing a policy shift, prioritizing social stability and national security over investor interests. The crackdown on private tutoring companies has erased $1.5 trillion from Chinese stocks, affecting tech billionaires and foreign venture capital firms. Xi's vision, dubbed "progressive authoritarianism," aims to curb inequalities and ensure common prosperity, with a focus on the squeezed middle class. The policy response has triggered a realization that the old rules of Chinese business no longer apply, and investors are struggling to adapt. Xi's motivation is also driven by the upcoming leadership transition and growing discontent among the population.

site_title: HSBC profit more than doubles as economies rebound, loan-loss fears ebb
summary: HSBC Holdings reported a 126% increase in first-half pretax profit to $10.8 billion, exceeding analyst estimates. The bank reinstated dividend payments and released $700 million set aside for potential bad loans, down from $6.9 billion last year. Revenue fell 4% due to low interest rates. HSBC expects credit losses to be below its medium-term forecast of 0.3-0.4% of loans, and may even make a net release of funds from earlier provisions. The bank plans to pay an interim dividend of seven cents per share.

site_title: SPH offer: Keppel eyeing Reit for student housing business; other assets could also be monetised
summary: Keppel Corp is proposing to acquire Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) for S$2.24 billion, with the option to sell non-core assets within three years, including SPH's student housing business, which could be securitized into a Reit. This deal is part of Keppel's asset-light strategy, which has already led to S$2.3 billion in deals. The acquisition is expected to be completed by the end of the year, with SPH shareholders receiving S$1.2 billion in Reit units. The move is seen as a way for Keppel to create fee income opportunities and reduce net gearing.

site_title: Evergrande stock rises after HK$3.25b stake sale in Internet unit
summary: Evergrande Group shares rose 8.6% in Hong Kong trading after the company announced a HK$3.25 billion (S$566.5 million) stake sale in its Internet unit, HengTen. The sale, part of efforts to ease funding pressure, reduced Evergrande's stake to 26.55% and Tencent's holdings to 23.9%. The move follows a 65% year-to-date drop in Evergrande's shares and comes amid concerns over the developer's financial health and access to funds.

site_title: Synergies in Keppel's SPH buyout win analysts' favour
summary: Keppel Corp has won analysts' favor with its proposed S$2.24 billion privatisation bid of Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) without the media business. Analyst Lim Siew Khee praised the deal for visible synergies between Keppel and SPH, citing its ability to expedite monetising selected assets due to its larger size. This move is seen as a positive development for Keppel, following a successful year for the diversified firm.

site_title: Malaysian opposition MPs march to Parliament, demand PM quit
summary: Malaysian opposition lawmakers marched to the Parliament building, demanding Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin's resignation due to the spread of Covid-19. The opposition claims the government has collapsed, citing the Health Director-General's warning of a high-risk environment for infection spread. The five-day session was postponed indefinitely, and protesters have called for the resignation of Muhyiddin, who has faced public anger over his handling of the pandemic.

site_title: Singapore-based crypto startup Matrixport raises over US$100m in Series C round
summary: Singapore-based crypto startup Matrixport has raised over $100 million in its Series C funding round, valuing the company at $1 billion. The round was led by DST Global, C Ventures, and K3 Ventures, with existing backers and new investors participating. The startup, led by Bitmain Technologies' billionaire founder Wu Jihan, aims to expand its crypto financial services and hold hundreds of billions of dollars in assets under management within five years. Matrixport plans to go public in three to five years to offer investors an exit.

site_title: SP Group partners BCG Energy on solar project in Vietnam
summary: SP Group has partnered with BCG Energy on a joint venture to invest in rooftop solar and renewable energy projects in Vietnam. The JV aims to develop 500MW of rooftop projects by 2025, contributing to Vietnam's goal of 30% renewable energy by 2030. The first project will be a 25MW rooftop solar installation for Vinamilk, generating 35,000MWh of clean electricity and reducing 32,000 tonnes of annual carbon emissions. The partnership is seen as a key milestone for SP Group's entry into the Vietnamese market and promotes the use of clean energy in manufacturing companies.

site_title: Singapore business leaders on the same page as 'born digital' employees: study
summary: Singapore business leaders overwhelmingly support flexible work, with 78% in favor compared to 50% globally. This aligns with the preferences of "born digital" employees, indicating a shared understanding of workplace priorities among the Born Digital generation in Singapore. The study, conducted by Citrix and Milieu Insights, highlights a convergence of business leaders and young professionals on key workplace issues.

site_title: Quarz, Black Crane again requisition Sabana Reit EGM over appointment of director
summary: Quarz Capital and Black Crane Capital have requisitioned an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) for Sabana Shari'ah Compliant Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit) to endorse the appointment of hedge fund founder Chan Wai Kheong as an independent non-executive director. The two firms, holding over 10% of Sabana Reit's listed units, claim Chan's substantial holdings in a competitor and his previous sale of shares in another company pose a conflict of interest. Sabana Reit's manager has rejected the requisition, citing the lack of grounds for the objections and stating that Chan's appointment is subject to endorsement by the Reit's independent unitholders at the annual meeting.

site_title: Hot stock: Rex International rises 7.1% in early trade
summary: Rex International's shares surged 7.1% in early trade, reaching a high of 22.5 cents, with 26.2 million shares changing hands. The company's heavy trading is attributed to rising crude prices and its acquisition of an oil field in Norway. Analysts from KGI Securities initiated a "outperform" recommendation, citing Rex's strong balance sheet and potential for record free cash flows. The analysts praise the company's diversification into the commercial drone business, positioning it for a "coming-of-age" as an independent.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.81% and the Topix index advancing 0.88%. Investors are cautiously watching corporate earnings due this week.

site_title: Australia: Afterpay lifts shares to record close
summary: Australian stocks reached a record close, with the ASX 200 index rising 1.3% to 7,491.4, driven by Afterpay's 19.5% gain after a US$29 billion buyout by Square, creating a global transactions giant. This is the country's largest ever deal, boosting peers in the industry. The benchmark index closed at a new high, with Afterpay's shares leading the charge, sending the company's valuation past $1 billion.

site_title: Australia cranks up Covid curbs with Brisbane lockdown extended, army patrols in Sydney
summary: Australia has extended a Covid-19 lockdown in Brisbane, its third-biggest city, until late Sunday, amid a surge in new locally acquired cases. Soldiers began patrolling Sydney to enforce stay-at-home rules, as the country struggles to contain the highly contagious Delta variant. The lockdown follows a record 13 new cases in 24 hours, with Queensland's vaccination drive lagging behind other developed economies. Prime Minister Scott Morrison aims to reach 70% vaccination coverage by the end of the year to ease lockdowns.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares start the week higher
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.83 points, or 0.32%, to 1,499.43 at 9:18am Monday, driven by higher shares. Volume reached 104.5 million lots worth RM38.9 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 208 to 107.

site_title: Gold eases as US dollar holds ground
summary: Gold prices fell 0.2% to $1,809.21 per ounce as the US dollar held steady, despite concerns about a slowdown in the global economy. The Federal Reserve is expected to start reducing its monthly bond purchases and potentially raise interest rates in 2022. China's factory activity expanded at the slowest pace in 17 months, while US infectious disease expert Anthony Fauci warned of rising virus cases. Speculators cut their net-long positions in gold and silver, and prices retreated from a two-week peak.

site_title: Descartes Underwriting opening in Singapore and Sydney to target Asia-Pacific
summary: Descartes Underwriting, a Paris-based insurtech company, is opening offices in Singapore and Sydney to expand its parametric insurance against climate risks in the Asia-Pacific region. The company, founded in 2018, aims to provide cost-effective and transparent products to supplement gaps in traditional insurance. With US$200 million in capacity per policy, Descartes will collaborate with brokers to protect corporate and public sector clients against natural catastrophe and extreme weather exposures. The move follows record-breaking weather events in the region and rising economic losses due to climate change.

images.alt_text: Tanguy Touffut, CEO and co-founder of Descartes Underwriting.

site_title: Singapore stocks open slightly higher on Monday; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.1% to 3,170.33 on Monday, driven by strong earnings on Wall Street and gains in local shares such as Rex International, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, and Sembcorp Marine. The US market closed lower on Friday due to Amazon's lower sales forecast and concerns about the Delta variant. European shares slipped to record lows, while Tokyo stocks opened higher in cautious trade ahead of corporate earnings.

site_title: Great Eastern Q2 profit falls 22% to S$232.2m amid less favourable market conditions
summary: Great Eastern Holdings reported a 22% decline in Q2 net profit to S$232.2 million, primarily due to less favourable market conditions. Operating profit fell 20% to S$148 million, while non-operating profit decreased 2% to S$34.9 million. Total weighted new sales rose 88% to S$535.9 million, driven by a low base effect. The company's net profit for the half-year more than doubled to S$669.9 million. Despite this, shares closed 0.09% lower at S$21.59.

site_title: US senators finalise details of US$1t infrastructure plan
summary: US senators have finalized a $1 trillion infrastructure plan, including $550 billion in new spending over five years, to invest in roads, bridges, ports, and high-speed internet. The bill, a top priority for President Joe Biden, aims to boost public transit and ease supply bottlenecks contributing to inflation. While some Democrats have criticized the plan as too small, others, including Senator Susan Collins, believe at least 10 Republicans will support it, potentially clearing a 60-vote procedural hurdle. The bill must now be considered in the House of Representatives, where its fate is uncertain.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares up at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks began Monday's session with a 0.36% gain, following a rally across Asia. The Hang Seng Index rose 93.78 points to 26,054.81, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.34% to 3,385.69. The rally comes after last week's losses due to concerns over China's regulatory crackdown.

site_title: Keppel makes surprise S$2.2b bid to privatise SPH
summary: Keppel Corp has made a surprise S$2.2 billion bid to privatise Singapore Press Holdings (SPH), describing it as a "rare" opportunity to tap SPH's quality portfolio and speed up growth. The deal sits on familiar grounds for Keppel, with strong expertise in asset management, urban development, and connectivity. The privatization could unlock value in SPH's purpose-built student accommodation business, potentially leading to a Reit listing or private fund vehicle in the future.

images.alt_text: Keppel's data centre in Tampines. The proposed deal will bump up Keppel's consolidated earnings per share as at end-2020 on a pro forma basis to 32.3 Singapore cents a share from 27.8 cents.

site_title: Keppel offers to privatise SPH at S$3.4b valuation; contingent on media business carve-out
summary: Keppel Corporation has made a S$3.4 billion offer to privatize Singapore Press Holdings' (SPH) non-media business through a scheme of arrangement, contingent on media business carve-out. The deal values SPH at S$3.4 billion, with Keppel's share totaling S$2.2 billion. SPH shareholders will receive S$2.099 per share, comprising cash and Keppel Reit units. The scheme requires approval from both SPH and Keppel shareholders, and will result in SPH becoming a wholly owned subsidiary of Keppel.

site_title: Sembcorp flags S$212m impairment for H1
summary: Sembcorp Industries has flagged a S$212 million impairment for its H1 2021 financial results, despite expecting a positive net profit. The conglomerate's 49%-owned joint venture in China, Chongqing Songzao Sembcorp Electric Power, is expected to record a net loss for H1 and the full year 2021 due to higher coal prices and government restrictions. Sembcorp also faces long-term competitive pressure from low-carbon power sources. The company will announce its H1 results on August 6.

site_title: China's July factory activity growth slips to 15-month low: Caixin PMI
summary: China's factory activity growth slipped to a 15-month low in July, with the Caixin/Markit Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 50.3. This is the lowest level since April 2020, driven by high product prices and demand contraction for the first time in over a year. The Chinese economy faces challenges such as rising raw material costs and commodity price surges, which squeezed manufacturers' margins. Analysts expect the economy to slow, putting pressure on policymakers to curb these challenges.

site_title: Oil prices slide on worries over China economy and higher crude output
summary: Oil prices fell by more than $1 on Monday due to concerns over China's economy, with Brent crude oil futures dropping 1.5% to $74.29 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures falling 1.3% to $72.98 a barrel. China's factory activity growth slipped sharply in July, and a Reuters survey found that oil output from Opec producers rose in July to its highest since April 2020. The decline in oil prices is attributed to worries about a significant decline in the global outlook if China's economic recovery slows down.

site_title: Elite Commercial Reit posts H1 DPU of 2.63 pence, 8.7% above IPO projection
summary: Elite Commercial Reit reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.63 pence for the six-month period ended June 30, a 34.9% increase from the previous year and 8.7% above its initial public offering (IPO) projection of 2.42 pence. Gross revenue rose 70.6% to £15.9 million, exceeding its IPO projection of £11.5 million.

site_title: China's indebted Evergrande to sell stakes in Internet unit for HK$3.25b
summary: Evergrande Group, China's most indebted property developer, agreed to sell stakes in its internet unit HengTen Networks Group for HK$3.25 billion. The sale includes a 7% stake to Tencent Holdings for HK$2.07 billion and a 4% stake to an unidentified buyer for HK$1.18 billion. The move aims to ease pressure on the developer, which has faced concerns over debt and potential systemic financial risk. Fitch downgraded Evergrande's credit rating, citing concerns of a potential default.

images.alt_text: China's most indebted property developer Evergrande Group has agreed to sell stakes in its internet unit HengTen Networks Group worth a total of HK$3.25 billion (S$566.5 million), an exchange filing showed on Sunday.

site_title: Pfizer and Moderna raise prices for Covid-19 vaccines in EU
summary: Pfizer and Moderna have raised prices for their Covid-19 vaccines in the European Union. The new price for Pfizer's vaccine is 19.50 euros (S$31.34) per dose, up from 15.50 euros, while Moderna's vaccine will cost 25.50 US dollars per dose, up from 19 euros. The price increases are part of the companies' latest supply contracts with the European Commission, which aims to fully vaccinate at least 70% of the adult population by the end of the summer. The commission expects to receive over a billion doses of vaccines by the end of September from four drugmakers.

site_title: Square to buy Afterpay for US$29b as buy now, pay later booms
summary: Square Inc will purchase Afterpay for approximately US$29 billion, creating an online payments giant. The deal is Australia's largest-ever buyout, tapping into the explosive growth of the buy now, pay later (BNPL) sector. Afterpay's fiscal 2021 sales nearly tripled in the US, and the acquisition will allow the combined company to expand rapidly in the US market. Square CEO Jack Dorsey stated that the deal will enable the company to deliver more compelling products and services for merchants and consumers.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp, Great Eastern, Sheng Siong, Aspen
summary: Sembcorp Industries flagged an impairment of S$212 million for its Chongqing coal mine joint venture, despite expecting net profit to remain positive. Great Eastern's net profit doubled to S$669.9 million for the half-year period, while Sheng Siong bought a shop unit for a below-market value of S$17.25 million. Aspen Holdings warned of an impending net loss due to significant pre-operating expenses. Trading halts were called for Keppel Corp, Keppel Reit, Singapore Press Holdings, and SPH Reit pending announcements.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: Singapore's government bonds saw a quotation update, but no specific information is provided. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and People's Bank of China (PBOC) plan to deepen their collaboration in green and transition finance. In local news, Helen Wong is set to retire as OCBC CEO, with Tan Teck Long named as her successor. Additionally, Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay increased by 30.5% to S$3.1 million, and Tesla marked its formal entry into the Indian market.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: The perils of holding on to too much cash (Ep 100)
summary: BT Money Hacks, the 100th episode, discusses the importance of investing extra cash instead of saving too much. Co-founder of The Smart Investor, David Kuo, emphasizes that holding onto idle cash can result in lost money. The conversation highlights key points, including the Rule of 100 and 72, low interest rates, and the importance of age and investing plans in determining investment amounts. Listeners share their learned insights from previous episodes, and the hosts stress the need to start investing to avoid losing money due to inactivity.

site_title: US authorities scramble, trade blame as millions face eviction
summary: US authorities scrambled to respond to the expiration of eviction protections, which left millions of Americans at risk of homelessness. The protections, put in place during the COVID-19 pandemic, had expired on Sunday, despite lawmakers failing to extend them. Only $3 billion of the $25 billion allotted for rental aid had been distributed, and over a quarter of renters were behind on rent. Democrats blamed the Biden administration for waiting until the last minute, while Republicans were criticized for not renewing the moratorium. The expiration of the protections has raised concerns about the impact on lower-income Americans and the rising housing costs.

site_title: Vietnam fintech VNLife raises US$250m from investors including GIC, EDBI
summary: VNLife Corp, a Vietnam-based fintech firm, has raised US$250 million in a funding round led by General Atlantic, Dragoneer Investment Group, and SoftBank Vision Fund 1. This round, which included participation from PayPal Ventures, EDBI, and GIC, increases the company's valuation to above US$1 billion. The new capital will be used to fund existing businesses and develop new platforms, according to the company. VNLife's subsidiary VNPay provides e-payment services to numerous banks, telecommunications companies, and businesses.

site_title: Anger as top US Republican jokes about hitting Pelosi
summary: US House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy faced calls to apologize or resign after joking about hitting Speaker Nancy Pelosi with a gavel at a fundraising dinner in Tennessee. The comments escalated tensions between the two, with Democrats condemning the remarks as misogynistic and dangerous. Representative Ted Lieu and others urged McCarthy to apologize or resign, citing past instances of violent rhetoric leading to the US Capitol insurrection. The incident marked a sharp escalation in the deteriorating relations between the Republican minority leader and the chamber's top Democrat.

site_title: Trading halts called for Keppel Corp, Keppel Reit, SPH and SPH Reit
summary: Four Singapore stocks - Keppel Corp, Keppel Reit, SPH, and SPH Reit - called for trading halts on Monday pending announcements, with all four counters closing higher on Friday. The proposed restructuring of SPH, which involves transferring its media business to a company limited by guarantee, may be the reason for the trading halts. Former Cabinet minister Khaw Boon Wan has agreed to be the chairman of the CLG, and SPH and Keppel have several ties, including a joint venture to develop data centre facilities.

site_title: Australia home prices keep rising even as Sydney locks down
summary: Australian home prices rose 1.6% in July, driven by a pandemic-driven shift to working from home, despite a coronavirus lockdown in Sydney curbing auctions. National prices climbed 16.1% from last year, with houses surging 18.4%. The red-hot market has provided a huge windfall to consumer wealth and confidence, but stretched valuations may make affordability more of a drag. Regulators have warned banks not to loosen lending standards, and analysts suspect they could tighten loan rules later this year if the market stays hot.

site_title: Zoom reaches US$85m settlement over user privacy, 'Zoombombing'
summary: Zoom Video Communications Inc has agreed to pay US$85 million to settle a lawsuit claiming it violated users' privacy rights by sharing personal data with Facebook, Google, and LinkedIn, and allowing hackers to disrupt meetings in a practice called Zoombombing. The settlement requires approval by US District Judge Lucy Koh and includes security measures such as alerting users when third-party apps are used in meetings. Subscribers will receive 15% refunds or up to US$25, while others may receive up to US$15.

site_title: US blames Iran for tanker attack, vows 'appropriate response'
summary: The US has blamed Iran for the deadly drone-style attack on an Israeli tanker, the MT Mercer Street, off Oman, killing two crew members. US Secretary of State Antony Blinken stated that Iran conducted the attack and vowed an "appropriate response" would be forthcoming. Britain also accused Iran of deliberately carrying out the attack, violating international law. Iran denied involvement, with a foreign ministry spokesman calling the accusations "baseless."

site_title: Most Integrated Shield portfolios in the black
summary: Singapore's private insurers offering Integrated Shield (IP) policies have reported a turnaround in their underwriting results for 2020, ending years of losses since 2016. This marks a significant improvement for the industry.

site_title: Hydrogen goes nuclear as UK reactor pivots towards renewables
summary: The UK's Sizewell C nuclear station, a $28 billion project aiming to reach net-zero emissions, will pivot towards producing hydrogen as excess energy. This move is part of a broader trend by nuclear developers in Europe, North America, and Russia to utilize hydrogen as a low-carbon outlet for their power. Governments have pledged $70 billion to support the industry, with the goal of reaching climate goals. By producing hydrogen, the nuclear plant can maximize revenue from one of the most expensive energy assets on the planet.

site_title: Myanmar junta chief says new elections to be held in two years
summary: Myanmar's junta chief announced elections will be held in two years, with a state of emergency lifted by August 2023, extending the initial timeline. The military deposed Aung San Suu Kyi in February, leading to a bloody crackdown on dissent that has killed over 900 people. The announcement comes as the country remains in turmoil.

site_title: Scuffles in Berlin as Covid sceptics defy protest ban
summary: Thousands of anti-lockdown demonstrators defied a court-ordered protest ban in Berlin, resulting in scuffles with police. The "Querdenker" movement, which opposes Germany's coronavirus restrictions, gathered despite a ban on 22,500 people. Police deployed over 2,000 officers in riot gear and detained over 600 protesters. The protest was marked by harassment and attacks on officers, with few wearing masks. Germany's domestic intelligence service has placed some Querdenker members under observation over ties to right-wing extremism.

site_title: Young, raring to go - and time to start prepping for retirement
summary: In Singapore, many young individuals are behind on retirement planning, with 3 in 4 behind on their plans. To start, a realistic projection of income flows and expenses is necessary, and dividing projected expenses into needs and wants can help determine when financial freedom can be achieved. Building up guaranteed and non-guaranteed income flows is also crucial. CPF savings offer attractive and risk-free interest, but bank savings alone are inadequate for retirement. Non-guaranteed income, including riskier assets, is equally important to invest for retirement amid inflation risks.

site_title: China's central bank says it will maintain pressure on crypto market
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), will maintain pressure on the cryptocurrency market through regulatory measures, according to a statement released on Saturday. The PBOC will supervise financial platform companies to rectify their practices, following an escalation of the clampdown earlier this year. Policymakers discussed work priorities for the second half of the year, emphasizing the need to regulate cryptocurrency trading and speculation. The move aims to curb market speculation and maintain financial stability.

site_title: Goldman Sachs bets on city bounceback with Paris real estate deal
summary: Goldman Sachs has made a real estate deal in Paris, acquiring a block to transform into upscale stores with office space above. The firm's asset management unit is betting on cities' recovery post-pandemic, expecting a bifurcation between high-quality buildings and others. Similar bets have been made by private equity firms such as Brookfield and KKR, as workers return to offices seeking better workspaces. Goldman invested a mix of clients' and firm capital in the 100 million euro deal, citing post-corona opportunities for better buildings.

site_title: Wealth tax - use 'shock therapy' cautiously
summary: Singapore is considering enhancing its wealth taxes to narrow the wealth gap, but experts caution against it due to potential risks of capital flight and discouraging entrepreneurship. A progressive wealth tax on property gains above S$3 million could generate revenue, but it may also deter investments and talent. Implementing a wealth tax could undermine Singapore's competitive edge and contradict its meritocratic values. Experts propose alternative solutions, such as increasing income tax rates, improving social safety nets, and promoting entrepreneurship and philanthropy to bridge the wealth gap.

site_title: Luxury looks homeward as Covid curtails travel
summary: Luxury brands have seen a significant rebound in sales, with LVMH, Kering, and Richemont reporting profits and sales above pre-pandemic levels. The "upper middle class, rich, and ultra-rich" have driven the recovery, with Chinese buyers making purchases at home rather than in Europe. The US market has also seen a strong rebound, with Hermes and other brands experiencing significant growth. This recovery is attributed to a combination of factors, including increased wealth among Americans, digital marketing, and a younger generation's comfort with luxury purchases.

site_title: China's new home price growth slows in July: private survey
summary: China's new home prices slowed in July for the first time in five months, growing 0.35% from June, due to higher mortgage rates, price caps, and other measures to cool speculation. Smaller cities were particularly affected, while larger cities like Shanghai and Beijing continued to see price growth. Resale homes also showed slower growth, and land sales declined 25% from a month earlier.

site_title: Twitter offering cash 'bounty' to find algorithmic bias
summary: Twitter is launching a cash "bounty" competition to identify algorithmic bias on its platform, with prizes up to $3,500. The competition, inspired by bug bounty programs, aims to find and mitigate unintended ethical harms in machine learning models. This move comes amid growing concerns about automated algorithmic systems incorporating bias, as seen in Twitter's own recent discovery of bias in an automated image-cropping system. The goal is to cultivate a community of researchers and users to proactively identify and address algorithmic harms.

site_title: Flexi-work leaves San Francisco trailing NYC in office comeback
summary: The San Francisco office market, once a hub for tech companies, is trailing behind New York City in its office comeback. Despite the flexibility offered by flexi-work, the tech sector's spreading concerns about the Delta variant have stalled momentum. As a result, the San Francisco office space remains vacant, with a fifth of all office space vacant, and rents have dropped 14%. This trend is in contrast to other major cities, such as New York City, which is seeing a faster recovery.

site_title: Airbus production plans expose strategy rift with engine makers
summary: Airbus is planning to almost double jet production in a few years, capitalizing on a bulging order book and Boeing's woes. However, engine makers are concerned that this increased output will lead to the early retirement of planes, negatively impacting their repair business and supply chain capacity. This rift between Airbus and engine makers is a result of contrasting business strategies, with Airbus prioritizing growth and engine makers focusing on maintenance and repair. The disagreement has masked deeper issues within the aerospace industry.

site_title: From miners to Big Oil, the great commodity cash machine is back
summary: The natural resources sector is experiencing a resurgence, with commodity prices surging due to consumer spending on physical goods and infrastructure projects. Companies like Anglo American, Rio Tinto, and Vale are paying out record dividends and buying back shares, with some announcing billions in profits. The sector's recovery is driven by a supply shortage, as miners and oil companies have cut spending on new projects, and a strong demand for raw materials. While concerns about climate change and the long-term future of the industry persist, bullish forecasts predict constrained supply and strong demand, supporting prices for commodities like copper and oil.

site_title: BT podcasts' Money Hacks marks 100 episodes
summary: BT's popular personal finance podcast series Money Hacks has reached its 100th episode, marking a milestone in its 3-year journey since its launch in 2018. Hosted by Christopher Lim, the podcast has become a staple in Singapore, regularly topping the downloads chart. With prominent guests such as Ravi Menon and Li Hongyi, Money Hacks has established itself as a viable platform for corporations to reach BT's audience, and has paved the way for the launch of two more podcast series.

site_title: Desperate grounded pilots swamp aviation recruiters in fight for jobs
summary: Desperate pilots, who have been grounded by the pandemic for over a year, are flooding aviation recruiters with applications for limited flying jobs. 400 resumes poured in for a Boeing 737 cargo pilot position in 48 hours, with many former commercial passenger jet pilots seeking work. The industry has been decimated, with 150,000 job losses last year, and global airline capacity remains 31% below normal levels. As pilots approach the end of their validity periods, some are opting to leave the industry altogether, leading to a potential shortage of skilled operators in the cockpit.

site_title: Claims management measures help boost Integrated Shield 2020 results
summary: Five out of seven Integrated Shield (IP) insurers ended 2020 in the black, thanks to the pandemic suppressing claims as policyholders postponed non-emergency treatments. The big question is whether these gains are sustainable. Insurers, such as Prudential, have introduced measures like claims-based pricing to contain costs and drive more prudent healthcare consumption. The Ministry of Health has also formed a committee to manage rising healthcare costs. Despite some insurers' caution on premium hikes, others, like Prudential, see claims-based pricing as a key factor in their turnaround.

site_title: Industrial S-Reits confident on resiliency
summary: Industrial S-Reits in Singapore have shown resilience despite global economic challenges, with a 20.9% average total return in the year-to-date. The sub-segment has attracted over S$315 million in net retail investor fund inflows. Key performers include ARA Logos Logistics Trust, Aims Apac Reit, EC World Reit, Sabana Reit, and ESR-Reit, which have reported significant revenue and net property income growth. The sector's resilience is attributed to its diversified tenant base and nature of property tenanted to light industrial production and manufacturing.

site_title: South Korea's July exports jump to record though growth pace slows
summary: South Korea's exports reached a record high in July, with a 29.6% increase from the same month last year to $55.43 billion. This marks the ninth consecutive month of export growth, driven by demand for chips and biohealth products. However, the growth pace slowed from 39.8% in June. Imports also rose 38.2% from last year. The Bank of Korea forecasts 4% economic growth this year, relying on global demand to lead the recovery.

site_title: Anti-vax app squares off with Apple, Google over misinformation
summary: A new social app, Unjected, designed for unvaccinated individuals, has sparked controversy after accumulating 18,000 downloads. The app, launched in May, allows users to connect and share information, but Google Play removed it for spreading misinformation about Covid-19 vaccines. Apple also removed the app from its App Store, citing its "inappropriate" reference to the pandemic. Unjected's co-founder, Shelby Thomson, plans to restore the social feed and flagged posts, claiming the platform is meant to exercise freedom of choice, not harm society.

site_title: Strong reversal in play for GBPUSD
summary: The GBPUSD (pound/US dollar) has seen a remarkable V-shape recovery, breaching April's low and bouncing off February support at 1.3567, with a bullish picture painted by chart patterns and technical indicators. A break from the descending channel and RSI breaking above its neutrality level of 50 signal further upside. The MACD indicator also supports the bullish outlook as it gets closer to the positive region. The first price target is set at 1.40, with potential historical resistance around 1.4090.

site_title: US debt ceiling suspension ends, Congress unclear on next step
summary: The US debt ceiling suspension ended, and the federal government is now authorized to borrow up to $28.5 trillion. Lawmakers have yet to outline a plan to address the issue, putting the US at risk of default as early as October. The Treasury Department has taken special measures to shore up cash, and Democrats have expressed uncertainty about how to approach the debt ceiling. A solution is needed to avoid a default, which has not occurred since the 1980s.

site_title: US dollar rises but still set for biggest weekly loss since May
summary: The US dollar rose on Friday, reversing some of its losses from earlier in the week, as upbeat economic data and dovish remarks from the Federal Reserve boosted investor confidence. The dollar rose 0.34% against other currencies, while Japan's yen and Norway's kroner also gained. The gains came after the US Federal Reserve's St. Louis president, James Bullard, suggested reducing the $120 billion monthly bond purchases, paving the way for a potential interest rate hike in 2022.

site_title: Amazon faces more than slowing sales growth - it needs more warehouses
summary: Amazon faces pressure to expand its warehouse and delivery system due to slowing sales growth. Despite shoppers venturing outside, the company is returning to pre-lockdown sales patterns. This requires significant investment, estimated to be in the billions of dollars, putting downward pressure on shares. Amazon's forecast of lower sales growth led to a 7% share drop on July 30. The company must adapt to changing consumer behavior and meet growing demand to avoid further decline.

site_title: Warehouse giant GLP sees frothy valuations in certain logistics assets
summary: GLP, a Singapore-based logistics giant, sees asset values soaring in the global logistics sector, with prices rising 20% in some markets over the past year. Managing director Ralf Wessel warns that frothy valuations may emerge if investors deploy capital too quickly without distinguishing high-quality assets from lower-quality ones. However, GLP remains disciplined and focused on high-quality assets, particularly in dense urban areas with strong domestic consumption. The company expects low interest rates and high investor demand to continue driving price gains, with its data-centre business also showing strong growth.

site_title: Malaysia defers parliament session amid calls for Muhyiddin to resign
summary: Malaysia's parliament session has been postponed indefinitely due to a Covid-19 outbreak, likely easing pressure on Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin amid calls for his resignation. The decision follows a health ministry assessment that found the parliament building to be at risk of infection spread. The postponement comes after a king rebuked a government minister for misleading parliament on the status of emergency ordinances, deepening Muhyiddin's troubles. The opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim urged Muhyiddin to step down, and hundreds of protesters gathered in Kuala Lumpur calling for his resignation.

site_title: 113 new locally transmitted Covid-19 cases in Singapore
summary: Singapore reported 113 new locally transmitted COVID-19 cases on Sunday, with 38 new unlinked cases and seven seniors above 70 who are partially vaccinated or unvaccinated. The total number of cases stands at 65,102. Meanwhile, eight imported cases were detected, with one arriving in Singapore and the others testing positive during stay-home notice or isolation.

site_title: Israeli exporters on edge with central bank dollar plan in doubt
summary: Israeli exporters are concerned about the end of the Bank of Israel's US$30 billion dollar-buying program, which has helped keep the shekel low and made exports cheaper. The program is set to expire, and companies such as Teva Pharmaceutical Industries and Israel Aerospace Industries are bracing for the potential impact on their industry. The program's expiration is seen as a temporary measure to support the economy during the pandemic, and exporters are worried about the consequences of a rising shekel on their competitiveness.

site_title: Sofa, so good for Koda as the furniture maker looks to grow further
summary: Koda Ltd, a Singapore-based furniture maker, plans to boost production capacity in Vietnam to meet growing demand amid the pandemic. The company aims to have 100 stores in China by 2022 and has already started sourcing furniture from China to fortify its supply. Koda's retail arm, Commune, has seen double-digit growth in Singapore and China, driven by the shift to working from home. The company is diversifying its product line, including the manufacturing of sofas, and expects robust demand for furniture in Europe. Despite challenges such as raw material costs and Covid-19 restrictions, Koda remains confident in its growth prospects.

site_title: Deutsche Bank, Societe Generale among weakest lenders in European stress test
summary: Deutsche Bank and Societe Generale emerged as the weakest large European lenders in a stress test, with Deutsche Bank's CET1 ratio falling to 7.4% and Societe Generale's ratio dropping to 7.5%. The test, conducted by the European Banking Authority, found that banks are better prepared to deal with a severe economic crisis than they were three years ago, with a CET1 ratio of 15% at the end of last year. The results will guide regulators in assessing capital needs and dividend levels, and will influence the European Central Bank's decision on dividend payouts and staff bonuses.

site_title: SolarWinds hack reached 27 US attorneys' offices: Justice Department
summary: The US Justice Department confirmed that hackers behind the SolarWinds cyberattack gained access to employee e-mail accounts in 27 US attorneys' offices, compromising Microsoft 365 accounts of at least 80% of employees. The breach affected employees in offices in the Eastern, Northern, Southern, and Western Districts of New York, as well as 14 other states. The Justice Department suspects Russian state-sponsored hackers were behind the attack, which also affected at least nine US federal government agencies and about 100 companies.

site_title: Local pro Koh Dengshan off to Florida to hone craft
summary: Singaporean professional golfer Koh Dengshan is heading to Florida for a four-month stint to hone his craft, competing in the US PGA Tour's Qualifying School and practicing at world-class venues. The 33-year-old golfer, who has never played in the US before, is partially sponsored by Sentosa Golf Club and fintech company FTAG, and aims to learn valuable tips on biomechanics, psychology, and mental aspects of the game. If he makes the cut, he will get a slot in the Korn Ferry Tour, the developmental Tour for the US PGA Tour.

site_title: Sembmarine 'deliberately priced' rights issue at affordable level
summary: Sembmarine's latest rights issue, priced at 35.7% discount to theoretical ex-rights price, aims to encourage subscription by all shareholders at an affordable level. The issue, to raise S$1.5 billion, is led by Temasek Holdings, which has committed to subscribe up to 67% of the rights issue. The company needs another infusion of funds due to losses in the first half of FY2021, primarily caused by Covid-19 pandemic restrictions. The board prefers not to go to shareholders again for funds, but uncertainties and market factors may change the situation.

site_title: Muted launch for South-east Asia's largest railway station
summary: Bangkok's massive Bang Sue Grand Station, Southeast Asia's largest railway station, is set to hold a soft opening on Monday, with thousands of Thais receiving COVID-19 vaccinations on site. The Red Line, a 40km elevated track, will launch a free trial passenger service, but ridership is expected to be low due to the ongoing pandemic. The station, completed last year, has been used temporarily as a vaccination center and will remain largely vacant until an official opening in November. The station's commercial space remains unoccupied, with the State Railway of Thailand holding unsuccessful bids for a public-private partnership.

site_title: Sunak calls for urgent easing of UK travel rules
summary: British Chancellor Rishi Sunak has called for the urgent easing of the UK's travel restrictions, citing their damaging effect on the country's tourism industry and economy. With 72% of UK adults fully vaccinated, the restrictions are out of step with international competitors, Sunak wrote to Prime Minister Boris Johnson. Ministers are set to discuss travel guidelines this week, with up to a dozen countries expected to be moved from the amber to the green list.

site_title: Celebrate National Day, belanja a meal
summary: Deliveroo Singapore has partnered Food from the Heart for Project Belanja!, a hot food redemption initiative for the less fortunate. For National Day, Deliveroo waived its onboarding fee and welcomed new hawkers onto its platform, including Jack's Kitchen and Xin Kee Hainanese Chicken Rice. This partnership aims to provide freshly-cooked meals and create new revenue streams for hawkers amid Covid-19 restrictions.

images.alt_text: Deliveroo customers can order a meal from any of the participating Project Belanja! hawker stalls, and Deliveroo will match and donate the value of all meals purchased till Aug 8.

site_title: Fed reverse repo volume hits US$1t as debt ceiling looms
summary: US Federal Reserve's reverse repo facility hit a record $1 trillion in volume last Friday, driven by investors seeking safe-haven assets amid the looming US debt ceiling and Treasury bill issuance cuts. The financial system is holding $4 trillion in reserves, with the Treasury General Account dropping by over $1 trillion since last autumn. The Fed's rate hike on reverse repo agreements and the rapid drawdown of government funds are contributing to the increased liquidity. Analysts predict usage of the programme could top $2 trillion by the end of the year.

site_title: MNACT directors add to their stakes
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.7% in the five-trading sessions from July 23-29, driven by Mapletree Industrial Trust and Singapore Airlines, which received the highest net institutional inflows. Despite this, institutions were net sellers over the period, totaling S$366 million. Share buybacks were limited, with only The Hour Glass and Global Palm Resources conducting transactions. Director and substantial shareholder transactions also slowed ahead of earnings season. Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust's CEO Cindy Chow Pei Pei acquired 200,000 units of the trust, increasing her stake to 0.03%. Raffles Medical Group's independent director Allen Lew Yoong Keong acquired 200,000 shares, while Second Chance Properties' founder Mohamed Salleh Marican increased his stake to 69.23%. Keppel DC Reit and Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit also announced new acquisitions.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report highlights the week's tanker and dry bulk market developments. The Capesize market strengthened due to Pacific route disruptions caused by typhoon In-Fa, with the 5TC index rising $3,244 week-on-week to $35,713. Panamax rates remained soft, with the Atlantic basin struggling due to limited activity. Supramax rates showed positive gains, while Handysize and VLCC rates also saw some movement. The market is expected to stabilize as order is restored after the typhoon.

site_title: China securities body seeks talks with US SEC on overseas IPOs
summary: China's securities regulator, the CSRC, has called for talks with the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) over the suspension of Chinese companies' initial public offerings (IPOs) due to improved risk disclosures. The SEC halted IPOs of Chinese firms until they improve their disclosures to protect investors. The CSRC seeks mutual respect and collaboration on the issue, amid China's crackdown on private industry and increased oversight of its private enterprises. Roughly 70 Chinese companies are in the pipeline for US IPOs, with some deterred by the increased scrutiny.

site_title: Heroes, rivals, records: Tokyo swimming had it all except fans
summary: The 2020 Tokyo Olympics swimming events showcased memorable performances and world records, despite the absence of Michael Phelps. The US team secured 11 gold medals, while Australia achieved a historic nine golds and 20 medals overall. Caeleb Dressel won three individual golds, and Katie Ledecky dominated the women's events, while rivalries between athletes like Dressel and Titmus generated excitement. Australia's Emma McKeon made history by winning seven medals, including four golds, and Britain achieved unprecedented success with four golds.

site_title: Wild puma found living in New York apartment
summary: A 36kg wild cougar, named Sasha, was rescued from a New York apartment in the Bronx after being living there with its owner. Authorities, including the Humane Society and Bronx Zoo personnel, worked together to remove the big cat, which was taken to the Bronx Zoo for examination. Sasha was then transported to an animal sanctuary in Arkansas, where she will be cared for. The incident is part of a larger issue of exotic pets, with animal rights activists pushing for stronger laws to prohibit breeding and possession of certain species.

site_title: All eyes on dividend payout from banks in Q2
summary: Singapore's three major banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, are expected to lift their dividend payouts when they report their second-quarter results, following the lifting of regulatory caps. Analysts forecast a 50% payout ratio, translating to a 4.6% dividend yield, which should support share prices. Earnings are expected to rise due to a post-pandemic recovery, with fee income and credit growth expected to recover from the impact of recent social restrictions.

site_title: Positive factory data a boost for locally listed tech plays: analysts
summary: Singapore's listed tech manufacturers have seen strong share price gains year-to-date, with the technology sector outperforming, averaging 27.9% in total returns. Positive manufacturing data, including a 14.5% year-on-year rise in total manufacturing output, bodes well for earnings in the second half of the year. Analysts are bullish on semiconductors, with stocks like Frencken and UMS expected to perform well, while downstream players may see mixed fortunes due to a global chip shortage. The sector's outlook remains positive, with growth expected in the next 12 months and beyond.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: Singapore Government Bonds quotation as of Aug 31, 2021, is available. No further information is provided in the article.

site_title: Kitchen Culture lodges report with CAD on payroll irregularities; board responds to SGX
summary: Kitchen Culture Holdings lodged a report with the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) over suspected payroll irregularities involving two former employees, totaling about S$520,000. The company's board also revealed that it fired former CEO Lim Wee Li due to "grave misconduct" and breaches of Catalist rules, but an independent director, Yap Sze Hon, disagreed with the decision, citing a lack of evidence and potential unfairness. The board listed several potential breaches, including loan repayments and cash transfers without proper documentation.

site_title: US dollar at 3-week lows as traders await tapering clues
summary: The US dollar is trading near three-week lows against a basket of currencies due to uncertainty over the timing of the Federal Reserve's stimulus taper. Following Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's comments at the Jackson Hole conference, analysts will closely watch US payrolls numbers due out on Friday for clues on tapering. The dollar index slipped to 92.456, while the euro gained 0.4% to a three-week high of US$1.18370, and sterling reached a two-week high of US$1.38010.

site_title: Chinese cities test millions, impose new travel curbs as virus cases surge
summary: China is battling a widespread coronavirus outbreak, with 75 new cases reported, including 53 local transmissions. Cities are imposing fresh travel restrictions and mass testing millions of people, particularly those linked to an eastern airport cluster that has spread to over 20 cities and 13 provinces. The surge in cases raises pressure on policymakers, with China's GDP growth expected to slow.

images.alt_text: Chinese cities rolled out mass testing of millions of people and imposed fresh travel restrictions as health authorities battled on Sunday to contain the country's most widespread coronavirus outbreak in months.

site_title: WHO experts say urgent search for Covid-19 origins 'stalled'
summary: WHO experts say the search for Covid-19 origins has stalled, despite time running out. The initial report concluded the virus likely jumped from bats to humans via an intermediate animal, while a lab-leak hypothesis is deemed "extremely unlikely". The WHO team calls for further research on disease reporting, antibody surveys, and wildlife farms, as the window of opportunity for tracing the earliest cases is closing. China has refused to share crucial data, citing politics, not science, and US intelligence agencies have presented inconclusive findings on the lab-leak hypothesis.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close flat, set for August gains
summary: European stocks closed flat on Monday, ending at 472.68 points, but are set for a 2.4% rise in August, its seventh consecutive month of gains. Chemical stocks rose 0.6% and technology stocks 0.5%, driven by the US Federal Reserve's continued support for the economy. Oil and gas stocks closed flat after crude prices retreated from three-week highs due to a hurricane in the US Gulf coast. The European Central Bank expects the Delta variant to have limited impact on the euro zone economy due to an advanced vaccination campaign.

site_title: Investors should scrutinise Razer's B2B fintech bet
summary: Razer is ceasing its consumer e-wallet, Razer Pay, and instead focusing on its B2B fintech business, which has seen significant growth. The company processed $3.2 billion in total payment volume in the half-year ended June, up 79.5% year on year. Investors are concerned about Razer's ability to generate value from its B2B fintech investments, as the company's core business is hardware and not payments. Despite this, Razer's strong financial position, with a $517 million cash pile and no debt, gives it the funds to invest in growth.

site_title: UK construction, refurbishment costs to soar on tighter climate change regulations, materials and labour inflation
summary: UK construction and refurbishment costs are expected to rise due to tighter climate change regulations, materials and labor inflation, and the coronavirus pandemic. By 2023, landlords in London and other cities must install minimum energy efficiency standards, with buildings required to have an energy efficiency rating of at least "E". Refurbishment is expected to be the primary option for properties with low energy efficiency ratings, with companies like British Land and Land Securities aiming to meet government and industry proposals for net-zero emissions by 2030.

site_title: US: Stocks hesitate at open
summary: US stocks opened trading on a hesitant note, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq nearly flat after ending at records in the prior session. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.1% to 35,454.39, while the S&P 500 slipped 0.1% to 4,492.29, and the Nasdaq Composite Index edged up 0.1% to 15,050.67. Traders are awaiting Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's speech at the Jackson Hole symposium, which could include hints of changes to stimulus policies, and await government data on new unemployment claims and GDP.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing to grow more slowly as chip supply crunch kicks in
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector is expected to slow down due to a chip supply crunch, with factory output growth moderating to single digits from September. The electronics cluster saw a decline in semiconductor production, with output growth cooling to 1.5% in July. However, economists remain optimistic about the overall manufacturing sector, citing the biomedical segment's outsized growth. Despite a slowdown, economists expect services to lead the recovery in Q4 2021, and the chip supply situation may resolve over time.

site_title: Stocks to watch: LMIRT, AusGroup, Ellipsiz, ESR-Reit
summary: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) reopened 7 malls and 2 retail spaces in Indonesia, with shares rising 3.3% to 6.3 cents. AusGroup reported a full-year net profit of A$1.2 million, reversing losses of A$59.5 million. Ellipsiz posted a net profit of S$3.1 million, reversing a loss of S$689,000. ESR-Reit listed 124.1 million new units at 40 cents per unit, raising S$49.6 million.

site_title: Can the Straits Times Index hit a new all-time high?
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) has climbed 38% above its pandemic trough, but is still 19% off its 2007 peak of 3,831.19. The index's last major revamp occurred in 2007, when it reduced the number of companies from 49 to 30. Over the past 14 years, 18 of the original 30 constituents have remained, while 12 have been replaced. The STI's key components, including the three local banks and seven Reits, are expected to drive growth, with the banks' fee income and Reits' stable rental income providing a boost to the index.

site_title: Singapore stock market cap at lowest since March
summary: The Singapore stock market experienced a decline in August, with the total market capitalization falling 1.5% to its lowest level since March, reaching S$846.1 billion. The Straits Times Index (STI) also fell 3.6%, while the technology sector was the strongest globally, with indices like the Philadelphia Stock Exchange Semiconductor Index gaining 5.8% in August. Losers outpaced gainers 328 to 178, with Jardine Matheson Holdings being the biggest loser, and local banks averaging a 2.0% decline in total return.

site_title: Chip shortage set to worsen as Covid-19 rampages through Malaysia
summary: A surge in Covid-19 infections in Malaysia threatens to worsen the global chip shortage, impacting automakers that rely on the country's semiconductor testing and packaging facilities. Key suppliers such as Infineon Technologies, NXP Semiconductors, and STMicroelectronics operate plants in Malaysia. The country's emergence as a major chip testing and packaging hub has made it an important player in technology supply chains, despite not being as prominent as Taiwan, South Korea, or Japan. The shortage has already affected automakers for months, and the worsening situation in Malaysia is expected to exacerbate the issue.

site_title: Europe: Shares mark biggest daily drop in a month as miners, luxury stocks tumble
summary: European shares dropped 1.6% to a two-week low, with mining stocks falling 4.2% and luxury stocks declining 5.8-9.2% due to a Chinese crackdown on excessive corporate profits and wealth inequalities. The slump was also influenced by US Federal Reserve policy minutes hinting at a potential cut in its pandemic-era bond-buying program. The European Central Bank's decision to hold steady on monetary policies has raised concerns about rising inflation.

site_title: Mission minded: philanthropist Nicole Shanahan
summary: Philanthropist Nicole Shanahan is funding research into "reproductive longevity" at the National University of Singapore's Yong Loo Lin School of Medicine, with a $8 million gift. Her goal is to extend female fertility and improve reproductive health in women, particularly in their later years. Shanahan, 35, personally struggled with infertility and was inspired by the concept of "reproductive longevity." She has established the Centre for Female Reproductive Longevity and Equality with the Buck Institute and plans to develop new diagnostic tools, therapies, and treatments. Shanahan's foundation also focuses on criminal justice reform and environmental sustainability.

site_title: Silly season: How did the football transfers game get so Messi?
summary: Lionel Messi's transfer to Paris Saint-Germain (PSG) marked a turning point in the football transfer market, with the six-time Ballon d'Or winner becoming the world's most desirable free agent after his contract expired with Barcelona. Messi signed a two-year contract with PSG, worth 729,000 euros per week, and a 25 million-euro signing-on fee. The move highlights how the transfer market has become increasingly lucrative, with top players earning salaries comparable to those of top CEOs. The market's growth can be attributed to factors such as the rise of football agents, TV broadcast rights agreements, and oligarch club owners.

site_title: China Telecom surges in 2021's biggest listing, beating Kuaishou
summary: China Telecom Corp, the country's second-largest mobile operator, made its market debut in Shanghai, surging 44% over its offer price, becoming the world's biggest listing in 2021. The surge indicates enthusiasm for China's push to build the world's largest 5G networks. China Telecom is seeking diversified financing channels after being removed from the New York Stock Exchange. The company plans to use proceeds to develop 5G infrastructure, cloud businesses, and research and development. This listing may signal more Chinese companies listing abroad, following China Telecom's success.

site_title: GM workers in Mexico defeat union in first test of US trade deal
summary: General Motors workers in Silao, Mexico, have voted to scrap their collective contract, marking the first test of labor rules under the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement. In a vote of 5,876 employees, 3,214 rejected the bargaining agreement, while 2,623 voted to keep it. The outcome was seen as a historic move, with many workers criticizing their union for not fighting hard enough for better salaries. The vote was conducted under new labor safeguards agreed upon by Mexico and the US.

site_title: US: China stocks in resume slide after brutal sell-off in Asia
summary: US-listed Chinese stocks continued their downward trend after China's regulatory crackdown, with American depositary receipts for tech giants like Tencent and Alibaba falling over 3% at the trading open. The slump comes as Beijing studies proposals to regulate online drivers and the live streaming industry. The decline has prompted some of the world's top investors to exit their holdings, with the Nasdaq Golden Dragon China Index plummeting 52% in six months.

site_title: Tolaram-led funding raises over US$700k for food-tech startup Shandi to produce plant-based chicken in Singapore
summary: Tolaram Group has led a US$700,000 funding round for Singapore-based food-tech startup Shandi to produce plant-based chicken products. The fresh capital will be used to set up a manufacturing facility in Singapore and expand partnerships in the food sector. Shandi will also allocate funds for product innovation and development of new textures, formats, and meat analogues. This investment aims to commercialize and scale the company's proprietary plant-based chicken products, further solidifying its presence in the Singapore food-tech market.

site_title: Norway's US$1.4t fund flags more unlisted property deals
summary: Norway's $1.4 trillion sovereign wealth fund is making more deals in unlisted property after a pandemic-hit market is showing signs of recovery. The fund paid $391.9 million for a 47.5% stake in a US office property in Cambridge, Massachusetts, marking the largest asset trade this year. Investments in unlisted real estate have returned 4.6% in the first half, while the listed property business returned 14%. The fund aims to deploy more capital in the coming years and will be a major player in the private real estate market.

site_title: Japan's faster vaccine roll-out is good news for the economy
summary: Japan is on track to meet its goal of having 51% of its population fully vaccinated by September 12, beating the US inoculation rate, according to the country's vaccine drive. This rapid rollout is expected to boost the economy, which has endured multiple virus emergencies. Economists predict that vaccinations will have a significant impact, leading to the lifting of restrictions and a rebound in consumer spending. However, the spread of the delta variant and lower vaccination rates among younger generations pose challenges to the recovery.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed on Delta variant gloom
